review.description:
Located in the same building as the Ogilvie Metra Train Station this food vendor & specialty market definitely has a very European feel. Very similar in nature to ones you'd find in train stations in Europe but larger than many of those. Lots of fresh sandwiches, sushi, pierogis, Korean, Belgian Frites, Dim Sum, pizza, vegan, markets with fresh fruits and veggies and many more. Plus you walk in by the French Bakery - who doesn't want a bag of Macarons to take home? 

We came hungry for a late lunch before catching our Metra home and wandered all the aisles before making a decision. I ordered a fresh mozzarella & prosciutto sandwich at Firenze Italian Street Food and my husband got a Tuesday special corned beef sandwich from City Fresh Market. We were both quite happy with our selections. And we did get Macarons on our way out. 

There's a cute area set up with tables that attempts to replicate French Bistro dining. Overall it's definitely an attractive space and you're likely to find something you'll enjoy. Cost for a lunch for 2 is in the $20-25 range. We also noticed there are Happy Hour Specials.
review.author: Mac R.

review.description:
How have I not reviewed the French Market yet???  I take the train every single day into the city for work, and stop in the market at least once a week for goodies.  

They have some great places in the market, but my favorites are:

1.  Patisserie (when you first walk in, to your right).  The French macarons are AMAZING and the best I've ever had (and expensive!), as well as the filled croissants.  SOOO GOOD.

2.  I can't remember the name, but it's way in the back, and they sell salamis and cured meats.  They have the best pastrami EVER.  You have to order it in advance.  What I do is order a lb of fresh pastrami in the morning when I get off the train around 8:15 a.m.  And I pick it up around 5pm after work before I get on the train.  We fry it in the pan to heat it up, and melt swiss cheese over it and eat it on toasted rye.  Delicious!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

3.  Flip Crepes.  These Gluten-free crepes are delicious!  I usually get the Bam Jam for breakfast, or the Strawberry Dream. That vanilla cream the put inside is decadent.

I haven't been to many of their other vendors, but they really are all good, from what I can tell.

If you take a train in to the Ogilvie train station, go down the stairs that you see right when you get off the train.  It's downstairs, along with a few other places to eat/shop.
review.author: Karen K.

review.description:
Seriously. I am so in love with whoever made this place a part of my reality. Awesome little spot with places to shop and eat. Anyone who knows me I love to both shop and eat!

I've already tried K Kitchen and Santullo's. I can't wait to go back to I can have me some empanadas. I love me some empanadas. #forreal
review.author: Michelle M.

review.description:
I like this French Market located at the Chicago Ogilvie Transportation Center. If enter the center from the south, you need to go to second floor and follow track 8 and 10 to station then walk down from the station. I like it located at the station give rider to have chance for food before onboard to their trip. 

This market is not too old. Found at 2009. The market become the tourist attraction and so for the local. This market has fresh produce, art, and their original food hall. The art section is small. The market is big enough to get something for your home cooking. However the food hall is big with many vendors for restaurant types of food. 

The food hall line up includes the poke, sushi, dim sum, crepe, Cajun, cheese, Italian pizza and sandwich, raw bar, espresso, Vietnamese, French lunch box, sweet and more. The only thing to prepare is not to go there wear a good clothes. Because the food smells will stick to your clothes. This also come to this area need a good ventilation system for all oil cook smell.
review.author: Boon C.

review.description: I can't believe after living in Chicago and working down the street for the time that I have that I haven't checked out this place sooner. There is a food cuisine for any type of foodie. Great place to take those co-workers or friends who are often indecisive on where to eat for lunch.
review.author: Samantha Z.

review.description: My husband had a smoked Montréal pastrami sandwich that was great, I unfortunately chose the Maine lobster roll place, which was way over-priced and the sandwich had a bitter aftertaste like their flat top needed cleaning. Avoid it. The crepes and other choices were quite good.
review.author: Joan N.

review.description: It was smaller than expected yet had some great food options, a small grocery area, and a lively feel.  We attended a Belgian Frites event that was so much fun.  That place made an amazing burger also.  I'd love to return.
review.author: Scott H.

review.description: This is a pretty cool place to hang out in Chicago.  They have a lot of variety of types of food.  We got to try some of the tea places and walk around and check out other stuff it has to offer.  They also have a big seating area for you to enjoy the treats you bought!
review.author: Danny N.

review.description:
I was really, really pleased that the French Market took part in Bastille Day (July 14, 2018) this year with the vendor Pastoral offering a French wine and cheese tasting in which it appeared that several dozen people attended!

How fun! It was the first Bastille Day Wine and Cheese Event that they have held at the Chicago French Market.  The event was very comprehensive in nature and open to the public. It offered three wine tastings and three cheese tastings which were guided by Pastoral's cheese monger and manager.

I loved every minute of it and hope to attend next year!

FYI-Pastoral Wine and Cheese was one of the first stores that opened in the Chicago French Market and offers specialty cheese, charcuterie and bread, chocolates, crackers, deli sandwiches, cornichons, plus wine & craft beer.
review.author: Christina S.

review.description: I love the wide variety of food vendors the Chicago French Market has from different cultural backgrounds! Craving tacos, sushi and a burger all at once? You can find it here. This place has a large selection of vendors to chose from. Although the vendors rotate every few months, there's always something new and exciting to be found here. I tried the dapper doughnut vendor over the summer, it was delicious but definitely overpriced; 4 tiny doughnut holes came out be around $4 (can't remember the exact price), so keep in mind that the vendors usually charge more than they would at their original locations. With that being said, it's nice to try many different types of food at once at higher prices then visit their restaurant and eat at a more reasonable price if you decide you like the vendor.
review.author: Sumeja F.

review.description:
It's a must-stop EVERY TIME on our way outta town, if we took the metra... which we generally do. Like any public market, it's a full range of everything you'd ever want for your hectic business lunch schedule and more. Me, I'm from Wisconsin, so if I'm here, it's usually pretty casual, and I'll go with an open mind and empty gut. 
This last time, I stopped at the deli counter and snagged a prosciutto, Brie and blueberry sandwich. Yup. It was as amazing in my mouth as it was odd on paper.
I also made a stop at the poke stand, and grabbed me a bowl of fish and avo and veg that I scooped up with the homemade tortilla chips. Delish!
And that's just the two items I chose THAT day.
review.author: Tony F.

review.description:
There are so many different varies of food places to eat here. Come prepared with an empty stomach to experience the adventure of The French Market. Very affordable prices. 

Its a bit crowded down here so please have your patience button on and ready to maneuver through the crowd. A Great Market to come and grab a quick lunch or make it a weekend fun day with the family or a friend.

There are so many vendors to choose from ranging from sushi, seafood, desserts and vegan options. I guarantee whatever your options are you won't be disappointed. The food is prepared freshly and hot. 

The Chicago French Market is just a remarkable place to come and enjoy the taste of some good food surrounding in good vibes.

The vendors are pretty nice and attentive to each of their customers. 

Depending on the time of your visit and your food preference the lines can be a bit long.
review.author: Maronda H.

review.description: This is a cute place to go for lunch. They have a variety of different cuisines and a small market. My favorite spots are aloha poke, k-kitchen, and Klay over kitchen.
review.author: Annie T.

review.description:
Maybe my expectations were too high,  but I was expecting to enjoy my time here.  In reality it felt more like a waste of time (especially considering how far we walked to get here, that was on me, should have ubered). 

When I think of a market I assume there will be a variety of vendors.  Not here, it's just prepared food... aside from one florist.  And had I not just ate the largest breakfast of my life before getting here, I would have like to have grabbed a coffee and a macaron or even a crape! Sadly that was not what how my time played out. We walked in a circle looked at all the food we didn't want, then left.

If you stop in for a meal, I'd say you would have an enjoyable time.  If you're coming here expecting a market, you'll most likely be disappointed.
review.author: Emma J.

review.description:
Not to be confused with the Chicago French Kiss, which happened to me several times last time I was here.

The French Market in Chicago is an expensive little indoor market that is along similar lines to the West Side Market in Cleveland and the North Market in Columbus. It's a little bit larger than the latter and perhaps is more evoking the Philadelphia Reading Terminal Market - but nowhere near as busy or as popular. Nor as good.

Yet parking around here is just as difficult! I would have thought that it would have been a little easier considering this isn't in the most fashionable neighbourhood of Chicago unlike the Reading Terminal Market of Philly, but they're definitely milking it for all it's worth.

Nevertheless it deserves four stars because it's the kind of place that tourists can come and feel warm and safe and have a lot of different options. Overpriced and sometimes hipster options but nevertheless, options.
review.author: Fox E.

review.description: This market was an awesome accidental find while walking randomly through the streets of Chicago. I had never heard of a French Market in Chicago, and I'm sad that I've never been here before! The atmosphere and setup reminded me a bit of North Market in Columbus, Ohio if you've ever been. There were a bunch of different food places like a macaron spot, an organic vegetable and fruit shop, a donut place, a polish stop, and so much more . I stopped at the macaron spot and got a 6 pack (coconut, rose, hazelnut, lavender, raspberry, and mango), and they all were very good. The next time I visit Chicago, I will definitely be stopping here again!
review.author: Erica A.

review.description:
WOW! I love the Chicago French Market. I commuted from the suburbs to the city for school and the French Market was a safe haven for me while waiting for my trains.

The Chicago French Market is made up of lots of booths offering an array of services from food to small gifts. It does get really busy but its also downtown Chicago (so not really surprising). It is a great place to go if you are looking for lunch, flowers for your girlfriend, or just a fun afternoon of roaming around!

I personally think the location is perfect especially for commuters. It is directly connected to Ogilvie Transportation Center (train station). You don't even need to leave the building to get here or to your train! 

Perfect. The market itself has a romantic, cozy, yet bustling vibe to it. It is very inviting and I could easily spend a few hours roaming the booths and the stations.

They have options went from around the world. They also have tons of vegetarian and vegan options. The BEST thing that I got here was macarons. Oh wow, they were some of the best macarons I have ever had. I would highly suggest!! I also found it a really useful stop to get a quick lunch or dinner or even a box of wine for my train ride home. 

If you are ever at OTC or just in the area, definitely stop through here. I doubt you will be disappointed as there seems to be a little something for everyone.
review.author: Davis C.

review.description: This place has everything you could want - great for a quick breakfast, work lunch or to go dinner and conveniently located in the Ogilvie transport center. You name it - raw salad, empanadas, poke bowls, crepes, sandwiches, dessert - all this and more in a precious market setting.
review.author: Kristin S.

review.description: I had about 30 minutes before my 6p train so took a nice stroll through the market. I'd been one time before during lunch when it was quite busy. Very well laid out with wide aisles. Lots of options from raw and vegan to soaps to carnivores' delight. What a great option for a treat, a gift or a meal.
review.author: David M.

review.description:
I was a little hesitant about this place, but it did not disappoint!  With all the food halls these days, there are many that aren't up to par, but the French Market offered lots of great eateries and seating.  I was shocked at the size of this place, there were so many vendors here.  Some vacancies which were a little concerning, but there seemed to be a decent number of people around.  

Another surprise to me was that the hours here are much more day oriented with not much of a night scene, this includes a lack of alcohol which most food halls typically have.  I came during the day so I wasn't looking out to drink, but just a warning if that's what you're after.

As for what I had, I'm not sure if I want to go into too much detail, but the Vietnamese place was great.  So was the crepe place.  Some of the restaurants here offer smaller portioned tapas which I thought was great, especially for those looking to try rather than just have one entree.  

Overall, I'd say this is a great food hall with pretty decent theming.  It's fairly accessible if you're in the area.  The food offerings here are fantastic with a lot of variety.  And there's plenty of seating so you don't have to concern yourself with that either.
review.author: Bryson L.

review.description:
I will definitely be coming back for lunch sometime, they have a huge selection for food and drinks even snacks and candy. 

On this occasion we happened to be waking by and went in to check it out. We had a beer at a small bar towards the back prices were reasonable. 

We got a free hot dog from a temporary place.
review.author: Jonathan M.

review.description: One of my favorite places to go in the city! So much variety to choose from sometimes it's to hard to decide. Absolutely love the raw carrot muffin from raw it was to delicious not to bit before the pic
review.author: Gary A.

review.description: I had heard about this place before but seeing it as another thing. I was really impressed. Great choices of world cuisine, snacks and fresh produce. I ended up choosing a place I had been to before in the city Litos empanadas. I went with the 3 empanadas and drink deal for about 11 bucks. They were light tasty, flaky. It's the place to be for morning meetings or lunches or if you're about to leave the city or just coming in quick and want to grab something.
review.author: Grant A.

review.description:
I love the variety of food that I can get here! I've only been here once so far but from walking around that time, I definitely want to go again. We got bahn mis and crepes, which is a fairly odd combination of food but we just couldn't make up our minds. The bahn mis were absolutely delicious. I would highly recommend trying the pho bahn mi! The beef was so flavorful and tender. We also tried the classic bahn mi but I definitely like the pho one better! 

As for the crepe place, we got two crepes- one with just butter and sugar and the other with butter, sugar and lemon. Between those two, we definitely liked the plain butter and sugar one more. The lemon juice was a little too overpowering. The crepes were fluffy, which is different from an authentic French crepe but still yummy nonetheless. They sell packets of the crepe flour for you to make at home. 

The seating was plentiful and they even have free WiFi. There was also a musician there singing and playing guitar. Really gave the place a nice feel. There are so many other food options to try and I can't wait to go back!
review.author: Rosy L.

review.description:
With old-timey trombone or folksy guitar music and hanging lights, this venue has become and remains one of my favorite balances of convenient and eccentric. Despite it nearly constant state of bustling crowds I have never felt inconvenienced, packed in, uncomfortable. Quite the opposite. I've never had to really wait in line for any of the wonderful vendors, or left wanting because I gave up waiting on my donuts, pizza, sushi, or beer. Yes, that is the plethora of edibles with many, many more I haven't tried yet. Bubble tea, french pastries and crepes, exotic chocolate truffles, even a fruit stand and a tiny deli with salted meats; everything you could want within a short distance to the Metra.

One note, is despite all my praise this market still has big-city price tags. If you are look for dollar energy drinks, or cheap pre-processed snacks, this is not your place. However, if you want a better experience in general, want a place to soak in the energy while you eat, relax, and refresh the extra price might very well be worth it.

I have talked about one particular vendor here before, but the whole market deserves its shout-out because it really lives up to its name. Much like the European markets I've envisioned in my mind the French Market embodies all the comfort of a warm crowd with the added benefits of being downtown Chicago, an oasis from a hectic city, especially in winter. I have had wonderful, and brief conversations with complete strangers, passing through on their way to the train, but stopping for a quick drink, or bite to eat. I thoroughly believe it is the layout and orientation of this venue that feels welcoming if albeit a bit touristy.
review.author: Andrew M.

review.description:
I try to go to the French Market every time I am in the city.  Being that this isn't very often, there is always something different.  It's a cute place although it's a little dark and depressing getting to it underground.  It's just fun to browse and get something to eat. 

I wish more people would go check it out.  Maybe more marketing at the train station.  There are tons of people that get out and get herded like cattle out to Madison.  If they just turned around and went downstairs right from the platform, they would get to the french market.  Also, the bathrooms on that level aren't as crowded when you get off the train!
review.author: Shevon R.

review.description:
Perfect place to browse, peruse, get a meal and dessert. And so many options you could come back everyday for a month and get something different. 

Conglomerate of a variety of food vendors and cuisines to select from (more than just French food). There are about 3-4 'lanes' of food stalls. 

There is an entrance at Clinton and also two entrances near the metra station. Also in the station is a CVS if you want to grab a cheap drink instead.
review.author: Kristin L.

review.description: 2 Star for the smoothie place. I came here at 630 and saw three staff cleaning up and not acknowledging me even though they close at 730. So I came back after getting another item because I wanted my smoothie. Staff seem reluctant to help. I got the El Classico smoothie bowl. It tasted like a melted ice cream popsicle. :/
review.author: Vi N.

review.description:
The CFM is a Chicago classic and I'd recommend it for anyone who wants a decent food-court-esque experience. 

The ambiance is a little strange and seating can sometimes be tough, but I'm a sucker for options, of which they have plenty. If I can eat pierogies, Italian sandwiches, and French macarons all in the same place, I'm a happy gal. 

Most of the vendors inside are a little pricey and there's definitely some room for improvement, but I think it's worth a stop if just for the novelty.
review.author: Abby B.

review.description: Cute little market with so many food places. There's beef jerky, pasta, sushi, lobster rolls, macarons, pastries, artisan condiments and cheese, fresh flowers, breakfast food, bubble tea, deli food, snacks and loads of other stuff. The price is not too bad.
review.author: Nandana N.

review.description: I finally made it to the French market the other day for lunch. I tried the empanadas from Litos and they were amazing. I had one chicken and one beef and they were so good I got a couple more to go for later! I will definitely be back!
review.author: Nerissa L.

review.description: Not just French influenced food and goodies! Everything from lobster rolls and dim sum to macaroons and french fries. I have seen the seating area get filled up pretty quickly. Fun place to spend an hour or two. Family friendly.
review.author: Gail G.

review.description: I cannot imagine a lovelier downtown market. This has been my go to spot whenever I come through Ogilvie, and it's my favorite reason to take the Metra. Saigon Sisters has delicious Vietnamese sandwiches and pho, and you cannot go wrong with anything from Black Dog for dessert (my favorite ice cream/gelato in all of Chicagoland). This is a great place to take out of towners to show off some of the fresh, high quality food our city has to offer. The atmosphere will transport you, and you can even grab snacks from the grocery section to fuel your downtown adventures (they have a wide variety of candies and yogurts).
review.author: Megan C.

review.description:
One of my favorite places to visit at any time throughout the year, located in the lower level of the Ogilvie Transportation Center. This is a great place to enjoy a great mix of premium foods without ever wandering into the sometimes cold and wet streets of downtown. Depending on the time, you may be able to also enjoy some free entertainment in a cozy setting.

The stores here change from time to time, although a few have remained in business for quite a while. It's competitive to own a restaurant in the loop and the French Market is not immune to this, despite naturally being located in a busy area. In particular, 2 staple restaurants I like are:

Vanille Patisserie: Despite lots of great places to get sweets in the loop, the elegance, clean flavors, premium ingredients, delicate designs, and clear themes in the food here make it worth the premium price for a treat.

Frietkoten: The heartiness and crispiness of these fries matched with the well-tuned sauces, all at reasonable prices makes this the standard by which I judge all other fries in Chicago.

Even if you are not dining here, there's several shops such as city fresh market, pastoral, fumare, and city fresh produce offering meats, cheeses, and fruits for reasonable prices. 

Other options range from Vietnamese to donuts to gourmet pastries to seafood to BBQ and others. Not all options here are the best, but overall they are above average and enjoyable (or else they go out of business within a year).

Definitely worth a visit if you take the train into the city or are a tourist to Chicago. You'll get exposed to lots of great food in a convenient spot. Also, check out revival food hall nearby for some other premium options.
review.author: Sherwin C.

review.description: I absolutely adore walking into the French market after my long train rides into the city. The French Market offers a variety of different vendors. The French market offers produce, groceries, kombucha, Health drinks, and snacks in the front of the market. To the right of the grocery section as I call it, they have the cutest cupcake stand. This is called vanille. The cupcakes are rather dear, but they are very beautiful. I like to go here to pick up special birthday treats for my friends and coworkers. A typical treat could be $3.25 to $10. The staff here is very sweet they're usually young girls who do an excellent job wrapping your cupcakes and sending you on your way. The French market has Asian cuisine, French cuisine, crepes, vegan, sandwiches, and chocolates. No matter what you are in the mood for, you can find it at the French market.
review.author: Shannon E.

review.description: Love the variety of food stalls here at the French Market! I also love that it's has been adding new vendors (now they have ceviche and empanadas stalls!). It's a great spot for lunch or before hopping on the Metra. The atmosphere itself is so cute with the string lights and live music. I never had a negative experience here, and I look forward to see what else they add!
review.author: Arielle A.

review.description: I like french market.i miss everyone .all of them are very nice !I want to work at french market everyday with everyone
review.author: Food L.

review.description: If you're with a group of picky people, or you just want to try a lot of different things, this place is for you! They have so many different vendors, and if you can't find anything to eat then you need to rethink your tastebuds! Sushi, sandwiches, poke, pierogis, pasta, Korean, vegan, crepes... pick one or pick it all! We decided on Da Lobsta and the pierogis, both were really good!
review.author: Ashley C.

review.description: This is a great place to go with a variety of people....especially the littles! Everyone can get whatever they want and meet to eat in a casual, relaxed environment. Most of the vendors sell excellent quality options at pretty fair prices. The fries with a variety of sauces are always a hit as are the crepes!
review.author: Cas T.

review.description:
This Market is FULL of E-A-T-S!!

So many booths to choose from, I know I'm going to come back again and again. The inside of this market is decorated like a street market and it's quite lovely- there is a very pretty backdrop of the Eiffel Tower adorned with comfy rattan café tables and chairs and lovely Parisian music from overhead. The stalls come in all sizes and the smells are tantalizing. 

I decided to visit some vendors instead of others due to the warmth and reception of the counter workers--as in real street markets, I'm willing to spend my money on whoever draws me in-- 

The place was jam packed at 5:00pm but each booth had their lines figured out so there was never any cutting or running into each other; I was able to peruse and leave or peruse and stay.

What I enjoyed most about this place was the fact that there were So Many Options- BBQ / Sushi /  Pastries / Crepes / French Fries / Beer & Wine / Donuts / Juices / Tacos /  Flowers / Cheese / Thai / Korean / Fruit & Veggie Market and even a GRILLED. CHEESE. AND. SOUP. STAND!!!!   *hugs*

Wonderful!
review.author: Nicola P.

review.description: One of my to go places for cheap and good eats. I love getting the noodle salad from Saigon sisters, it is so fresh and light! The fries from Frietkoten Belgian are the best. They are super crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. The crepes from Flip Crepe are one of my favorite dessert items. There are so many different flavors and made fresh to order!
review.author: Connie U.

review.description:
This is such a cute market. It kind of reminds me of a much neater Pike Place Market (in Seattle). It's a nice place to roam around when you're waiting for your METRA train.

I didn't get to explore that much but I did get some bubble tea from BI Tea, and I also got some apples from the market. The golden delicious apples were quite good and about the same price as Whole Foods. However, the apples here tasted much better to my delight.
review.author: Danielle C.

review.description:
Underwhelmed and does not live up to the name "French Market." 

The decor has a somewhat French flavor, but the vendors and cuisines in there are more international than French. It may have been in the past, but it seems like the French has migrated back or away from this venue. 

There is a crepe vendor in here which has a variety of crepe selections, but it is more of a US fusion of crepe than French. The taste and price is decent however. We had a Smokehouse Crepe for $8.35 (as in the name, I don't think Smokehouse is French!). Moreover, I bought a cup of coffee here and I think the French won't be happy.... 

I give it a 3 stars because of the decor, otherwise a 2 star. 

Low down: worth a visit once but don't come hungry.
review.author: Simon G.

review.description:
I love this French Market!

It is so cool.  It's underneath the Metra trains at Ogilvie station.  When you first walk in it looks like a small convenient store lined with drinks and snacks.  Once you walk further back it opens up and there are rows of food vendors / restaurants.....tons to pick from.

Lots of variety from sandwiches, rice bowls, vegetarian, sweets, juices......you name it.  

I have been to Los Angeles where they have their food market which I thought was the best I've ever been to.  Now, this Chicago French Market is my favorite and probably best I've ever been to.
review.author: Jason P.

review.description:
Hm.. how to start. I dont know why this place have great reviews? Or people who eat there did not have been to France or they eat whatever and give it five stars.. 
I have bookmarked this place and couldn't wait to go there. I am very disappointed with overall experience. 
First of all, we couldn't find parking. Which was let's say ok, it is place for people around area to grab and go lunches or quick eat inside. 
There are plenty of different shops inside but we decided to grab a lobster roll. I am kind of person who will give last penny for my hedonistic spirit. But 16$ lobster roll sandwich?! The problem is not about the money it is about the roll. It is not even a tasteless,it is like a snack. It is not worth it for a lunch. The roll is two slices of bread filled with mixed green salad, topped with lobster tail meat, and sprinkled with garlic butter. Like side you get pickles. Does it worth 16$? No. It was good?! It was not soo bad. 
Across the Lobster stand there was sort of praline chocolaterie. And I didn't trust them to pay 14$ for 4 (the smallest size box) praline. 
When we were walking trough the marketplace to the setting point we run into the some sort of bakery Vanilla bakery and it seemed that they have nice cakes. Outside was very hot so we decided to skip. Otherwise they will be ruined. 
I wanted fries so we grabbed reccomended one next to the sitting court and it was decent. Hand peeled and freshly fried. Just ok. 
I just didn't liked that place. We had two rolls, two Sodas, large fries and with parking we paid more than 50$. Was it worth it? No. 
Would I recommend it? No. Chicago offers a huge palette of food points you can try that you should not spend anytime here.
review.author: Kiki K.

review.description: This is the place to take a walk through if you're looking to try different food's. Lots of great smelling & delicious food stands offering everything from snacks/treats to full meals, even some vegan. The day we were there, there was also some live music to set the mood. Definitely worth a couple of hours!
review.author: Freddie L.

review.description:
i tell my friend manny
i want a loster roll
but where in in chitown
so he said go to  the market on  clinton
so i try it today i walk around  and fined da lobsta
was pretty good i order the 16 " roll  and a can of coke  $21 
i be back to try some thing else for sure
review.author: Cely R.

review.description:
This place is great, but there is so much potential to be even better. I like that there are many different options for food, from poke bowls to sushi to Italian street food to desserts to crepes to French to vegan to empanadas, and even raw food! But the two things that are lacking are (1) more options for wine and (2) better seating. Regarding #1, there is literally one bar that serves any alcohol, and the wine selection is just plain sad. And they will serve you your wine in a plastic cup if you don't drink it at their counter. How classy is that? And, by the way, how can you call yourself a "French" market and have barely any wine options? Regarding #2, there are a handful of tables on the east side of the building, but it reminds me of a cafeteria. The ambience could certainly be better. 

If I had to add another issue, It would also be great to have more options for ice cream or gelato. If you visit their website, they claim to have one vendor that serves gelato, but when I visited last time, they were not offering it.

Anyway, the food is certainly good, and there is so much variety in the different cuisine that is offered. But I'm so thirsty for a good glass of wine. Please quench my thirst.
review.author: Nerissa P.

review.description:
This lovely market is hiding on the other side of the Ogilvie Transportation Center. I had no idea it was there until I finally made my pilgrimage to Vanille and discovered I could have been spending my time waiting for the train in a much better way. 

Usually I beeline for the fancy cakes, but we've taken a stroll through and had a good time exploring the different stands. There were definitely some other spots that caught my eye, and one of these times we'll have to make a proper go of eating our way through or grabbing some goodies for our trip home. 

The setting itself is pretty drab and calling the entrance understated is an understatement, so I don't know if I'd go out of my way to visit, but since we usually get to town via the OTC it's become part of our routine.
review.author: Stacey L.

review.description:
When the French Market first opened when we lived in the loop it was only ok. At the time only a few vendors and everything was a tad pricey for what you get. So on our recent trip back to Chicago I was excited to see some of the oldies but goodies still there and quite a few vendors I wish I had the time and stomach space to try. 

With so many food options near the major attractions in downtown, the French market still mainly attract the folks working in the area or those riding the metro to/from the burbs. Overall not a must stop for a tourist but worth a visit if you happen to be in the area and want to grab a quick bite to eat and especially if you're w a larger group and can't decide on what to eat.
review.author: Ming T.

review.description:
Been wanting to go here for a while and finally made it.. Unfortunately I made it close to closing time so some of the stands were closed, anyhow this place was awesome filled with lots of unique food and goodies, indoor seating, super clean, lots of to choose from, got big box of the most delicious macaroons I've ever had. 

I will definitely come back. Staff if super friendly.
review.author: Tiffany B.

review.description: I'm a fan. This market is full of vendors with a wide variety of options, including raw, vegan, kosher, Asian, French (obviously), Cajun, Latin, etc. I imagine that booths here are expensive so there are very few cheap options here, in my opinion, but the food overall has never disappointed me. I like that I can have something different every day of the week.
review.author: E W.

review.description: Was going to au chevali for burger and saw this on the way, didn't try anything but seems promising for those catching the train or looking for a quick lunch
review.author: Susan L.

review.description:
Wow! I mean wow!

I have always heard of this "secret market"..& finally had the chance to check it out! So glad that I was able to make my way down there! It is located right under the Ogilvie Train station! It smelled wonderful! After taking it all in..taking tons of Snapchats, and pictures I finally got to the vendors! 

Food - I am always in search of a good lobster roll..and Da Lobsta was amazing! I had the Chicago Style Roll which was with Sriracha Mayo & Topped with spicy giardiniera and warm garlic butter! My friend got the Traditional Style which was with tarragon mayo & topped with warm garlic buttery and celery salt. Both were delish! Both were paired with a light coleslaw. Apparently it was National Lobster Day..so I deff took advantage of that! If you like seafood..please check out this vendor!

I also had coffee from Polpetti! It had a Cubano twist..dark roast..just sweet enough! It was a great drink to have after that delish lobsta roll! 

I would just make a trip back to The French Market for the ambiance and the culture of the market!
review.author: Maria Q.

review.description: I didn't get to visit every stall I wanted to because time did not permit, but I love the concept! There is truly something for everyone here. From pastries to veggies, from Belgian frites to raw vegan to Korean bbq to tacos, from a butcher to a chocolatier. The location attached to Ogilvie makes it convenient for Metra commuters and West Loop workers. It isn't, necessarily conveniently located for me, but I plan to trek over here and explore a bit more soon.
review.author: Loretta P.

review.description:
I love this market & decided to finally tell you. 
I love the Parisian vibe, and the Parisian music and the food ...It makes me happy.... I worked on Clinton today;))and as I was leaving for the day I said ...Today Ill get everything Ive been wanted to try: I bought a Pastoral Salumi Picante sandwich(wow wow fantastic sandwich), 3 Lito's empanadas (mmm they were only ok-sorry Lito's) & some white bean & mushroom soup with bread from the french place(delicious). Ill be back ...Cant wait! No pics...I gobbled most of it up... oops
review.author: Eman S.

review.description:
An undiscovered gem in the heart of downtown Chicago. Dozens of unique food vendors packed into a bustling market setting under the train tracks. Vendors run the gamut from raw food/vegan to tiny dessert doughnuts to banh mi to lobster rolls. It's all anchored by the terrific City Fresh Market which serves up great deli fare and a great little market with packaged and fresh grocery items.

There is plenty of seating but it's tough to find a spot at peak lunch hours and there is frequent live music as well. Overall it's a great place to visit and if you work downtown it gives tons of daily lunch options.
review.author: Michael R.

review.description: The Chicago French Market is right across the street from my office and I LOVE coming here. They have such a huge variety to choose from. From burgers, juices, desserts, sandwiches, ice cream, soup, crepes, donuts....They got you covered. It gets pretty packed during lunch time, but they have a pretty decent size seating area.
review.author: Tavi J.

review.description:
This is a delightful marketplace chock full of goodness located in the Ogilvie Transportation Center-the other train station downtown.

Assuming you try to drive here there is convenient (sort of) covered, ground-level parking available in the metra market parking lot located just north of Randolph, along with street parking but look-this is a train station -so there will be dozens of buses and trains coming here everyday, and Chicago traffic is beyond fierce. You are best served by getting here any other way that does not involve driving a car. The El and the other train depot-union station-are both within easy walking distance. If you for some bizarre reason (such as being a masochist) do end up in that parking garage and wind up spending more then 20 bucks (easy to do) at the market, the first hour is free. Otherwise the parking is a Chicago bargain at a mere six dollars every 30 minutes. Rounded up. thus 31 minutes will be twelve dollars.

Both the street facing entrance or the totally innocuous train platform entrances give no indication of the wonders contained within. Inside there is a dining area with some more or less comfortable chairs next to a decent full size mural designed to make you think you are not underneath one of the largest train stations in america, an effect somewhat ruined by the the wall shaking effect every 45 minutes when a train arrives and/or departs. There is also a limited amount of outside seating in the summer, and some cozy little two spots scattered around here and there. 

Other then the seating the real gem here is the thirty to forty shops selling various foods from around the world. There is a butcher, a seafood shop that will steam anything, mexican street food, polish kielbasa, belgian frites, burgers, raw foods, several sweet shops, bánh mì, sushi, wraps, tri tip, green grocers, kosher, bakeries, pickles (both american and Indian), halal, pastrami,gnocchi, gelato, poke,beef bourguignon,artisan cheeses, coffee,  burgers and well a true american smorgasbord in all it's diverse grandeur. In other words a pocket food paradise cleverly hidden in a train depot. From time to time there will be live music. Pricing ranges from four bucks for soup or some other small item to several hundred dollars for a magnum of champagne and some caviar. Generally speaking lunch will be in the 15 dollar ish range. Bring some extra in order to take some stuff home for later though. 

Overall it's an absolutely amazing place for anyone that likes food.
review.author: Steven W.

review.description: This place is a hidden gem that you should you should consider for casual brunch or lunch. The market has multiple food vendors with verity themed food. If you're in mood for Japanese food there is vendor for you. We decided check out seafood. I ordered lobster roll which came steamed or chilled and topped with an amazing sauce and bacon. It was crispy soft and full of amazing aromas. There is also a little bar where we actually ate our food. It has wine and beer which went well with the food. There are also multiple chocolate, dessert and fruit vendors you can choose from. I would definitely come back here in future when I return to Chicago.
review.author: Parisa M.

review.description: Love coming here! Any place you eat will be delicious! Still making the rounds- the goal is to hit every single place. Great lunch options, but be warned, it's very busy during lunch rush! Do not expect to find a seat. They have a limited seating area and you sometimes have to wait until someone leaves their table.  Only one (maybe two?) places serve beer or wine.
review.author: Tara S.

review.description:
Imagine a grocery store except the aisles are lined with little restaurant booths rather than shelves. Super cool place, you can kill a solid hour just looking at all the food. There's poke, lobster, baked potatoes, wine/cheese, sandwiches, boba, cupcakes, it's all here. Also the place is air conditioned, a key step in heatstroke prevention. It did not go unnoticed!

As far as the food goes I have only had the pleasure of trying the wine and cheese place, it's called Pastoral and there's another location on Lake street, too. I don't know jack shit about cheese so I relied heavily on the staff there to help me choose the chief cheese for the occasion (a concert in Millenium park). They let you try a lot of cheeses and they actually know and care a ton about the cheese. I discovered that I am a fan of nutty Spanish cheeses that have medium-hard consistency and are made from sheep, goat, and cows milk. What will I do with this information? The possibilities are simply endless. I forgot what the cheese was called also, but that's on me. But it was a fabulous cheese indeed.

Wow this turned into more of a review for pastoral than for French market. Anyway, French market is dope, and under the assumption that the booths are similar in quality, you're going to have an informative and scrum-diddly-umptious time there.
review.author: Nishaad N.

review.description:
I'm in love! I can't believe I haven't stopped in the Chicago French Market before. I've passed by it a million times, but I'm always in a hurry. Thankfully a co-worker of mine suggested a group of us meet there for lunch...I am so glad he did. 

Sure, it was busy at lunchtime, but that was to be expected. In my opinion, the wait made it possible for me to scout out many of the other businesses (from the waiting line), that occupy the market. My colleagues went for the Aloha Poke, but Lillie's BBQ smelled too good for me to pass up. I ordered a pulled pork sandwich with coleslaw in the bun, and what I love about Lillie's is the fact you can choose your type of BBQ sauce on the side. I ordered up sweet & mild sauce. It was so good I wanted to drink it straight out of the container. Let's just say in the end, I used up every last drop. 

Other vendors I noticed...Beaver Donuts & Coffee, grilled cheese sandwiches, a deli stop for bulk salads and homemade turkey sammies, a crepe station, and killer good looking cupcakes. But, the one place I couldn't keep my eyes off of is the Kosher deli. I'm super curious to find out how authentic it is. Hmmm...seems like another review to come?

There is indoor seating, and some tables come with umbrellas...super cute. We were able to snag a small stand up table for the four of us. 

My first French Market experience was simply perfect all the way around. Cheers!
review.author: Angela S.

review.description: Very Cool Market with about 20 of different food stalls. We tried some tacos, Nutella crepes and some Korean noodles that were All very good! Planing to come again and try other stuff!
review.author: Glenn D.

review.description:
For those of you familiar with Quincy Market/Faneuil Hall in Boston: this is VERY similar but much, much smaller. If you can't decide what type of food you're in the mood for, this is the place to go. It's a little off the beaten path for a tourist but seems to be a hot spot for commuters, which (in my opinion) makes it even better. You want to go where the locals go. 

There were a few empty spots but otherwise was bustling and the smells caused my stomach to grumble in response. The bread right out of the oven, fresh fruits, and the sweets on every corner... oh, it was a fantastic experience. It's a good thing I can't visit here every day.
review.author: Kelly C.

review.description: This one star is for the guest singers that they have every now and. First of all their sound system is really bad. It's painful to hear the music & makes the singer sounds horrible. Makes you just want to leave the place. Today's singer does'nt fit for the environment either. She needs to be at a bookshop or coffee shop.
review.author: Tess L.

review.description:
I don't live in Chicago, so I assume it's over my head why this is called the "French" Market. Considering it isn't all French. Can anybody help me out here? I mean, Eataly, for example, is at least mostly Italian. It's not even like the French Market is all European because there's a Mexican restaurant and a Vietnamese restaurant and Da Lobsta. Maybe I'm not culturally savvy enough to get it. I'll keep trying.

In the meantime, I'll continue with my unenlightened review. I swung in for lunch midweek, and ho boy, that was a mistake. To say it was bustling and cramped was an understatement. Between that and the market-style atmosphere, I felt like I was in France. Maybe I just solved my query. Except I've never been to France so I don't actually know if it's like France. Plus, America is also bustling and cramped. I've just decided it should be called the "Chicago Market", regardless of why it has "French" in the name.

The only thing found in abundance here are food options. Everything else--including available seating, personal space, and clearly marked exits--are absent. Of course, my stupid self went with choices that weren't French. I tried Da Lobsta, which consisted of weak lobster and puny pasta noodles. Sad! Then I grabbed an horchata from the Mexican restaurant because this drink is like, impossible to find anywhere for some reason.

Unless I literally worked next to this place, I don't think I'd ever come here. I like Chicago and the French and markets, but apparently the three combined don't work well.
review.author: Josh L.

review.description:
You don't have to ride the Metra to be a fan of this hidden treasure in the West Loop. I live about four blocks north of here, and it's my one-stop destination for a great take-out meal, and especially for putting together a spread to entertain friends.  

I've purchased things from about half of the 30 or so vendors and have my favorites. Pastoral Artisan Cheese has an outstanding selection, and the counter people are helpful at selecting complementary cheeses for a tray. It's also a good place to pick up a loaf of fresh bread and bottle of wine, too. Furmare meats is nearby, and they deserve their reputation as The Sandwich King. Can't beat their locally cured pastrami on rye with hot mustard... several hearty soups, too.  

There are many choices for sweets, but Delightful Pasteries is above the rest. Nothing compares to their specialty cakes for parties, and the absolute best are Death by Chocolate and Tira Mi Su. (I say, why waste your calories an anything less than pure butter and chocolate!)  

If you crave macaroons, you'll find them at several of the stalls. There's a stall just for lobster, and their rolls are pretty good (not great)  Saigon Sisters Vietnamese food is available for take-out. If you want to sit down and enjoy your meal, there are several options for that, too.

My only suggestion is to be prepared to wait in line during lunch. They don't have enough people behind the counters to serve the crowds. Note that French Market is closed on Sundays.  

Several Yelpers have complained about high prices, but I don't agree. The prices for fresh produce, meat, fish and cheese are comparable to Mariano's and Whole Foods. Bakery goods are conpetitive, too.
review.author: Marcia S.

review.description:
I've been riding the Metra for months and just now visited the market underneath the station.  Silly me.  

This place surprised the hell out of me.  It immediately reminded me of a fancier version of an Asian night market.  Tight quarters, lots of food stalls and potential customers getting in your way constantly and a few merchants selling random things like scarves and knick knacks.  Several of the food stalls are bit expensive for a quick lunch but they all sound great when you're hungry.  Lobster rolls, hot dogs, chicken tikka masala, crepes, pho, fresh donuts and a few different bakeries and chocolate shops.  There's even a little mini grocery store for fresh fruit and a meat market if you want to gnaw on a raw t-bone steak on the train ride back. I should have been down here sooner.
review.author: Lily F.

review.description: Chicago French Market...j'adore. Contrary to what the name leads you to believe, the majority of the things you will find in here are not French. There's actually a City Fresh Market where you can buy meats, fruits, vegetables, etc. But most come here to EAT. Whatever you're in the mood for, Chicago French Market probably has you covered. Lobster rolls, poke bowls, bubble tea, juiceries, etc. There are so many options that you could eat lunch here everyday for 3 weeks and eat something different everyday...not even exaggerating. There's more places to eat than there are seats, however, so good luck trying to find a spot during prime lunch hour!
review.author: Pauline P.

review.description: I went during lunch time during a weekday which was not a smart idea so i recommend going at a different time if you're a tourist as well. The food we ordered at different spots was pricey but was worth it in the end with the incredible flavors. I recommend coming here 100%.
review.author: Ashley C.

review.description: Very cute, fun place! Wish it was around when I lived in Chicago a while back. I tried Da Lobsta- fresh lobster imported from the east coast! It was delicious. Loved the clam chowder too. The guys working there were super nice and friendly! The seating area in the market is adorable too. The furniture feels like a European cafe, and they had a live musician setting up while we were leaving.
review.author: Paige S.

review.description: This is a "Chicago Market," but it's not a "Chicago *French* Market." Maybe 1/6 or 1/8 of the vendors could be -- generously -- labeled as French. The rest are Italian, Mexican, some generic bakeries, a gross-looking NY-style pizza place, a convenience store, etc. If this was like a French version of Eataly, it would be fair to call it a "French market." I went to the one French-ish cheese/butter stall to inquire about my favorite French food product -- salty butter with sea salt crystals -- and was handed an $11 product from Vermont. Ummm, no thanks -- for something that costs €2 (or less) in France. What a disappointment. If you're in the area, it's worth visiting for lunch, but definitely don't make a special trip expecting a taste of France.
review.author: Anthony L.

review.description:
We came here at 5:30pm on a weekday and almost everything was closed. Pretty annoying since we walked quite a distance to get there and it says that the market closes at 7:30pm.

The name is really misleading. Most of all the stores have nothing to do with French cuisine and there was a Chinese food stall that looked unappetizing. 

Overall it was quite disappointing. If I was to visit chicago again I wouldn't come back here.
review.author: Jimmy D.

review.description:
This is such a hidden gem. I've been wanting to come here for ages, and I don't know why I waited so long. 

My girlfriend, sister, and I came here before going to a play to get some lunch, and it was all of our first time there. 

Inside this marketplace is a grocery store-esque market, a florist, a chocolatier, a cheese shop, and a myriad of food and drink vendors. There's seriously something here for everyone. There's a few delis, a crepe place and macarons for those who want to keep it French, a place for beer and fries, vegan places, donuts, bubble tea. You name it, and you can find it here. Everything's pretty well organized, and there's a good sized seating area so you can relax and enjoy your culinary finds. I strongly recommend Fumare Meats and Beaver Donuts, for their Montreal Pastrami and milkshakes, respectively. 

The only downside there is to this place, is that there's not much of an actual market. Think more gourmet food court and less grocery shopping. 

I'll certainly make a point to come back here again.
review.author: Jill O.

review.description: There a little bit for everyone here.  I love to come here when I stop in Chicago I come from the suburbs and I like to see the many stores this market has to offer.   The r stairs t are so amazing.   I wish we had more markets to go to.   Come and experience the great variety of foods.
review.author: Gina V.

review.description: I came here for breakfast and got the lox crepe at Flip Crepes and Cafe Au Lait with almond milk at Polpetti. The lox crepe is burrito style and it really was fantastic. The coffee was also very delicious. We also got six macaroons to go from Vanille patissiere. We ordered a range, but the Lavender was outstanding. This place is fun since they are a lot of options. I just think it is a little strange how there are other foods besides French? Otherwise, I recommend!
review.author: Cameron C.

review.description: Sorry but I think this place is a dump.  There is no bathroom.  No place to wash your hands before you touch your food.  When I asked a vendor for the restroom, they referred me to a nearby bus or train station!?  I just think that's subpar.
review.author: Victoria V.

review.description: I love visiting the French Market, it has great dessert options and meals. I like to go around happy hour time because it's not so busy and you can find a table to sit down and eat. During the lunch time it is massively packed and it's hard to get in line find food wait for it and then sit to eat. Everything there is good, however not super cheap. But you can find a deal and there like at Frietkoten Belgian Fries & Beer $9.50 for a juicy delicious grilled burger with fries so delicious!
review.author: Jaci Y.

review.description:
I liked the market okay, but it was not what I was expecting. This is not the French version of Eataly, which is I guess what my visitor mind had conjured up. 

Compared to Eataly, French Market sticks much less strongly to the French theme than Eataly does to its Italian theme. French Market is also smaller. 

To me French Market might be a place for every day shopping. I saw lots of just traditional market type stands such as I might find in any farmer's market.
review.author: Ben S.

review.description:
First visit; inside a train station,  all the vendors are sort of crammed in the middle of a small space. Everything smelled so amazing! And  hardly any of the vendors were, French as I was expecting. 

Flip Crepe was a good value for such a large size crepe; Mexican restaurant huevos ranchos came with rice and beans for only $7, and mini donuts for $2! 

Wasn't quite what I expected but would go here again to try out other shops.
review.author: Sarah E.

review.description: So many good food options here from crepes to vegetarian you'll find a little bit of everything. 1 hour free parking with ticket validation (purchase of $20 or more). Recommended!
review.author: William Q.

review.description: I love this place ! I work right down the street and it literally has EVERYTHING from sushi to baked potatoes to ice cream to salad. It can handle any palette and even has a mini grocery store! I go here for lunch from time to time. Though it is crowded and seating is very limited, it is nice if you are bringing it back to the office (seating is why I gave this 4 stars). There are also some nice fancy chocolates and macaroons here for a sweet treat :)
review.author: Kayla J.

review.description:
I have to admit, when I first came here, not that long after opening, I wasn't impressed. In fact, I was kind of disappointed. It seemed more like a place to buy candy and popcorn more than anything, especially a french market.

I gave it a second chance out of necessity. I was commuting to my parent's house frequently, many times unexpectedly, and this was my chance to grab food before boarding a train. I noticed that the caliber of vendors had improved and I could not only get some healthy options, like fresh fruit, but some damn good food too. Pastoral is my go to vendor there, but there are some other great choices as well like Aloha Poke, Saigon Sisters and Black Dog Gelato.

It still doesn't transport me to the bank of the Seine or France at all, but a trip to Ogilve means I'll be going out of my way to stop into the market for something tasty. Color me impressed at the turnaround from its early days.
review.author: Mary T.

review.description:
Nice market with lots of food options -- though as other Yelpers have pointed out, not a whole lot of French cuisine here. There were, however, plenty of stands with desserts and baked goods, a stand which sold meatloaf cupcakes, Saigon Sisters with Vietnamese food, a stand that specialized in meatball subs, a donut stand, a lobster stand, a bubble tea stand, and more. So, you will definitely find something you like here! I went around lunchtime on a Friday and it certainly was busy, but not packed. There were lots of vendors handing out samples around that time, and you could probably get reasonably full just eating those. 

My boyfriend got some bubble tea from Bello Tea, which we were disappointed in. We ordered coconut taro, and it was made with a powder mix that wasn't mixed very well (we saw them shake the drink in a water bottle a few times and that was it), so it was gritty and also way too sweet. Our cup was also filled 80% ice so I feel like we got a really bad deal given the priciness of the drink. 

We also had some fries from Frietkoten, which were awesome. Super crispy, not greasy (even though they were double-fried) with lots of sauce options to choose from.
review.author: Tiffany W.

review.description: Really cool place to go. There's a lot variety to choose from which is great if you're looking get a taste of different foods. I got da lobsta, some macaroons, and a coffee but I wish I had more time to try out more things. If you're looking for a unique food adventure check out this place.
review.author: Brian F.

review.description:
So small! I'm not sure why but I had envisioned Chicago's French Market to be similar to Philadelphia's Reading Terminal Market. 

Really just a handful of vendors and a small area to sit and eat, Chicago's French Market's most recent addition of Aloha Poke Co is what really draws the crowds. It was 10:30AM on a Thursday and Aloha already had a long line, whereas all the other vendors were empty.

There are cute donut shops, bakeries, bbq, asian, and seafood options too.

There's a transportation center right there so people getting on the commuter rail have plenty of options to choose from and clean bathrooms too.

As a tourist pit stop, I'd take a pass, but it was in between visiting the Big Monster Door and the conservatory.
review.author: Nancy H.

review.description: French Market is a great go to when trying to satisfy different people's tastes.  They have many food stalls to pick from. I recommend to take a walk around so you can see all the different options and then make your choice.  Everybody can pick their own thing and then meet in the back where they have communal seating and enjoy some great conversation and food.  A great laid back environment with decent prices for quality food.  Don't miss this place!
review.author: Amber L.

review.description: This place is simply amazing! There are so many vendors selling so many different things! Not all of it is french, despite its name. It is, however, extremely European. Walking in the door made me forget the outside world. I planned on spending 20ish minutes, but instead I walked out a full 90 minutes later. Oops!
review.author: Michele M.

review.description: Nice selection of many different places to eat! Just hard to know which one to pick. We had Belgium burger and fries plus crepe sandwiches. Not bad but might pick different food next time. The cheese guy seemed very friendly and I think I'd go there next time.
review.author: Heather A.

review.description:
This place is soooo cool. Most cities like Baltimore, Boston, Seattle, etc have some place like this.  It's under the Metra train so sometimes you csn hear it rumble overhead which just adds to the coolness factor. 

We got food from Aloha. My daughter has been trying to get me here but lost me when she called it "deconstructed sushi". I prefer my food "constructed" in its usual artificial way. Anyway, it was delicious. I got the Alpha with Salmon and she had the crunchy with Salmon. The flavor and sauce works together wonderfully. The best part is that you can do add on's for no extra cost. 

We went after lunch hour but apparently the line can be incredibly long for this particular restaurant. 

There are several other places to eat. Next to Aloha was Lillies Que which we frequent over on North avenue quite often.

They have a fresh market as well as places that serve beer. Can't wait to try them all.
review.author: Melissa C.

review.description: The French market was an oasis away from a festival I was attempting to attend at grant park. Quiet and cool it had a variety of different places to suit your food/drink needs! We hit the juice bar and then made our way to aloha poke for a refreshing lunch and took home some macarons for later. I also had interest in the Vietnamese and Belgian burger places as well but we were already full.  This was like a smaller, better version of the Indianapolis city market and I am so thankful we found it after getting scorched in the park on a humid July day!
review.author: Katie S.

review.description:
A few steps away from the Clinton stop on the green line, French Market is a great place to go if you want to hit up many of Chicago's great food places all in one go!

They have lots of seating available and often have live music playing too! If you go during happy hour (4-6pm), many places have discounts like 4 for $40 lobster rolls at Da Lobsta which is a steal! They also have places where you can buy groceries and fresh fish although the prices are steep (maybe you should just go to Mariano's for groceries?)

Careful though, this place can get crowded since there are a lot of office buildings around. I recommend going during dinner if you have time. Unfortunately it closes at 7:30pm most days, most vendors close up shop before then so if you wanna grab dinner come right after work and take something to go.

I've tried most of the places here, and they're all pretty solid. Not gonna lie I think the best part are the dessert places (eg Black dog gelato, Beavers donuts, Vanille Patisserie).
review.author: Sunny K.

review.description:
Very cool place! It's pretty hidden, but in a prime location! 

So many good restaurants inside. I've only tried a couple so far, but I will definitely be coming back to try the rest! 

Markets are a great way to try a lot of different things at once. Chicago needs more ;)
review.author: Dominique M.

review.description:
Incredible market with a variety of foods, though very crowded during lunch rush!
The French Market is situated in the heart of corporate downtown Chicago and seems to be a popular place for people on their lunch rush to flock to when needing a break. 

It's essentially a market with groceries, but when you walk in and around, you'll see several food booths. There is so much variety! Everything from Banh Mi, to macarons, to sandwiches, to vegan/raw foods, to Indian food, etc. It does get a bit crazy during lunch, but the lines move quick.
review.author: Aparna B.

review.description: Always expensive, always crowded, and maintains the feel of a more seating-friendly Eataly. I'd recommend eating outside, somewhere in Union Station, rather than in the actual cafeteria.
review.author: Thomas T.

review.description: Had few hours to spare until my next Amtrak.  I searched ahead of time for anything that peaks my interest.  French Market. Ok.  So I looked through photos on Yelp here to see if there was anything I wanna try.  Thank u yelpers for the great photos!  Two things caught my eyes.  1 the traditional lobster roll it was delicious (1st timer).  2 the pastrami.  They ran out since 1pm.( It's now 6:45pm).  Bummer.
review.author: Ahmay V.

review.description: OMG I love this place! Why have I never been here before this????? Came with a group of 4 girls, so we each went to a different booth to order something different. It's great to order a variety of dishes to share, and it was so fun sitting at the cute little umbrella tables and enjoying each specialty. It ranges from actual French food, to Asian, to dessert, to coffee and tea. Lots of things to try, and not enough time or stomach room to try it all. But I'll definitely be coming back for more!
review.author: Tina L.

review.description:
This is the awesomeist place to find food in Chicago! Anything you want is here so those that struggle with their food decisions will find themselves in a culinary paradise where decisions make themselves.
   
Located directly beneath the train tracks of Ogilvie between Canal, Randolph, Clinton and Washington Streets in the city's transforming West Loop/ Fulton River District, the French Market (formerly the MetraMarket) is home to 30+ unique restaurants and boutique eateries including several bars and a supermarket. There's even a large dining area that features high quality live music (free) every evening.

I have tried most of these eateries but being a raw vegan I am very partial to the amazing Raw and Juice Loop. Lavazza was incredible but they pulled out and were replaced by a very competent equal. 

Exiting the trains and going down the back stairs will empty you out into the corridor entrance to this market. I do this five days a week and it's a dream. 

Try it.
review.author: Dan H.

review.description:
I think Milwaukee Public Market in the Third Ward is superior to the Chicago French Market. I think the North Market in the Short North neighborhood in Columbus is superior to Chicago French Market. 

Da Lobsta had no lobster sandwiches and it was lunchtime. The customer service was withdrawn and unhelpful. Beaver Donuts was not impressive, and at noon on a Saturday a lot of stuff wasn't even open. The highlight of the trip was the Belgian fries with garlic mayo and curried ketchup.
review.author: Sarah P.

review.description:
Why the hell haven't I been here? GO THERE!

So many options to please so many different people. I could have spent over an hour looking around this place before deciding where to eat. They had desserts, coffee, juices, Korean, Vietnamese, American, French, Hawaiian, Japanese... so much to choose from. I could come back her numerous times and not get bored.
review.author: Nikki M.

review.description: Very clean and more spacious version of Quincy Market. There are tens of vendor stalls selling various food items. I didn't find exactly what I wanted but I bet there are lots of people who drop in for lunch from various places downtown. Raw Chicago is also located in here, btw!
review.author: Julianne S.

review.description: It's sooooo bad! Our family went there on Saturday. It says that parking is free for the first hour if we purchase above $20, so we had lunch there. However, when we tried to validate our parking, it still charged us for $17, because there is no assistant on Saturday. We paid for their fault
review.author: Wendy Y.

review.description: Love the French market especially da Lobsta Da best will be back soon...Da best hotsauce collection I've ever seen....Also try the original clam chowda & Lobsta bisque
review.author: Michael S.

review.description:
We stopped into the Chicago French Market for lunch and have had mixed experiences.

Décor: It's located in the "back end" of Ogilvie Train Station and is a cool spot that has lots of different stalls (vendors) and a really nice assortment of little markets and places to grab a snack or bite to eat. There can be live music, at times, and there are a bunch of tables you can sit down to eat at. The lighting is nice and just the whole set up is really inviting and friendly.
Bathroom: yes, in the train station part just outside the entrance

Staff: Everyone is friendly and the maintenance staff keeps everything nice and clean.

Food: Like I said, there is a large assortment of options here and we have tried several. You would wise to take a lap and evaluate your options but, for the most part, you cannot go wrong. There of course can be a miss here or there but give something a try, whatever you have a taste for, and you will probably enjoy it.

Value: Price depends on the vendor, some can be spot-on and others can be a be pricey.

We are BIG fans of this spot, for a meal or a snack, and will be coming back many times in the future.
review.author: Mark B.

review.description:
This place is awesome!! Located conveniently inside Ogilvie Station it's a hidden gem! Once you go in, you see vendors but once you turn the corner you see all the amazing vendors this place has to offer! 
They have everything from fresh produce, to a deli, to sushi, to lobster, to meatballs, to dessert galore with macaroons and gelato. I went during lunch and the lines moved surprisingly fast. Can't wait to go back!
review.author: Alexis M.

review.description: I've been to the French Market several times for lunch and felt like it was time to write a review!  There is such a great variety of stations you can always find something to satisfy whatever you're craving.  It's also just fun to walk around and look at the various stations and unique treats.  Some of the dessert stations are like looking at an art gallery- it's literally food art!  If you're ever in the area, it's definitely worth a quick walk through to check out the unique spots inside!
review.author: Rachel S.

review.description:
Just great. I love this place! yeah, I don't know how authentically "French" It is, but who cares. It's fantastic. Many stalls to peruse, lots of bakeries, and several food stalls have pretty cute tables/bars/areas to eat as well.

I popped in one day 'cos I was weirdly craving Macarons. I know, weird, right? But, I had to have them. There are several outlets for Macarons here, and I purchased a few of the spendy little devils. They are delicious. Ended up buying some from the stall that is right at the entrance, on your left side. Tremendous selection, and nicely packaged.

Then, I was off for a lobster roll! Da Lobsta satisfied that craving. Great roll, generous blob of delicious lobster meat, and a super friendly, nice counter guy. They have everything lobster here. Everything.

It makes riding the Metra, if that's your thing, just a little cooler - great place to stop in for dinner fixings - hello fishmonger! - or just snacks or drinks for commute home. I'm sure coming back here, they have everything.
review.author: Erika G.

review.description:
I love the concept of the French Market! I'm a big fan of markets with different options for dining. The French Market is no different. There are all sorts of dining options - crepes, gelato, Indian, jerky, vegan and raw, poke, sandwiches, and a small grocery market for fresh produce.

Compared to other similar types of markets I've been to in other cities I was a bit disappointed though. The quality of the food stands is definitely variable. Some are much . When I was visiting there were quite a bit of empty stalls. Not super consistent on cleanliness. I get that each of the stands is independently run, but having some standards around look and feel could benefit everyone in there.

There's a nice common seating area, which mimics the outdoor patio of a low end restaurant. There is certainly opportunity here to make it a bit more upscale without losing the casual feel of the market.

I liked the Poke stop! Unfortunately they were out of salmon when I was there, so I had to settle for tuna, which was fine, but only a bit disappointing.

The French Market is conveniently located at the transit center, providing a great place to hang out and grab food while waiting for your bus.
review.author: Mary L.

review.description: I had a great time walking around all the stalls and found some really yummy things to eat! It wasn't nearly as big as I thought it was going to be, like only 4 aisles, but there was no shortage of delicious food and treats. The cheese-mongers did a great job of answering my questions and were super patient with my ignorance! I came home with a big box of yummy cheeses, salami, prosciutto, delicious artisan mustard, and a demi-baguette. Also, couldn't resist some fancy waffles and macaroons. There were a surprising amount of plant-based and healthy options too!
review.author: Becky W.

review.description:
I went there when it first opened and it was still spotty and hadn't found its groove yet, but this time was different.  Went for lunch on a Saturday and it was wonderful.  The vendors have filled out nicely, offering a wide range of delicious choices.  From artisan cheese shops to crepes, Vietnamese, Indian, lobster, French, Ribs, Italian coffee stands, artisan cakes & cookies, raw and even a Girl and the Goat station.

I had the chili from The Girl and the Goat station which was hot and very tasty.  I also had a fabulous freshly prepared lentil soup from the Le Cafe du Marche. 

The back seating area is designed to feel like you are sitting under the Eiffel Tower and a terrific jazz guitarist complimented the scene nicely. 

Food is quick and prices are reasonable considering the ambiance. Free parking if you spend $20 and relatively easy street parking make it a nice alternative for a weekend brunch joint.
review.author: Michael B.

review.description: Only 10 min walk from my office. Translation: I'll be @ French market at least once a week. What an awesome concept - food, drinks, desserts. It's such a perfect assortment that you're bound to find something you're craving. Gotta love aloha poke and Vanille. And not to mention, the free phone charging station! All with a charming French-themed backdrop.
review.author: Sara T.

review.description: Great for quick loud lunch spot or a place to grab something to go, you will however have to elbow through the crowd.  I love the concept but hate the seating and the fact then when you do find a seat the tables dirty and no one in site with disinfecting spray and towel.  Still give it 3 stars because Aloha Poke.
review.author: M G.

review.description: Love this market! Such a hidden gem in west loop. I lived about 4 blocks away for almost a month and had no idea it existed (CTA user not Metra user). I've been slowly working my way through the different restaurants and have been loving it. Don't forget to finish any meal with some ice cream or crepe
review.author: Monica K.

review.description:
You have to really want to find this place because the signage is for shit. Even knowing where it is supposed to be (and having been once before! Albeit years ago...) it's a bit like trying to find Platform 9 & 3/4 or something.

It is worth it for all the fun food options, though! An international delight, from croque monsieurs to Belgian frites to bahn Mi sandwiches to macarons, and much more. Look around because sometimes you can find the same thing (ex: drink) for drastically different prices.

If you have the time for an explore its worth looking for. If you are easily frustrated you might want to pass...
review.author: Shannon M.

review.description:
Wasn't planning to come here originally... I was at Au Cheval and they quoted me a 1.5 hr wait, and so popped by since it was within a 10 minute walk. Boy am I glad I did! Stand after stand of delicious goodness!

I had no idea that Black Dog Gelato had a stand here. Love the bubble tea stand as well --  super easy to order. I requested my bubble tea be made less sweet than normal, and they did a great job with it! My friend's lavender tea was AMAZING -- might have to give it a try next time I'm here. 

This would be a really great spot to stop by for lunch or just for random munchies during the day. You can really get a taste of everything!
review.author: Linda L.

review.description: I definitely need to come back when I have more time to fully experience this place.  So many food stalls and they all looked and smelled wonderful.  We were able to try a few and we're quite pleased. The bakery,  the pastrami,  the fries,  oooo those fries!  Absolutely worth a stop to enjoy some delicious treats.
review.author: Shannon O.

review.description: I only gave this 2 stars because all of the eateries are not French. In fact, most were not. I thought this was pretty deceptive. It would be more accurate to just call it a food court. The food that we did eat was good, but I wouldn't have wasted my time walking here as an out of town visitor if I had known it wasn't all French.
review.author: Foodie Y.
