review.description: Yum!! So tasty. We had the lobster rolls. With so many different options, I would come back every day for lunch and try something new! This is kind of a hidden gem. Without having the tip of a friend to visit this place, I would've buzzed right past thinking it was just another metro station.
review.author: Katie M.

review.description:
"I feel like I'm in France..." 

I literally spoke these words (dreamily)  to my friend who brought me here for lunch.  It also reminded me of the Mercado San Miguel, an indoor market in Madrid... this is place is so refreshing and outshines the countless food chains around the Loop. 

What a wonderful establishment filled with cheeses, olives, fresh produce, delectable sandwiches!  I loved the bustle of people who will take time out of their day to grab some quality food.

There were so many options, Indian, French, Thai, and also a branch of the Girl & the Goat.  While I've only tried two sandwiches from Pastoral so far- both priced at $7.52 ("Cali Chevre" and "Sinfully Healthy" which includes a great mango chutney)- I would come here again to try other sandwiches, like the "Blue Pig N' Fig."  Pastoral also has an olive bar with free sampling of their cornichons and at least six kinds of olives...

I just did a quick walk-around the French Market.  Well lit, wide aisles to mosey down and people-watch and dream about what to eat next.  There is a warmth that draws you inside, plus ample seating just outside the market area. There are so many places to try and it's a happy, food-made-with-love kind of place.  I will no doubt be coming back bientot!
review.author: Eva S.

review.description: A great place to bring big groups of people! There's something for everybody. I plan to be back to try more and more :)
review.author: Anya R.

review.description:
I absolutely love this place! I discovered the market about two years ago and have been coming back every chance I get. My favorites are:
-Pastoral: amazing selection of artisan cheeses and wines, very friendly and knowledgeable staff
-Fumare Meats: best pastrami I have ever had. Probably the best in Chicago
-Aloha Poke: soooo good but go after lunch to avoid waiting in line 
-Beavers Donuts: WOW! Amazing fresh mini donuts and Milkshakes + great customer service 
-Loop Juice: fresh, delicious, reasonably priced juices and smoothies
review.author: Sam W.

review.description: This was a very cool market with a wide variation of food to please anyone's tastebuds.
review.author: Natalie H.

review.description:
I really like the French Market though it gets SO PACKED at lunch so that you can sometimes not really walk through.  People are pretty organized and step out of the way when they're waiting for food, but I will say that some of the kiosks are set up better than others and much more conveniently.  You can easily tell which restaurants/shops are the most popular during lunch time as you'll wait 20 min for one spot or 2 min for another, but I personally think all of the spots are good and use fresh ingredients.  You can even shop for food to prepare for dinner or wine to bring to a party - quite convenient.

I will say that I think their seating area can be a bit more organized.  People are fighting for spots and there's not a ton of room.  I realize they can't exactly add more space, but it's tough to sit there and eat - much easier to pick things up to go.

Worth a visit for lunch/ice cream/shopping/wine pickups/etc.  Good addition to the train station.
review.author: Kathleen C.

review.description: We discovered this place on our way back from seeing the blooming corpse flowers at the botanical garden.  While I don't think "French Market" is quite the proper term we loved this place and came back every day during our stay in Chicago.  So many different foods to try, all of which were very tasty.  The goat cheddar at the wine and cheese market is the best cheese I've ever tried.  The truffles, chocolate with bacon, baked potatoes, lobster mac n' cheese...okay, I'm getting hungry and ready to go back.  This place would make being a train commuter in Chicago worthwhile.
review.author: Alex P.

review.description: Yummy I loved it here...had the aloha poke wasn't hot at all...would pass on that next time! Everything else looked great!! Will come back again
review.author: Karen R.

review.description: A wonderful, eclectic mix of different restarants and shops here. Located right underneath the Ogilvie(?) Station, this place is practically hidden. There's a whole array of places to eat and drink: Vietnamese, lobster, poké, fresh fruits, donuts, desserts, bubble tea, you name it! A great place to go and eat lunch, but beware, it can get packed!
review.author: Jennifer M.

review.description:
Whether I'm jumping off/on the train at the adjacent OTC or just in the area and looking to kill time, I love walking through here. 

The colorful stands of all sorts of foods are always fun to admire. The French Market is filled with any cuisine you could possibly be craving. 

With delicious Mediterranean, smoky barbecue, flavorful curry, fresh gelato...hot Beavers donuts, how can you choose? You can't. You'll just have to make plenty of return trips so you can feast on it all.
review.author: Meghan H.

review.description: If you can go on a Saturday go.  Not crowded at all.  So many good food vendors - my favorite are Saigon Sister's Classic Ban Mi and the Belgium fries ... great place to get a lot for less and love the free charging stations in the dining area.  A hidden gem that I love to take guest to.
review.author: Cam R.

review.description: This market is a FIND near Ogilvie train station! Take the double doors at the end of the food court, walk through the hallway, and be transported into another world. There are many vendors in this market, each selling a unique product. Grab a macaron from Vanille Patisserie on your way in. Haven't had breakfast? Beaver's Coffee and Donuts (cute little donuts!) has got you covered! Want something a little more French? FLip Crepes and Le Cafe du Marche are there! Need groceries? City Fresh Market can help you out! On a raw/vegan/non-GMO diet? RAW has got you covered. Honestly, there is a wide variety of flavors that can pique different interests every day. If you're taking a train out from Ogilvie, I'd recommend stopping by!
review.author: Madhavi B.

review.description:
I went over here a few weeks ago as my friend made a recommendation to visit Beavers Donuts for their donut shakes. Absolutely two thumbs up, if you can afford the calories! I ordered the strawberry Nutella donut shake and it was phenomenal. I want to go back and try other shakes on the menu. One shake probably equals an entire meal, but it's totally worth it!! 

As for the French Market as a whole, it is a hidden gem if you aren't around that part of town often. There are so many options for food, groceries, and private kiosks for shopping. Definitely a place to check out!
review.author: K. A.

review.description:
I love a good multi-vendor market. Chicago French Market is not my absolute favorite market I've ever been to, but it's really, really solid. While it's a bit on the small side compared to some others, everything seemed really high-quality.

My favorite things that I got from the market: a mermaid tote bag from Saigon Sisters and the BEST. FREAKING. PASTRAMI. EVER from Fumare Meats. I will go back to the market for the pastrami alone, and I can't wait to sample goods from some of the other vendors.
review.author: Susie R.

review.description: There are a lot of places to choose from for a quick bite to eat.  Great sitting area in the back of the market.
review.author: Regina T.

review.description: What a fun location "hidden" right in Ogilvie train station! I never even knew this place existed-but my first trip was very fun. I especially enjoyed all of the fresh produce, the crepe location, and the bakery. There were many other locations here too- I will definitely be back to check it out in the future. If you are looking for it, just get off a train in Ogilvie and head to the opposite end of the station from where you normally exit- take the stairs and pow- you are there!
review.author: Lindsay B.

review.description:
I love the Chicago French Market! Although, I have to admit that I don't know why it's called "French" when they have offerings from all over the world. This market has added a bright spot to my dreary commute to Ogilvie over the last few years. When you walk in you're immediately hit with the delicious aroma that fills the place. It's like flowers and caramelized garlic. Maybe that description doesn't appeal to you but just imagine the most delicious smell you can and that's it!

The market is always orderly even when it's very crowded. I think this is because of the layout. There's plenty of room for people to wait in line at one booth without blocking another. Also, the dining area is always orderly and it's big enough to accommodate large crowds of people without feeling overrun. The best time to go is in the winter because you feel like you're eating outside at a sunny cafe even thought you're in a train station!
review.author: Dustin G.

review.description: I came downtown for a lunch hour meeting - complete with lunch from Corner Bakery.  If I wasn't full from lunch, I definitely would have left this place with SOMETHING!!!  This is a delightful addition to Ogilvie Station...I'm not sure if people who don't commute through here even know about the place.  I used to commute out of Ogilvie 10-ish years ago, and this would have been nice back then, and for the fact I used to work across the street.  Needless to say I'm jealous of those who have that kind of set up these days as there is ANYTHING and EVERYTHING food-wise to buy, and the items aren't just "FRENCH"  It's an adorable place for sure! Lots and lots of food items to buy, an area to sit down and eat those items...and other non-food items as well.  If you're commuting through Ogilvie or nearby, this place is worth walking through.  Odds are you'll leave with something!
review.author: Janine K.

review.description:
What a fun place. So many cute vendors. It's like a food truck alley but inside. If anyone has been to Michigan's Gibraltar trade center, it's like that but for food. 

Very cute and food styles from all over the world.
review.author: Jacquelyn M.

review.description: I was in town for a few days and as I always like visiting markets when in a different city, I've chosen to visit the French Market.The French Market is not very far from Chicago's main attractions. Of course, you can find vegetables and fruits but mostly little spots to eat and you have plenty of choices. I stopped at Aloha Poke for lunch (decision was made when I saw the word Poke which is kinda my new thing now). There weren't much people, the service was great and I was greeted with smiles. I ordered a marinated Tuna Volcano Poke over White Rice and honestly it was one of the best I've tasted so far! All the ingredients were fresh and well seasoned. After I went to an Ice Cream spot (which unfortunately I do not remember the name), and I had goat cheese and caramelized peanut Ice cream and it tasted very good! I really enjoyed my experience at the French Market and will definitely be going back the next time I'm around.
review.author: Cindy D.

review.description: My daughter was here on a school trip and wanted to share it with us folks after the AIC. It was not exactly walking distance from the AIC but glad we stopped in. Tucked away with the trains is a lively and festive food court market with a really eclectic mix of vendors offering just about everything you can think of. My daughter is a huge fan of the crepes and macaroons. My wife and I were in the mood for a burger so we hit the Belgian burger bar and ordered two number ones with fries. I noticed the fries were a big hit with lots of other folks just ordering fries. The fries were nice and crispy just like I like them. True to Dutch form they offer mayonnaise along with the fries for free, along with ketchup as well. If you want to get fancy they also have flavored sauces for 75 cents per or 3 for $2. I was also glad to see they had malted vinegar as well. If you have not had fries with malted vinegar yet, you are missing out. What was also surprising were the prices during happy hour - $2 PBR tallboy, multiple bottled belgians for $3?! Really good homemade mushroom soup for $3.50. Also nice to have was the complimentary live music during happy hour and the sitting area where you could nosh on your selections. I would totally come here again and this marks the second food court/market type place that I have been to downtown that is a bookmark go to. Next on our hit list is the Italian market.
review.author: michael w.

review.description:
The "French Market" refers to the grocery section of the street-level floor in the Ogilvie Transportation Center, but there's a wide variety of shops within this space, including gelato (Black Dog), coffee and donuts (Beavers), meatballs (Meatball Vault), poke (Aloha Poke), a deli counter (Fumare), Vietnamese (Saigon Sisters), lobster rolls (Da Lobsta), BBQ (Lillie's Q), and more. Seated and standing tables are located in one dedicated area.

The French Market itself sells produce and packaged goods at prices comparable to Whole Foods, and it's a convenient place to pick up some things before catching your train.

On weekdays, this place is packed during lunch and less crowded during dinner.
review.author: Angela C.

review.description: I wish it were open on Sundays. And later at night. Otherwise, no complaints! My favorite spots are the meatball place for cappuccinos, Delightful Pastries for ham & cheese croissants, and the Korean BBQ spot in the back for bugolgi.
review.author: Marjorie H.

review.description: I always shopped at the French Market, If I need something for dinner...ie:bread, dressing, tomatoes, whatever, it was very nice to be able to run in for last minute items just before you get on train....but now ...the rules have change, you cant purchase anything with your debit card unless its over $5.00...in this day and age when no one carries cash, and even McDonalds encourages you to use your debit card....I know I will not run in anymore to purchase the last minute things I need.....it doesn't make sense when a business takes the convenience out of using them.......
review.author: Mary Ann B.

review.description: What a fabulous place, with such a broad variety of places in which to indulge.  The seating is limited with mostly business people from adjacent office buildings, but we loved the choices.  Cafe du Marche, sushi, kosher deli, raw foods, vietnamese food, crepes, vanille patisserie - it goes on and on.  What a treat and delight.
review.author: Ali C.

review.description:
This place is perfect. Whether you're dropping in quickly to pick up lunch to go or if you're wanting to try something new-- The Chicago French Market is the place. 

I took a colleague from Texas here the other day and we had a blast. First time for both of us. We had quite a few meetings in the loop and decided to have lunch here. 

There is a parking garage but there was no attendant. It took us a good 5 minutes to see the tiny sign on the hut that said "parking full--monthly only" but there is street parking surrounding the building, it's usually all taken though. Drive north a bit and there's a small side street with a lot of metered parking. 

We ordered from Da Lobsta, original lobster sandwich. SO DELICIOUS!! The workers there were very nice and helpful. 

We also got desserts from Lolli and Pop. I got a couple truffles and 2 Petit Fours for my husband and I to share. They have so many flavors and designs. It was difficult to choose only four. But the selections I made were to die for.. Can't wait to go back and try something else. It seems like anything you get from them is delish. 

We walked around quite a bit and got to see all the vendors. They market had a wide array of food selections, if you are here with a big group there is something for everyone. 

There isn't a lot of space for tables. Just a corner of the market. I would suggest staking a table out and having someone save it for you and you can order food in shifts.
review.author: Lynette H.

review.description: Went there with my wife we found a breakfast place where they make creps she enjoyed it we also had some croissants ,and if you want go healthy i had  a vegetable juice at a stand where they sell them  very clean place different choices to choose to eat I enjoyed  it would go back again.
review.author: Richard H.

review.description: The best lunch spot near my office. I always come here when I'm not sure what I'm in the mood for because there are so many great options.
review.author: Kathryn C.

review.description: It makes me real happy to know places like these exist. A tightly knit string of wonderful vendors serving good food and market items. I will say it can get crowded, but good things attract consumers. Dont get me wrong, some vendors straight up suck. but most of it is great.
review.author: Gill S.

review.description: Fun place to visit, we went on a Saturday morning for brunch and I was surprised that it was open. There were virtually no crowds on a Saturday, unlike the weekdays where the place is swarmed with people. We had breakfast sandwiches by the place next to beaver donuts (I forgot the name). Nonetheless the sandwiches were good and after eating we walked around again and ended up purchasing soda's at lolli and pops (candy place) and I got a great deal on cupcakes at vanille. They were buy one get one free. Overall we enjoyed our time at this place.
review.author: Tony A.

review.description:
They have grocery items but we came here for the food! After landing and checking into our Airbnb, we found ourselves at a strange lunch hour ~3PM so we headed to the French Market. 

Ask Fumare Deli for a sample of their pastrami. This may have been one of the best pastrami sandwiches I've had. Juicy! Staff was really nice and patient. 

We also got a lobster roll from Da Lobsta. Really buttery and tasty. 

Overall I enjoyed my visit at the Chicago French Market. From dessert, groceries, sandwiches, coffee etc. this is a great place for variety and indecisive people.
review.author: Elaine L.

review.description: Terrible design and line control make it a disaster at lunch, but go for the sweets during a slower time.
review.author: George C.

review.description: What a fun find in Chicago! Full of great eateries & food boutiques! We had the  Montreal pastrami sandwich (best ever) and the crepes, which were also very good.
review.author: Lauren W.

review.description: Nice environment and food here looks so delicious. I had a coffee here which is really good. Next time I will try their fries and desserts;)
review.author: Shirley H.

review.description:
The French Market is a great stop if you're commuting or in the area. There are a lot of reviews here saying "well, it's not EXACTLY like the markets in France and I don't really feel like I'm in Paris". Ummm...it's in the basement of the Metra station in downtown Chicago so what do you expect?

I actually find it authentic in the sense that the FM reminds me of the small markets attached to train stations in France & Germany. There are multiple places to grab a quick bite, pick up something to heat up at home or score some treats. I especially like the inclusion of cuisines that are historically French influenced like Vietnamese, Québécois & Belgian. Sure, there are some outliers - sushi, Indian, a raw food place, but you certainly won't lack for choice. 

I had a delightful pate sandwich and Pastoral, some yummy tea from Bello and I grabbed some treats from Vanille on the way out. (Couldn't resist the macaron case)

Would I make a special trip? Questionable - unless I was dying for some macarons and couldn't get to Lincoln Park. But you can bet I'll stop if I'm nearby.
review.author: Joanna T.

review.description:
This is a really cute indoor market with a wide selection of things to eat.  Chocolates, Paninis smoothies, organic raw , fruit stand...

There's a seating area towards the back where you can take your food.  I went around 6pm on a Friday and it wasn't very busy at all.  The market was smaller than what I imagined from reading the reviews on Yelp, but still worthwhile if you have some time.
review.author: Foodie G.

review.description:
A cute food market found in the Fulton district that's only opened during weekdays. Worth the exploration if you're looking for a quick bite. There's a good variety of vendors. And don't be fooled by the name - just because this is called a French market doesn't mean it's all French; they have all types of food ranging from American to Indian to Hispanic.

Foodies, this is the destination for you!
review.author: Olivia S.

review.description:
"Ceci n'est pas une pipe". We get it. You've been to France, and this is not an "authentic" French Market. We've been to Paree, aussi, ma cheri- we get it.

Chicago's French Market is a commuter market in the sense of the Reading Terminal Market in Philadelphia, or Pike Place Market in Seattle. I at least agree that the name does not match the mission- why it wasn't named as a terminal market or commuter market is just bad branding, but it doesn't make it a bad market. I'm so happy it's here. Ceci n'est pas Paris, afterall.

Flowers, fresh herbs and vegetables, meats, cheeses and wine- stop here on your way home for that one thing you need to make dinner at home! Market success.

Lunch- Da Lobsta, Lillie's Q, Saigon Sisters, a good selection, albeit a small selection of eateries.

I enjoyed my Banh Mi from Saigon Sisters, washed down with a Beetacular juice from Loop Juice.

For your commute home, for lunch, the Chicago French Market is easy "brie-z"!
review.author: Kyle H.

review.description: Love this place! Great food selection & fun atmosphere. It's like a hidden gem in the city. I tried open-face bao buns from one stand and they were delicious. A friend and I then sat at a little bar station and enjoyed delicious beers while sharing a Dutch burger with pomme frites. A burger topped with smoked Gouda cheese and an egg, how could you go wrong? We tried several dipping sauces for the frites but settled on the truffle mayo a our favorite. Afterwards we strolled through the market and I found the perfect bracelet for my sisters birthday from another vendor. I recommend this quaint little Market to anyone looking for a place with delicious food options and vendors as well.
review.author: Jennifer C.

review.description:
I came by with specific places to visit in mind and was going to take the metra afterwards anyway, so it worked out. 

I don't think it's much to see, for anyone to swing out of their way just to come explore THE French Market because it's so interesting - it's not.

There's a lot of food and a eating area, so you can grab pastries, fruits and produce on the way home, cheeses and meats, or a very expensive lunch to go.  Every vendor here is pretty expensive, even if they're not any more artisan than your average local shop.

 Unless you have a vendor you love to visit, want to kill time while nearby, or work/live close enough that it's convenient, don't bother.
review.author: Tian Y.

review.description: What a great concept. I had the pleasure of visiting this place for lunch. Picked up a great Bahn Mi at Saigon Sisters. I ordered the one called Porky and it was near perfect. The bread was fresh and the pork tender. I will definitely be back. Lots of cute shops. Hidden gem and if you're in the neighborhood be sure to stop by.
review.author: Myra W.

review.description:
I ended up here two days in a row!!!

First the market is really unique to Chicago. In fact it reminds me of markets I've visited in other cities. For example, it is very similar to the maket in Philly. 

There are many unique businesses here. (I am not sure of the names of them...sorry!!!). 

One place had cheese...in fact it was the only place that had cheese. We were able to sample them before buying them. Yummy!   They also sold a spicy concentrate for  bloody Mary's.  It was really good and it is the only place in Chicago that carries it. 

There is a nice florist and a place to buy homemade soap products too. Definitely unique gifts for a special someone. 

And if you are hungry there is plenty to choose from: Sandwiches, Asian, pasta, etc...  One place that I am going to go back and try is the Belgium Fry place.  They severe them just like in Europe in a cone except this cone has been supersized American style!!!

This is a great us of space. I can hardly wait to come back.  I keep dreaming of the fries!!!

I also noticed stairs up to the different Metra Tracks but is another adventure for another day!!!
review.author: Anthony M.

review.description: Such a great hidden gem. It's easy to miss, but we loved it. So many options! We got delicious, decadent grilled sandwiches, coffee, and dessert.
review.author: Katie P.

review.description: It says spend 20 or more will get free parking, which is a lie. The food is just okay but expensive. Bad experience ever.
review.author: Wenjing Y.

review.description:
To market, to market...

I've seen this place evolve from just a few stands to a full on food court/market. This is why I try to come into the city via Ogilvie and not Union. Snacks for the Metra or dinner to bring home. Ah convenience. 

And speaking of convenience, I love how I can get to my train directly from the Market. The train schedules and tracks are marked well so no one should get lost. 

Every time I've visited it seems like an off time at the Market, it's quiet, just a few customers browsing (which is fine by me) There are a lot of vendors--BBQ, Little Goat Bread, Da Lobster, Vanille Patisserie, Flip Crepes, Saigon Sisters, Pastoral and more. Prepared meals, produce, bread, meats. coffee, drinks.   

Things are a little on the pricey side, but I know that's what you get for convenience. I'm still a fan.
review.author: Aimee M.

review.description: This is my new favorite place to eat in Chicago! It's like a SE Asia Hawker Center with a market. Get fruits, veggies, fish, meat, cheese, macaroons, dessert or grab a meal at one of the food vendors. It's clean, the people are friendly, the music is French. I cannot complain. They also have a happy hour 4:30-6:30 M-F. And Rush Hour Concerts every Wednesday and Thursday from 5-7.
review.author: Elly V.

review.description:
Thought this was a hidden gem, but it seems there are plenty of Yelp reviews - not sure if that's good or bad. It's definitely seems a bit dusty and neglected in here, but that's not stopping me yet. 

French Market would definitely be a fantastic place to stop with a group of out-of-towners for lunch. From Lobster rolls to packaged European import foods to Belgian fries and 'Little Goat' (yes, little sister of Girl and the Goat), there is something unique here for everyone. There's also a nice little space in the back for everyone to eat together.

The Macarons at Vanille's make a delicous dessert (sugar plum and violet cassis were our choices). Don't bother with the other places selling them - they don't match up.
review.author: Lindsay B.

review.description: the only reason i gave 4 stars is because we came on a saturday.. and they were closing most of the stands really early so we didnt get the full experience of the place!
review.author: Tay K.

review.description: I love the fish counter here!  Scallops as big as your head.  Fresh baby octopus.  Great selection of fish.  Reasonably priced too.
review.author: Elizabeth W.

review.description: Great experience at the market. Everyone was friendly and helpful.  Noshed at several places.  Risotto salad from Pastoral, Hawaiian Grilled sandwich from (I forget - the grilled sandwich place) fabulous fresh doughnuts & great latte from the tiny coffee bar!
review.author: Laura B.

review.description:
Want a taste France, but you're low on the dough? It's OK! Stop packing your suitcases and take the CTA over to the heart of downtown to the French Market. I promise it's just like Paris except everyone speaks English - no translator needed! Within the French Market, you can find a large variety of vendors selling almost anything! Some of my favorite places to frequent are:

1) LaVazza Coffee: they have some of the best lattes and cappuccinos in the city IMHO - definitely worth getting on one of these frigid Chicago winter days. 

2) Vanille Patisserie: macarons - nuff said. The price can be pricey, but their flavors are very unique, which change daily, but beware, they sell out in a jiffy so you gotta get here early!

3) Frietkoten Belgian Fries: Belgium isn't exactly in France, but it's in Europe right? So, you get to hit up two countries at the same time - perfect! Their thick cut Belgian fries are amazingly crisp and come in a huge cone. I would go with the small size - I came with three people and we struggled to finish it. Additionally, the fries come with the standard mayo for dipping, but they offer other dipping sauces as well for additional charge, such as truffle mayo, fire roasted pepper, garlic mayo and more. 

4) Beavers Coffee and Donuts: Their donuts are the reason I keep coming back. Wide selection of mini and regular size donuts that run the gamut of being filled, cake donuts, glazed - you name it, they got it. Coffees aren't half bad either. 

5) Saigon Sisters: great bahn mis, which are Vietnamese stuffed with just about everything and piled up with pickled veggies and fresh herbs - Oh, did I mention we're making a pit stop in Vietnam too? 

These five vendors don't do this place justice. There are other bakeries, grocers, seafood mongers, deli and more! You just have to check it out for yourself. Believe you will thank me when you do. If you want to drive, there is a parking garage located in the middle of the building which can be confusing to find. However, you can only park for 1 hour for free, that's the catch so I'd recommend taking public transportation because you can't explore the entire market in an hour!
review.author: Sonny S.

review.description: Really cool concept and a huge selection of food. It can get pretty cramped inside and the seating is almost always full. I wish there were more low carb options.
review.author: Ryan S.

review.description:
Sacre bleu, I wanted to really LOVE this place.

I adore the concept, I liked the look of it and the visual is great.  It was clean and nice, well organized with clean restrooms.  The sun was shining on the tables and chairs outside - I even got a little sunburnt.

But we tried gelato and molasses ginger cookies and did not finish either one.  Yes, you read that right, I left a sweet unconsumed.  I am a Molasses ginger cookie freak and only ate one stale bite.  I had better ones from Costco.

Oh French Market, I wanted you and I to be lovers.  I will try again to see if I can raise your rating.  Je regrette....
review.author: Kathleen M.

review.description: This is such a beautiful, quaint little farmer's market - even if you're not buying anything, it's just a nice stop to stroll away your morning and enjoy the atmosphere. It has a European feel to it and can be quite festive during the holidays with the decorations and live music. The food is a little pricey, but it is a novelty-style French Market. Located conveniently off the Clinton Green CTA train line.
review.author: Willie W.

review.description:
Been here more than 20 times, it's one of my happy places.  I've eaten at nearly every vendor, there's really no bad place to eat here!  On Saturdays, sometimes I just go grab a whole bunch of different things and share with a group of friends.  

Saigon Sisters and Pastoral get lots of shout outs, so I will name some other tasty treats!

Delightful Pastries has amazing 'Rainbow Cookies', which are actually little slices of fluffy layered cake with chocolate and jams inspired by the Italian flag.  Like a million flavors, all heavenly!

Loop Soup has an apple pie grilled cheese!  Some people are scared, staring at the menu board in disbelief.....don't listen to them....get it!

Da Lobsta has the buttery-est toasty Texas toast buns with giant piles of lobster!  They come across pricey, but I swear theres like a whole lobster on one roll.  And no imitation filler either, you will see all lobster!

Flip Crepes has a Croq' Madame Sandwich with savory bechamel sauce (reminds me a bit of white country gravy) and a fried egg.  They were happy to offer me the option to do cheddar and turkey rather than ham and swiss.  So amazing!

Frietkoten Belgian Fries & Beer didn't really jump out at me until I saw they had curry mayo and curry ketchup for their fries!  Also wasabi sauce and peanut sauce!  I'm not the biggest fry fan, but the sauces totally make them! p:

Bello Tea has so many great flavors of bubble tea.....how do you choose?  I highly recommend coconut taro also passion fruit.  I know everyone gets tapioca pearls, but try the coconut jelly!  It's not as filling and still fun and chewy!

Lolli and Pops is new, you won't miss the giant gorgeous display case with rows of luscious truffles!  Yes, they are pricey, but so worth it!  If you just want to treat yourself to one or two, don't be afraid, they won't pressure you to buy more!  So many neat flavors like strawberry balsamic and marion berry vodka!

Loop Juice has some amazing fresh squeezed juices!  I especially love the Detox with carrot, apple and ginger, so refreshing!  If you are in a hurry, I would suggest having a juice as a great meal on the go.  Super healthy and filling!  

Beavers Coffee and Donuts, I have yet to have your coffee, but you have marshmallow crispy treat mini donuts!!!!  It's hard to resist watching the magic deep fryer pop out the little donuts and watch them swim around until they are toasty brown......but then you added marshmallow cream drizzle and rice crispies????  Sold!

LILLIE'S Q always seems to close a little early, so try to snag some before they close!  Super tender BBQ and lots of great sauces to choose from!  The Carolina Gold is a nice change from your usual sauces, it's more a mustard base, and Ivory is a mayo base. 

I was sad to see Lavazza and Little Goat Bread go.  But they have other locations, highly recommend both!  Also I'm not sure if Spicy Monkey is gone or just taken over by Loop Soup?  They have many of the same sandwiches and make your own soup concept....in the same spot.  Still just as good, although I miss the 'Trust Me' grilled cheese with blueberry jam, that was probably one of my favorite items in the Market.
review.author: Crystal Aura W.

review.description: Not sure why it's called the French Market. Lots of different kiosks of international foods. Place seemed kind of dark, lighting isn't very inviting. Had the Pho from the Saigon Sisters...won't be going back. Overall, quite disappointing.
review.author: Ranoa D.

review.description: Such a great weekend adventure. Located in the West Loop of Chicago this market is great for fresh fruits, veggies, and juices! We come here to grab some juices or beers before hopping on the train to head to the suburbs. This market offers local vendors a chance to compete with the retail giants.
review.author: James C.

review.description: Cute concept but not really a French market. More like an indoor food truck gathering without the food trucks
review.author: maria h.

review.description:
Really enjoy this place. Lots of lunch options...fun foods to take home.  Only problem is, the vendors keep changing!  They could use more seating in the lunch area.

Lots of delightful choices this place!
review.author: Gretchen D.

review.description:
Things I don't have time for: sad desk lunches and mediocre food courts. 

Thankfully, French Market's aisles are lined with vendor pop-ups, each serving up a different specialty and representing some of Chicago's good eats: Pastoral Artisan, Black Dog Gelato, Vanille Patisserie, Lillie's Q and more. Regardless of what you're craving - be it smoothies or bánh mì or pasta - there is a vendor to suit your hunger.

Some vendors come and go (RIP Little Goat pop-up), but that just keeps your options open and interesting.
review.author: Kelsey S.

review.description:
What a wonderful place! The smells are so seductive.......

Over ten years in Chicago and I recently visited the French Market for the first time. How sad for me. My New Year's resolution will be to visit at least once a month and introduce my friends to it as well. I made a hefty purchase at Raw (their food will last for 5 days), I couldn't walk past Vanille Patisserie without making a purchase (they sell a cupcake with macaroons ON IT), and I picked up a pretzel from Ben's Soft Pretzels (delicious). I can't wait to go back and try some of the other vendors. If you haven't visited, please go. Thank me later.
review.author: Mark D.

review.description:
Most cities I've been to have a place similar to this near their downtown.  The farmers market in Indianapolis or the west side market in Cleveland.  This is kinda like those.  It's an indoor space with a number of little chocolate shops, delis and quick food stands.  And although it is called the French market there are only a few French themed places.  I'd say it's more of an international market but that's nitpicking I guess. 

I'd imagine this would be really nice if you work in the area or you're waiting around for your train.  My wife made a bee line straight to Vanille Patisserie for their macarons. I can't lie they are amazing.  Overall, although there are a lot of little shops here, there wasn't anything that was super unique or would make me take a special trip to come back. If you're in the area though I'd check it out, or just take a quick walk west down Randolph to the Fulton market area.  Once you hit Randolph and Halsted you can basically throw your shoe and anywhere it lands is an amazing place to eat.
review.author: Alex K.

review.description: Wasn't a fan. My mom and I probably had the wrong idea going to this market, as we were expecting a lot of french bakeries and such. We ended up leaving without buying anything because the market seemed very dirty and unappetizing.
review.author: Blake K.

review.description: This was an exciting first for me. I was positively overwhelmed by all of the choices, and I can proudly say that I tried authentic Mexican Food while I was there...I hadn't had anything that tasted like "real" Mexican food in almost 3 years of being in Chicago. All of the vendors were patient, helpful, and friendly. The food was fantastic.
review.author: Macy W.

review.description:
OK, I am glad other people have pointed out that this is not, in fact, a French market.  The only thing French about it is the decor.   This market is ridiculously expensive and unbelievably crowded.  

I could barely move around once the noon hour struck and there was just too much happening.  This really is just a glorified food court.  I was unbelievably disappointed considering I'm such a Francophile.  I love all things France, Parisian, market, etc. and this just didn't do it for me.  Maybe on a day where it's less crowded and I actually care to eat a full lunch, I'd be happier coming back.  

PS: There's no parking nearby, so prepare to walk, pay outrageous meter parking or just take the train.  At least this market is in Ogilvie Station which is convenient... if you take a train in or out of Ogilvie.
review.author: Jenna S.

review.description:
there is nothing french about this place, you would have a more european experience at Mariano's. This place is sushi, fried foods, and chips. They don't have french products! They didn't even try.

I was so pissed coming here after living in Paris because  I just missed french food and nothing.
review.author: Jasmine J.

review.description:
A little disappointing. I expected this market to be full of French goodness, but it was really just a market, a bit overpriced as well.

There was a lot of different types of food though: Gelato, donuts, cheese and sausages, sandwiches, crepes, raw vegan food, pastries, and even Vietnamese food. I ended up getting a little vegan dark chocolate sour cherry bark from the bakery. A tiny 1'' by 1'' square as over $1. It was alright. I'd come back to this place if I were in the mood, otherwise I'd look for an awesome specialty store in Chicago.
review.author: Krystle T.

review.description:
I'm never leaving. 

You can't make me. 

You can find so much at French Market! There are tons of vendors selling everything from sushi to sausage. 

I split the lobster grilled cheese and it's divine. I also like the Vietnamese sandwiches - the pork one is delicious. The sandwiches from Little Goat are all so great. I mean, how cool is it that one of them has Cheez-Its on it? Day.made. 

You can also go for fresh fruit, breads, cheeses, macarons and other things. Perfect place to go to prep for a nice picnic or party. 

Seating is tough during peak lunch hours but there is also some dining outdoors. Lovely.

Can't wait to return...
review.author: Jessica M.

review.description: If you are visiting Chicago take in the sites and make sure to visit this food mart. The indoor market has a variety of foods and cuisines to select from. Italian, Greek, Asian, American. Everything from sweets, to treats to meats. A few blocks walk from Union Station.
review.author: M 1.

review.description:
I love the French Market!  It's full of all sorts of delicious treats.  I like going for lunch.  It's a good place to go with a group because there's something for everyone.  They also have a good produce market if you're looking for some ingredients to take home with you.  

Pastoral is a great place to stop for a sandwich or to pick up some bread and cheese.  Saigon Sisters makes a great bahn mi.  

The only downside, is that like most things in / near the loop, it gets super crowded at lunch time.
review.author: Jordan M.

review.description:
I'll try anything French.  What can I say, I'm a Parisian at heart.

If you're in the West Loop, stop by this cute little market filled with loads of French delights that will remind you that your eyes are bigger than your stomach.  Let's just say I wanted a little bit of absolutely everything.  Did I mention the pastries?  This place is macaron, chocolate, and every other delightful French pastry heaven.

Like a little gelato?  No problem.  They've got lots of it.  Chomp on a croissant while you wait for your dessert to be served up.

If you want something a little more hearty, try a divine Belgian burger served on a brioche roll.  Smoked gouda and grilled sweet onions never tasted so good.  Make sure to get a side of crunchy Belgian fries that will make your mouth water.

Perfection!
review.author: Vanessa M.

review.description: Wow - this place was cool. I was in the 500 W. building visiting our Chicago office and had the chance to come down here for lunch. My only complaint is too many options! But none of them were chains - all smaller local-ish businesses. I wish I had something like this for lunch every day at my office. I settled on a savory (turkey, brie and apples) crepe for lunch, and came back down later in the day to grab something sweet - ended up getting Gelato. I'd imagine this is a super convenient place for grabbing not just lunch, but groceries or snacks if you come through here on your commute.
review.author: Mary F.

review.description:
I stumbled upon the Chicago French Market as I was taking a stroll one day. To my surprise, I found that tucked away in a nondescript building under a bridge on Randolph and Clinton is a lot of really good food... 

Don't be fooled by the name: this isn't particularly "French" and it isn't really a "market." If you are coming here looking for imported groceries, you are not going to find them. I would describe the French Market as more of a lunchtime food court with booths from all sorts of local restaurants. I am a fan of the diversity since you can try something new each time you stop in! Some of my favorites are Pastoral (sandwiches and cheeses), Beaver Donuts (awesome donut holes), Da Lobsta (lobster rolls), and Vanille (pastries). Where else can I stop in for lunch and grab a duck confit sandwich, bubble tea, and a macaron?

In the back of this large space, there's almost kitschy French cafe-inspired seating (umbrellas indoors for effect?). It fills up pretty quickly at lunchtime, so you might be spending some time scouting out a spot to sit.

All in all, the French Market is a great place for lunch if you are looking to try a range of local restaurants.
review.author: Lina D.

review.description:
I've been working across the street from the French Market for about a month now, and I think I've already been here 10 times for lunch or to pick up some food for dinner on the way home. The French Market is located inside the Ogilvie Train station, and once you walk in it has a number of different food vendors that you can order to-go, or sit in or outside of the market. My favorites so far have been Pastoral (french sandwiches, meats & cheeses), Little Goat (same owners as Girl & the Goat), the Montreal Pastrami place and the meat deli that is immediately on the left when you walk in (can get different types of meat to grill up when I get home). 

I wonder if I can set up payroll deductions directly to this place to fund the habit I have quickly formed?
review.author: Andrea R.

review.description:
This place is ADORABLE & AWESOME.

This reminds me of a small scale, homey Eataly from Downtown Chicago and of The Grove in Los Angeles. There's an array of food choices... from Indian to Lobster to Crepe sandwiches to Mexican... it's all here.

Choose this spot to shake up your average luncheon or show off your friends when you hop of the trains at Ogilve Station. 

Inside suggestions: Pumpkin Butter Latte from the Italian Coffee Shop, the Indian place was delicious, Crepe Place was decent (looked tasty but fell apart), and Lobster Roll from Lobster Place (friend loved it).
review.author: Maggy B.

review.description: You must try the Aloha poke! I know. That's not French, right? But you must try it anyway. We also ordered an Indian dish, chicken tikka, from another vendor. Then the most expensive item that we ordered was the lobster sandwich. I realize this is such an odd "review" of a supposedly French market right here in Chicago, but I will make it a point to try the truly French items on the market, such as wine and cheeses, macarrons, etc!
review.author: Ruth W.

review.description:
The French market is a fantastic option to grab a high quality lunch, snack, or specialty food items. After a hard the deciding where to eat, we settled on the Cafe du Marche and absolutely loved it. The croque madame (ham, swiss, Gruyere, Dijon, bechamel and a fried egg) was almost as good as my partner has had in Paris. He ordered the hot chicken sandwich with ham and swiss. It was way better than we both anticipated.  

Check out the Beaver Donut stand for amazing addictive donut holes, fried fresh and coated with a variety of toppings. Also, the chocolatier sells the most beautiful truffles. 

We will absolutely come back to try all the other vendors.
review.author: Jason S.

review.description: Quint little food market that not only sells french but a whole variety of other venues like Indian and Belgium. It was much smaller than I anticipated with around maybe 15 vendors. Very clean inside and the food is rather pricy but good. To me it's like a high end international food court. Tried the lobster roll from da lobster and a breakfast crape.
review.author: Arcadian B.

review.description:
I read online that this place was similar to eataly in NYC (see previous review). Out of the 26 vendors there only about 4 or 5 were of French orientation, so that highly disappointed me. it was a crowded place, the food looked and smelled amazing (even thought it was grilled cheeses or Mexican) , and I am glad I went. I bought a loaf of bread that was unbelievable. 

I think partly this rating is so low is that my expectations were so high... But there was not anything in particular that stood out... they were missing be wow factor that i so wanted them to have. There was nothing in particular wrong just a deceitful name. I would definitely recommend you to poke around to look at, but not worth traveling out of your way to go to.
review.author: Kim B.

review.description: Fake French market, they're  have only 3 or 4 French make ! All is American Italian or Dutch make. This is a problems in America if you write " FRENCH " in your business place you have to many peoples coming ...
review.author: Sinan Y.

review.description:
There's a couple of really great places here - it's nice to have a location of Pastoral here, City Fresh Market is a great place to pick up a few things if you don't want to brave a trip to the grocery store, and a few of the individual vendors (Bebe's, Meatball Vault, Fumare) are really great. 

But there's something I can't put my finger on here - they seem profoundly unable to keep vendors here. The turnover is pretty high. Just in the last month or so, three stalls closed. There's no place here that serves a decent coffee since Lavazza left. It appears to have morphed into a lunch food court, because few places are open for breakfast in the AM, and many places are out of things by 5 or 6 pm, the time many of us would be boarding the train to return home. 

Saturday used to be bustling but so many vendors stay closed and now few people wander in that day...it was dead the last Sat. I was there a few weeks ago. 

The planners of the market have somehow missed the boat.
review.author: PJ C.

review.description: How has the French market been right under my nose all these years and I've never noticed it? Well it's probably because its sole purpose is to cater to the west loop business folks, but still a great little treasure chest of delicious eateries very worth checking out. I had organic smoothies, butternut squash soup, barbecue pork and a bowl of poke all under one roof! A bit hard to find parking (like I said they're audience is mainly the walking-west loopians), but I was lucky enough to find a spot right outside on Clinton. I stopped by to check out Aloha Poke and found so many other awesome tings!
review.author: Juan R.

review.description: This is a great space with lots of vendors and a good amount of seating available. I wandered around looking at all the vendors before deciding on what I wanted. This place has a very good variety of food and dessert options. I came around 2PM on a Friday afternoon and it wasn't too crowded but I'm sure it can get more packed during meal times.
review.author: Becka C.

review.description:
Previously, I had been walking past this place for over a year with a vague intention of going inside. French Market? I figured there was a solid selection of bread, cheese, wine, and little else. Wow, I was mistaken in a major way. There's so much FOOD here, it's astounding. And the variety goes way beyond just French. Maybe they should change the name to "Chicago French Market & Market of All French Territories Past and Present."

They have food to buy and take home, food to bring back to your desk, and food to devour on the spot in their spacious seating area. The wifi is busted, but that's ok, you're too busy eating.
review.author: Joe B.

review.description:
A nice little place to grab a bite to eat at. The vendors remind me of a festival/fair (though I can see it be taken as food court). Nonetheless, there is a lot to choose from --- sandwiches, Asian food, Mediterranean, Crepes, and a lot more. 

I ultimately decided on ordering from "Presto Cafe & Grill". Had the beef kabobs which were tasty. Not the best I've had but decent for a quick bite to eat.
review.author: Lawrence Y.

review.description:
What a fun place. If you're a foodie, you can have a great time simply window shopping, or help the economy by actually buying something while you are there. Since they opened, I actually try to get to Ogilvie Station early so I can walk through the French Market before my train leaves.

It never ceases to amaze me the variety of foods you can find there - from Vietnamese to Glatt Kosher; from baked goods to fresh meat, fish and vegetables, wine and cheese, olive oils and balsamic vinegars and more. They also have several places where you can get meals, gelato, wines, etc.

Killing time, or really looking for something, the French Market is a great place to visit.
review.author: Bob R.

review.description:
This is totally a local place, but not the type I'd recommend for tourists from NYC or another city with a large breadth of cultures.  There's good variety of the world, but not of Chicago. From my perspective, this could exist anywhere in the world, and that's just not what I'm looking for. Sure, there might be some great things to eat, but I'm looking for just something that tastes good, I want a whole experience. 

If I lived in Chicago, I'd come here about twice a year just for a variety, but as a tourist, no, I wouldn't come here at all - Go to New Maxwell Street or Portillo's instead!
review.author: Jeff O.

review.description: Amazing!  So much good stuff here:  Vanille Patisserie, Saigon Sisters, Beaver's Donuts and much more!  I came here this past April for the 4th Annual Pastoral's Artisan Producer Festival and had a great time - endless free cheese and wine to sample galore!
review.author: Irene G.

review.description: Whenever I think of a "market," I often think about little outdoor stands with some fruit and goods and whatnot. This ain't that. This is like a food paradise. You can basically get breakfast, lunch, and dinner here. There's everything from smoothies to handcrafted sammiches to fresh seafood and meats you can buy and take home to prepare a meal. The market is huge. It's best to take a walk once around and see what tickles your fancy (which will be a lot) and then make your decision. And it's hiding right under the trains at Ogilvie: great if you take the Metra and need something delicious; just take the stairs at the middle of the platform. You'll probably want to dedicate an hour of your day here, as it does get pretty crowded, but it's so worth it.
review.author: Roseanne S.

review.description:
I have only been there once and wow!  I want to give it more stars but since I have only been there once, I feel my review would be based on the stop I made instead of the entire place.  

It's like an upscale, fancy food court downtown!!!

Great place to walk to and grab lunch.  Everyone can get what they want and enjoy.  There was very little space for sitting, however.  I can't wait to go back and see if it will then receive a 4 star.
review.author: Shane H.

review.description: Very eclectic and friendlier than I expected during the lunch hour! One of the best Italian Ices I've ever had at Polpetti's!
review.author: Chris P.

review.description: I'm from San Francisco and was in Chicago for a business trip, and discovered this place is actually around the corner from our office here. When I went to check it out was amazed by cool it was. There are several different vendors serving up not just french food but also Indian and Korean just to name a few. There are also lots of little stations serving sweet treats, and an area for fresh produce, which is pretty convenient. Definitely recommend coming to check it out if you're looking for a quick place to pick up some lunch or want to browse around at the vendors!
review.author: Jaymie S.

review.description:
My only regret about this market is that I went when I was not hungry. I tried, very hard, to conjure up hunger but a HUGE breakfast made this all but impossible. 

The location, in a train station, the vibe, of a market with endless opportunities for delicious smelling fresh food, and the space, to hang with a friend or catch a bite solo, make me want to head back here next time I'm in Chicago- hungry in Chicago- as I have no doubt it won't disappoint. 

Food options included Asian, Latin, Raw, Dessert, Juice, Take away, and much, much more. As a tourist here I was very excited to find the French Market and would recommend it for other market aficionados. Plus, on a cold Chicago day, it's nice refuge from the whipping wind and cold! Bonus.
review.author: Christine M.

review.description: So cool! Hidden treasure under Ogilvie Train station and offers the most diverse and fresh food options! You can get French, Raw vegan, Mexican, Traditional Belgian fries to customizable soup! If your working in the area or waiting for a train stop in you are bound to find something you love or never tried before! The vendors are a little pricey but it's definitely an experience!
review.author: Kierstien B.

review.description:
This place is OK.  In Indy there is a place just like this (City Market).  Most every city probably has a similar establishment.....

Chicago's French Market is not as big as it may appear on their map layout of the complex.  There is a pretty decent variety of vendors in here but I did not really feel like any of them were doing anything extraordinary.

Some of the stalls were out of daily specials by 1245pm on a weekday so that kinda sucked....

I had a bahn mi from Saigon Sisters and it was ok.  Not really memorable, but it was better than many other misses I have had with this type of sammy.  The service was fast.

The raw food stand in here is all prepared food which I thought was annoying.  If I wanted to buy something pre-packaged and made in advance I would go to a vending machine or something.  Obviously, you can't find good raw/vegan food in any vending machine, however I kinda though the idea was that these little food stalls prepare your food when you order it....

My biggest problem with this place is the parking.  On the official website for Chicago French Market, they advertise that you can get 1 hour free parking in the lot down the street if you validate your purchases to $20+.  Fine.  They ALSO say that you can park in the same lot for the day for $14 if you want to stay past an hour.  When I pulled up to the lot specified, the attendant completely denied the $14/day deal saying it doesn't and never existed for the lot and the most I would be entitled to was a free hour with $20 purchase from the market.  NOT COOL.

This place is across the canal/river so its a little more west of the loop.  If you can make it over here, I think a lot of the food inside is better than most of the lunch choices east-ward toward Michigan Ave.  I don't think anything in here is revolutionary but it is a nice option to Subway or Panda Express.
review.author: Shoshana K.

review.description: It's a cute place to go when you want to browse different foods. It has donuts, french fries, cheeses, lobster rolls, and a bunch of other foods I would label as "specialty."
review.author: Deborah C.

review.description: This spot is dope. Tons of lunch options! There is a one place called Vegan Now, which we only stumbled upon that had gyros, fajitas, tacos, hot dogs, you name it. Vegan comfort food! Heaven. Go here.
review.author: Davila T.

review.description: By far my absolute favorite market. Some of the freshest and most delicious produce and food sold here
review.author: Scott M.

review.description:
Wow, a food wonderland!

Where else can you get Sushi, French Pastries, Creole, Indian, Vietnamese, Chinese, fresh donuts, fine meats/cheeses and Raw food, not do mention doing a bit of grocery shopping?

If you find yourself at Ogilve Station with a bit of time, walk a block north and go check it out! It gets a bit crowded during the week at lunchtime, but the food is always worth the (short) wait.

I'm most fond of Saigon Sister's "Sun Tanned Cow" beef sandwich.YUM!
review.author: Phyllis S.

review.description: Wow, a French farmer's market in the bottom of the station where I could shop, drink and pass time before the train!  Indoors, so no worry of inclement weather.  There are all different types of vendors including cheese, macaroons, fruits/veg, deli meats, and different types of lunch foods.  Toward the back of the market is an area with tables and chairs with music.  There is a vendor that sells Belgian beer and homemade fries.  Grab yourself some of that then snooze on the train.
review.author: Marisa P.

review.description:
Love the Chicago French Market.  With such a wide variety of foods, I don't know how anyone can't find something they like here.  I am always in a hurry when I go through here, but still manage to try something new.  Last trip I got a loaf of amazing sourdough bread - and am now addicted!  I am kind of happy that I don't work near here though because I could see me stopping by there everyday to get breads/cheeses/desserts.  Prices are fair, but can still add up if I made this place a habit.  However, anytime I am anywhere near here, I definitely stop in!

Also, check out the seasonal vendors as you come in.  They carry some really cute items!
review.author: Lupe D.

review.description: In theory, fantastic just not positive it's what I had envisioned. I was there extremely early one morning and not all of the shops were open yet so I do feel like I have to give it another shot. I went specifically for these specialty doughnuts I had read about online. I ordered two dozen to bring into the office. Foolishly, I didn't ask ahead of time how much and almost fell over when I went to pay and they said $75. FOR DOUGHNUTS!?!?! They were not $75 good, but the overall look and layout and variety of vendors was very reminiscent of my time in Paris. I definitely want to go back and update this review after I've had a full experience.
review.author: Heather P.

review.description: When I discovered this place, I thought I had found a hidden gem. Turns out, I was right. There is literally something for everyone here. They have coffee, beer, and wine. They have sushi (although only one location), BBQ, candy, and salads. With outposts for Little Goat, Lilly Q's, and Saigon Sisters I just can't help myself. Newcomer Beaver Doughnuts has been a hit at work and Lavaaz coffee is a nice alternative to Starbucks (and they have gelato! Done and done). They have a quaint dining area where there is often live music and it connects to Ogilvie Transportation Center so I often find myself shopping for dinner or a snack on break or at the end of a long day. At off peak hours it does appear that some shop attendants are sleeping (or less enthusiastic than prime time lunch) but I've learned to get over that. I love this foodie oasis!
review.author: Courtney W.

review.description:
I was a little disappointed to see how actually small this place was - especially after making a 40 minute walk from the L stop (granted, I did get lost a few times on the way over). There was nothing particularly authentically "French" about it, which was also disappointing. 

However, the saving grace was Pastoral. Their cheese and cured meats were delicious and affordable, and the staff were very friendly! Give you free samples and really know how to make good recommendations. If i'm ever back again, it will be for Pastoral.
review.author: Jane W.

review.description: This place has it all! I love it! I come during lunch, which can be a bit of a mess, since apparently everyone else comes at this time as well. Last time, I had the sushi and it was a bit underwhelming, but fear not, this place has a lot of other options. I love that it has fresh flowers and packaged items as well. You can shop, grab a bite and move on with your day. Clean, easy to navigate, I'll definitely be back.
review.author: Brooke D.

review.description:
A hidden gem in the West loop - a sort of cross between an authentic Parisian market and an upscale commuter  food court.   Especially recommended are Pastoral, an artisan cheese, wine, and sandwiches cafe, Fumare Meats for well-executed Montreal-style pastrami, a nice little tea shop named Bello Tea (which has some hard-to-find teas by the cup), and Little Goat, the small sibling of Stephanie Izard's Girl and Goat, with its especially nice salads.  More mediocre eats include Lafayette (Cajun - just ok),  Klay Oven kitchen (fairly good, but nothing-special Indian), and Da Lobsta (maybe it's just me, but I don't 'get' the lobster roll thing).  Seating is at a premium on weekday lunchtime - get there by 11:45 am or after 12:45 pm.  

There is a very interesting crowd there - many West Loop and finance industry workers, a few random commuters, and always some very expensive-looking young women  who overlap the former categories to an extent, but who otherwise you would not typically see in numbers in most West Loop eating establishments during the day.   For eye candy, the only place I know of nearby that compares is the Protein Bar on S. Franklin.  

Overall, a great place to stop if you work in the West Loop, or happen to be in the area, but not necessarily a 'destination location'.
review.author: David W.

review.description:
Great Place in Downtown Chicago to Satisfy various
Tastes & cuisines, My Favorite Is the Raw Restaurant
Which iS Excellent as far as Raw Food goes , with generous 
Portions & Everything is Really Fresh! Also Best Raw food desserts ever
Especially the Lemon Bar!!! My 10 year old Loved the Crepe Stall
& says they are the Best she has ever Tasted !! My husband was also
More then happy with his choice of a deli Sandwich !! There
Are sooooooo many amazing  varied types of food @ French market
It could be a bit overwhelming !!! Everythjng from Sushi to middle eastern 
Great Bakeries with macaroons & just about anything your 
Heart desires !!! Lots of choices for fresh Seafood to cook & home
& a butcher with also fresh choices!!!
I great Hidden Chicago gem, built inside a train station!!
Go check it out !!!, you'll be glad you did !!
review.author: elizabeth t.

review.description: You can't go wrong with the Banh Mi at Saigon Sisters. I had the Classic Banh Mi and Pork Belly Banh Mi. Both were really good but I liked the pork belly more. They gave a generous amount of pork belly. Definitely give them a try when you are there.
review.author: Bin C.

review.description:
This place is awesome!!! I stopped in because my favorite food truck Beavers Donuts has a home base here and I was craving some of their delicious fried dough heaven. But man oh man did I discover someplace special, I mean wow I feel like every vendor has something unique and amazing to offer. So far I've tried almost everyone in the space;

-Fumare Meats is delicious, probably the best pastrami I've ever had and I eat a lot of Manny's so thats saying a lot
-Freiktoken (not sure how its spelled) but the french fry stand with different dipping sauces is a great snack. 
-Juice Loop has some great stuff, I never thought a green drink would taste so delicious and be so good for you
-Pastoral has the most friendly employees, need a good stinky cheese and dry red wine? These guys will hook you up
-Flower shop has a great selections, my wife can attest to this
-City Fresh has a good selection of groceries, many European brands you can not regularly find everywhere.... well maybe Marianos... but still great stuff and really friendly employees
-Poke place which is new I guess has great flavor, first three times I tried it out the line was too long for my liking but last week at 2:00pm I snagged some tuna on rice deliciousness in less than 10min
-Da Lobsta has great stuff, a little pricey, but still well worth trying and good for take out.
-Vanille has my favorite pastry (aside from Beavers) a chocolate filled almond croissant!! So bomb I usually buy 4+ whenever I see them in the display case
-Black Dog Gelato has a must try before you die "caramel cashew goat cheese" gelato that changed my life

I could go on and on, seriously some amazing and top level establishments in this place, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND YOU CHECK THEM OUT!!
review.author: Jim P.

review.description: I never knew this place existed. It's a smaller version of the. "Reading Terminal Market in Philadelphia.  Love this place will be back.
review.author: Patrick J.

review.description: This place is incredible! It has a variety of foods here and great desserts too! You can also get groceries here as well. I had the croque madam sandwich, can't remember which stand, but it was delicious. I always stop and get mini donuts here as well! There's a fresh juice stand here and it's pretty refreshing. I always stop by when I'm in the area as this place has a little bit of everything.
review.author: Khalisah K.

review.description: This place is alright I guess. The highlights for me were Saigon Sisters, Pastoral, and Beavers Donuts. Can't see myself coming here as a destination again, but if my excursions bring me by, I might stop in for a quick nosh.
review.author: Davin L.

review.description: There was a wide variety of food choices to choose from. Had a burrito from one of the vendors and it was good not great. I definitely want to come back and try a lobster roll. Overall, I was underwhelmed, but this may be because I've been to places like reading terminal market which have raised my expectations. I definitely would go back just try out some other things.
review.author: Gabby S.

review.description:
I don't know if the French Market is French, but it does have a certain....as the French say...I don't know.
I would never travel to the French Market, but if you're in the area or waiting at Ogilvie, it's a lot of fun to peruse. It's especially nice when it's cold outside.
The absolute best part is the belgian fry stand. You get a monstrous cup full of deeeeelicious chunky fries, and there's like, 15 sauce choices. Probably my favorite fries after Portillos. 
I'm sure if you lived nearby, it'd be great for small grocery shopping and specialty cheeses. It's fun to see the different chicago vendors in tiny market form.
review.author: Leanne A.

review.description:
The Chicago French Market is the best thing to happen to the West Loop.    So many great places to eat, and it just seems to get better and better.     Offerings include:  sushi, fantastic salads, tacos, raw food, indian food, Korean food (sorta), Lebanese food, Vietnamese banh mi sandwiches, kosher fare, juice/smoothies, bakeries galore, and some very delicious crepes.

The grocery store also isn't bad.    Try the smoked salmon -- some of the best I've had.

The only negative is that the eating area in the back is somewhat depressing.   But it doesn't detract much from the overall experience.
review.author: Joshua N.

review.description:
Pretty disappointing. They bill it as a tribute to European food markets, but it's more like a version you'd find in Disneyland than in a city that also has Frontera and Girl & the Goat. The ceiling is low and it's mostly dark colors, bizarre for a place inspired by the bright vibrant colors of fresh produce and sunshine filtering through tall windows.

It opens at 7 but that's a farce. More than half of the vendors don't open until 10, so three stars is really the most I could have given them (what was open didn't earn the max possible). I came expecting to get breakfast and maybe even pick up some food for lunch, but there was almost nothing available when the market as a whole opened. Even the places that were open didn't have full menus or only started serving until after I had to leave. It's like saying I can borrow your car at 3 but you can't give me the keys until 6.

I had a crepe, it was good. Better than a mall crepe, not really remarkable either way. There was nothing open to see there and the building itself isn't very welcoming, so I left.
review.author: Luke Y.

review.description:
One of my favorite finds in Chicago! The market fills up during lunchtime in the Loop, but it's a great spot for lunch.  Lots of options and different cuisines - everything is around 10 dollars or less, but there are a few spots that have more affordable options.

Some recommendations:
--Vanille - love the Macarons
--Klay Oven Kitchen - cream and lightly spicy Indian food on a cold day...perfection.
--Pastoral - get the Blue Pig and Fig
--Little Goat - The Shrimp. My coworkers also rave about the Turkey
review.author: Anh N.

review.description:
If you often find yourself wondering where you should go to lunch, the answer should always be Chicago French Market. No seriously... ALWAYS. 

You can walk in on either Canal or Clinton - it's actually connected to Ogilvie. Not sure what to get? Don't worry. I often find myself taking a lap around the perimeter before deciding. Something will surely catch your attention. If you're desperate for a hangover cure? get a greasy Pastrami or some Belgian Fries. If you want the best sandwich you've ever eaten and you're willing to shell out a couple extra bucks? stroll over to Pastoral or Little Goat Bread. If you have a sweet tooth? check out Vanille Patisserie and grab some macarons. But even better than all of this is you can grab some produce, meats, or fish to bring home and cook for dinner.

I can't rave about this place enough. And even if I did, I wouldn't be doing it justice. Do yourself a favor and go!
review.author: Erin T.

review.description: Such a cool place! I love the variety of vendors and the smells once you step inside are intoxicating. They had live music playing near the tables and the mural of the Eiffel tower on the wall was a cute touch. I plan to make many trips back here to try all the different offerings.
review.author: Elyse L.

review.description:
I expected Chicago's French Market to wow me. Coming from NYC, I thought it'd be a less pretentious version of Chelsea Market. Turns out it was just a more pretentious version of a food court. Located inside a busy railway station, this market was lackluster at best. We went for breakfast, which it turns out, is not a good time to visit. 2/3 of the vendors weren't open and those that were had very bland options. We ended up eating at the crepe place which was fine but nothing to write home about.

The overall feeling of the market area was a cramped mall food court that had donut stalls and sandwich shops instead of McDonalds and Wendy's. The lighting, layout, and overall ambiance did not encourage us to casually browse, linger, and enjoy our time there. Instead it said "Get your food and be on your way!"

Perhaps I had too high of expectations but if Chicago was trying to create a place for small food business to reach a diverse customer base (like European food markets work) or trying to create a tourist attraction (like Chelsea Market in NY), they would pay a bit more attention to the aesthetic appeal of the space.
review.author: Megan S.

review.description:
I REALLY wanted to like this place but it was just Meh. Maybe it's because I went on one of the first few sunny weekends we had in Chicago. Or that I went later in the day and not first thing in the morning.
I expected a bustling market and the place was desolate with a few vendors already closed up and a number of vacant booth spaces.
I was going to purchase some snack mixes from one booth but there was no cashier in sight so I put my purchases back and left. 
I may go again but overall I was disapointed.
review.author: Megan D.

review.description:
Walking around/into the French Market, all one is able to smell is the deep scent of cocoa. Walking in, it is a clever grouping of several businesses in the market layout. While French foods do dominate, there is also Thai, Asian, American, and Italian (amongst other!) influences as well. 

After taking a lap (with an expresso in hand from Lavazza Expression...che perfecto), we decided on ordering a few different items from different businesses and sharing them. We ordered a lobster roll from Da Lobsta, a fig and brie crepe from FLiP Crepes, macaroons from Delightful Pastries, bread from Little Goat Bread, and frites from Frietkoten. 

The lobster rolls was buttery and had a generous helping of lobster. Definitely would eat that again. The crepe was okay; I would have preferred to have had the crepe "dressed" while it was still hot on the grill so the brie could melt a bit and mix with the fig spread. It become increasingly too sweet since the flavors didn't really meld. The macaroons were heavenly, and the nice guy even gave us a free one since we had to order extra to meet the $5 credit card minimum. We tried everything from blackberry to lemon to chocolate to almond. All were so, so good. The frites were exceptional -- fresh potatoes cut and fried freshly with a variety of different dipping sauces. We just had the traditional mayonnaise, and we were still swooning over them. 

While we were there, there was a free wine tasting in the seating area by Fritekoten, which was nice. We enjoyed a glass of Beajoules Villages while eating our food. We took the bread home for a treat later.

We bought the broccoli & cheese bread from Little Goat, and it was spectacular. Toasted with a bit of butter was a perfect morning pick up.

This is a great spot if you are on the train and can home off to grab a quick dinner to take home, or a nice place to visit with a few friends and share a leisurely lunch. I really enjoyed my visit here.
review.author: Whitnie E.

review.description:
C'est l'amour 
That means I love it in French....thanks google translation

Anyway, this little market is great, however not really a market.  You can get produce, cheeses, sweet treats, spices, soups, etc....a little bit of everything.  It seems more like you can grab lunch!  Its not cheap but average prices for food markets.  They also have GELATO!!!  What an unexpected surprise!

I had some veggie dumpling soup from the place right by the tables...it was GREAT and all for less than $4.  I also tried my friends soup from Saigon Sisters...unimpressed...I think we shouldve went to the actual restaurant.  Pastoral was there.  There was a Raw food restaurant, etc, etc.

Check it out...more for lunch than groceries...like other people have mentioned...yes, its kind of like a food court with the ability to buy goods too.
review.author: Stephanie L.

review.description:
I dig this place. And I have a feeling I am going to dig it even more when the weather turns cold and dreary. I'm from Cali and I am accustomed to getting fresh fruit and veggies all year round; I'm hoping this is a good alternative in the winter. It's smaller than I imagined, but overall I think it's a great concept. You can get some eats, buy some wine, sample some gourmet cheeses, buy your sweetheart some flowers/candy and get some homemade soap. I mean, how can you go wrong - eat, drink, romance, sweets and cleanliness all in one locale! 

This is the kind of place I wish i worked next to - great lunch options and some gourmet items to load up on on your way home at night. Need a fresh, live lobster? Check. Need some bakery items? Check. 

The Metra runs through here, which is cool for Metra riders. Otherwise, unless you live in the area or near the green line, it's not super convenient. It takes some doing to get there, but it's worth it.
review.author: Shannon K.

review.description:
