I absolutely loved this place. Macarons, banh mi, Indian curry, special cheeses, sausages, wine all in one place? How can a girl not love this place? Seriously packed during workday lunch. Waited to get a table. (Fend for yourself kind of deal)
Boys had banh mi from Saigon sisters, we had Indian curry, our sis had sushi. We all tried the boba tea and smoothie stand. 


 I wish I had more time and less kids with me so I can explore all the goodies they had.
review.author: Christie M.

review.description:
An interesting hidden market and eatery in downtown Chicago. There is ample selection of foods, smoothies, pastries and sweets. A nice place to come to on lunch if you work close by. Or even if you are visiting Chicago or are spending the day downtown, great selection and hard to choose because everything looks so good. I got the vibe most places here were health conscious (minus the pastry places!) Although they as well have gluten free selection as well.

There is also a fresh produce market, and from the glance I gave it the prices seemed relatively competitive. I was here on a quick lunch so unfortunately did not have time to look around fully. Definitely want to come back!
review.author: Hina Q.

review.description: This place is the best.  I've been for breakfast and lunch mainly.... If they were open later than 5:30 PM I would likely go for dinner. Love all the selection of restaurants and I've always found a seat in their seating area.   They also have outdoor seating but that can get a little crowded.
review.author: Jes R.

review.description:
I love it! 

This is a nice place to go grab some lunch, desserts, and grocery. I would recommend to go if you never been there. It will definitely have at least one of type that you like.
review.author: Melody W.

review.description:
There is a lot of nice quality local goods and cuisine here.  I think too many people miss the point of it being a "French" market in the sense that it is primarily locally produced/local shops, with Euro-leaning sensibility, and is an open-type market located in an urban metro...like the ones you see in Europe...like France, Italy, etc.  No, there are not 60 stalls filled with crepes, baguettes and brie. Really folks who complain show their own ignorance in that regard.  So, maybe a better marketing name should have been "local urban market," so sue them for creating a bit more ambiance by calling it "French Market."  Ugh.  It seems this place loses one full star rating due to people complaining about the name and expecting to see it overrun with mimes in striped shirts or something like that, I don't know.

Anyway, I do take down one star for much of it being over priced. The grocery items you can find at other markets for less, so not really that appealing for daily staples.  Great if you commute through this station, or are in the neighborhood, and want to pick up a sandwich, lunch or special treat.  Forgot someone's birthday today? Stop here before heading into (or home from) work for a gourmet something or other treat for your friend, boss....or spouse (there is a stand with fresh flowers)...yeah, this place will save your bacon in a pinch.

What is worth the trip if you're not just passing through - - bakery Delightful Pastries great sweets and best quiche in town, Oh Olive! balsamic and olive oils, FliP crepes, Fumare meats, and frankly just supporting all of the local small businesses that have a presence here.
review.author: Christina N.

review.description:
Is it wrong that I thought the soundtrack to Ratatouille would be playing on repeat at Chicago's French Market? Well, instead I was met with some Sheryl Crow and other 90s music playing. Disappointment ensues. hehe Kidding, kidding..well on the disappointment front.

I'm in love with the French Market! Although I don't really see what's French about it. Perhaps the way it's set up with various little shops and getting a bite here and a bite there. I had heard of it for quite some time and finally had the pleasure of going through it on Monday. My friend and I made a full lap of everything before starting our culinary dive into all the cute little shops. There is a lot of cheap street parking nearby if that's how you venture there otherwise it's right under the train station. Oh how I wished I worked or lived right by here so I could pop in for some tasty treats or a quick lunch.

They sell some produce at great prices plus have tons of great food spots like Saigon Sisters, Raw, a pasta joint and a korean place (there are many more I can't think of off the top of my head). They also have quite a few dessert and baked good spots.

I highly recommend Sweet Miss Giving's Bakery, Lavazza and the fry shop! :)
review.author: Sarah S.

review.description: I love this place. There are so many options and things to try, and I get really excited about going here. However, the lack of seating and short hours are disappointing.
review.author: Keeka K.

review.description:
French Market is a bit of a let-down in a city of culinary wonders.  There are numerous vendors here, but they are mostly mediocre (check out the food section for more details).

Service: Most of the vendors are slow when there are long lines, especially at Flip Crepes (if there are 3+ people in front of you in line, don't bother).

Ambience: It's a convenient, clean market with vendors and a grocery area.  There is even a sitting area in the back of the market, but beware of the overly loud, crappy singer/guitar player who could use some lessons.

Food: Basically, there are only a couple places you should go to and many to stay away from.
To stay away from:
Flip Crepes - very mediocre crepes that take a LONG time to make
RAW - very dense, flavorless and super oily
Vanille's macarons - just difficult to eat.

To go to (But honestly, you get better service and cuisine at their actual restaurants): 
Pastoral 
Fumare Meats
Loop Juice
Little Goat Bread
Da Lobsta
Saigon Sisters
review.author: Lu Y.

review.description: Fun French Shop located near downtown Chicago. Wide variety of food stations French and America along with pastries and donuts stations. Outdoor seating along Canal St.
review.author: Sara M.

review.description:
I've been here a couple of times after I finally figured out how to get to it from the train station. Who knew it was under the tracks?

The Chicago French Market has an array of stands, from prepared foods, to fast food, as well as pastries, fresh produce, a cheesemonger, and meat and fish purveyors.

I was pleasantly surprised at the prices for produce and meat. The filet mignon was $14.99/lb, which is on par with Jewel, and it looked a whole lot better too.

I was able to score some oranges for $.10 each and a huge package of basil for $.99, so there are definitely good deals to be had here.

If you go there after work as we did, you might be lucky enough to sample some of the items vendors are selling. We got to try a Belgian beer and some raclette while we waited for our train.

I've also visited a few of the food stands, and the pommes frites, while expensive, were delicious. You can also choose from a Vietnamese sandwich, crepes or even pasta if you so desired.

If I took the Metra home, I would regularly stop here on my way home to pick up fixin's to make dinner.
review.author: Melanie S.

review.description: The hubby and I visited the market a few times during our trip to Chicago. We tried some frites at Frietkoten Belgian Fries & Beer; the fries were okay, not great, but I liked that they had several dipping sauces. Bello Tea has a good selection of loose leaf tea although service was a bit slow. Abbey Brown Soap Artisan makes lovely candles and soaps, which made the perfect souvenirs. And you can't beat that they have Little Goat and Pastoral there for some amazing sandwiches! I absolutely adored the Chicago French Market and wished we had one back in San Diego!
review.author: Parada O.

review.description:
I first have to get this out of my system, why is everyone complaining about the lack of French foods, or expecting that the selection is French, etc.?  They clearly state on their web site and in any other marketing that it is a European style market, where they focus around a transportation center and bring in numerous independent stands.  if you're expecting the food to be French, that seems to be your fault, not theirs...

I LOVE the selection at this place.  The fries from Frietkoten are some of the best in the city, Saigon Sisters is always good, and I could eat the Montreal pastrami from Fumare constantly!  Combine that with some great deserts, fresh donuts, tea, coffee, and more you can build yourself the perfect lunch!  Then you have the general market goods, seafood, fruits, vegetables, bread, cheese, olive oil, etc.  It seems some people are complaining about the pricing, but for me, the pricing seems perfectly good for the quality of the food.  Can you get cheaper food, certainly, but this isn't the place to go if you're just looking for a cheap meal, but I would say most of the things here are a good value.
review.author: Karl Z.

review.description: I know a tourist trap when I see one! Everything here is so expensive! I stopped by with a friend for a quick bite to eat and it was nothing special. The "novel" items like cheeses, meats and jams could be found in grocery stores or in other places around the city if you know where to look or know what you're looking for. Don't get me wrong, you have a ton of high quality variety here but its expensive and just okay tasting. And this is nothing like a French market in France and this place is barely French themed. Its more like an American take on what a French market would look like kiosk-style for touristas.
review.author: Amy M.

review.description: This place seems small but is actually sized well.  Located between Canal and Clinton, I feel like this place doesn't get enough foot traffic even though it is a Metra hub stop.  There are many eateries in here and choice items.  I personally like coming here.  Maybe it is good that it is not so busy so that it isn't overwhelmingly crowded.  I still have yet to try the Klay Oven.
review.author: Sheila K.

review.description:
I adore the french market!

It's very difficult to NOT find something here that'll tickle your fancy.  Want something fancy? Head over to Pastoral for their awesome cheeses and breads.  Want something soothing on a rainy, cold day? Go to Spicy Monkey to get a grilled cheese sandwich and tomato soup -- both done the way you like it. I like FM because of its variety, and because it is indeed many steps above any other food court.

Now, just because this is the "French" Market, do not expect Michelin star quality food. I deduct a star because nothing completely knocks my socks off, most of the items are over-priced, and this place is insane from 11 AM to past 2 PM
review.author: Naureen R.

review.description: What an adorable space with so many different things to see and eat. If you are in the neighborhood I definitely recommend popping in for a little adventure and to grab a quick bite/drink. Lots of big names have stands in here so the French Market keeps busy. There are also a few vendors who sell macarons if you are hunting for those.
review.author: Samantha E.

review.description:
I am obsessed. There is something for everyone. 

Stopped by for Loop Juice (one green juice for lunch, one red in a bottle "to go" for a one-day juice cleanse I was doing the next day). I supplemented my healthy meal with some gluten free macarons, and my husband was able to have a smoothie and a delicious sub on toasted italian bread. 

Not sure how else to explain how much I love Chicago French Market. Just... go. I will be back, no doubt about it!
review.author: Carly T.

review.description: Great place to stop for a few grocery items or a quick bite.  Some of the vendors turn over a bit, others have been there since market opening.  Wide, wide variety of items to choose from.
review.author: Stef M.

review.description:
Je t'aime!!! 

I loved this place! Inside the French Market, you will in fact, find foods that are not French but big whoop! There are french items available for purchase but one of the best things about this little neighborhood gem is that you can get so much inside! Great gelatto, sushi, fresh fruits and veggies, tons of fresh meat and seafood, coffees and lattes, decadent pastries, and more. There are even bistro areas inside and out where you can nosh on your purchases. 

Will be back!!! 

Oui Oui!
review.author: Jessica D.

review.description:
Visited the French Market this summer while in Chicago. What a fun place to browse, but even a better place to BUY. Particularly to buy CHEESE at Pastoral. Yum-me! God protect me from ever having a store like this next to my apartment. I could live on cheese, bread, fruit, and wine. It's a fact.

PS They even have a store that sells Banh Mi !!
review.author: Pippi L.

review.description: Incredible place.  It has a little bit of everything.  Some of the vendors can be a bit expensive, but it is usually worth it for the quality product available throughout the market.  If you haven't had chance to explore this place, do yourself a favor and make it happen.
review.author: Jesus F.

review.description: Lovely indoor marketplace. It's a real treat to visit and sample the offerings. My favorites are Vanille Patisserie and Pastoral. Lots to eat here - Flip Crepes and Frietkoten Belgian fries are fun.
review.author: Saira K.

review.description: This place is absolutely incredible! I have been here a few times but this time my daughter was visiting from out of town.  It took us some time to decide what to eat. For lunch we both had savory crepes then we walked around the loop for a few hours and before getting back on the train we had dinner,  This time we tried this incredible pulled pork, Belgium fries and an awesome deli sandwich.  We took a strawberry crepe home for later.  I also sampled a quiche that they were sampling delicious! The entrance is totally unassuming but once you walk in it's just amazing.  We were there twice in a day and everyone was so friendly. The crepe stand actually remembered what we had ordered for lunch and at that time of day it was crazy busy.  By the overall atmosphere it's nice to see there are people out there who still enjoy their jobs.  The only downer is that it's not opened on Sundays a few months back I was at the flower show and sadly the French Market wasn't opened.  Many of the food stands close early and are not open for dinner Who needs Taste of Chicago when you have the wonderful gem under the train station
review.author: Nancy K.

review.description:
I wonder why they call this place the French Market? Anyways, a ton of food choices here, everything from fast food to gourmet fast food to buying grass-fed meats. Pretty awesome if you ask me.

Located under a train station, you'll be amazed when you first step foot in this market due to the numerous vendors and food options. Before you hop on the train home, take a quick stop to check out what the French Market offers.

Grass-fed meats await you below the depths of the Metra.
review.author: Allen B.

review.description:
WOW! Was my actual first word as I entered the Chicago French Market.
I was amazed at the fresh produce  as we entered, it was better then some organic produce I have seen at Whole Foods. Then as I walked further and was able to see all the other vendors and food retailers, I thought I had entered "foodie heaven". 

I was like a small child in a candy store, there was so many good treats to choose from, that I didn't know where to start. I mixed my lunch with select items from different vendors so I could have a larger experience. Then I had to experience the bevy of sweets. I was stuffed, but happy. 

I visited here twice in my three days in Chicago. I now wish I had more time to experience each and every vendor. I guarantee this will be a stop on all my future visits to Chicago. 

Wish St. Louis would create something like this in our old Union Station, which is in need of a retail makeover.
review.author: Steven B.

review.description:
The French Market makes me wish that I didn't live in the suburbs.  I went for the first time last weekend and pretty much fell in love with it.

I had a Groupon to Flip Crepes so my boyfriend and I shared a crepe that we ate along with a side of fries from the Belgian fries place.  We stopped by later in the afternoon before we went home to pick up some desserts from Vanille.  I also bought some lip balm from Abbey Brown Soap Artisan.

We arrived a little before 11:30 on a Saturday afternoon and the place started to fill up around lunch time.  All the vendors that we interacted with offered us great customer service.

I definitely will be back here soon!
review.author: Jennifer L.

review.description: I would come bere everyday to be honest. They have French pastries around including my favorite all time desert, macarons. I could eat them all my life. Vanille Patierre would be my ideal place. Their macarons are very big and also very fluffy. I've eating their crepes at Flip Cafe and I love it. Big portions and not too pricey. I love getting the strawberry dream desert crepe. It's just a really nice place to chillax.
review.author: Bianca C.

review.description:
The French Market is always the treat I get to indulge in after a long stressful week of classes and returning home for the weekend.

Luckily from the moment you walk-in, greeted by La Vanille and the grocery, you start to forget your troubles - getting caught up in the wonderful whimsical charm of various streets within The French Market. There are many little restaurant shops to fufill every crave.
review.author: Janet C.

review.description:
What a cool place to spend a cold Chicago morning. I was searching Yelp for the best crepes in Chicago and this option came up. So I hopped the bus from Michigan Avenue and spent my time trying to decide what, exactly, I'd choose first. I loved that I could wander and no one was in the aisles, hawking their stuff yet everyone was pleasant and helpful if I asked a question.

I was curious about the bahn mi sandwiches at Saigon Sisters, but couldn't decide which to order. An adorable woman came out from behind the counter and chatted with me; she eventually suggested the Hen House. I wasn't going to get that, because I wanted a REAL bahn mi, but she convinced me. And it was so good! 

I also enjoyed a crepe and took some pastries to go. It was pretty empty when I arrived but filled up right when you'd expect the lunch rush to start. There was plenty of seating and I was able to park for just a bit to enjoy my sandwich and read. 

I wish that this place was around when I lived in Chicago, it would have been a great place to grab something--whether it was cooked for me or ingredients for me to whip up something at home--on my way home after a day at work in the loop.
review.author: Lisa A.

review.description:
I was so excited about the French Market but never came here when it first opened.  Lucky me, I work a few blocks away now, so I plan to come here every week to treat myself to something new.

The Market is small, but they have a ton of delicious lunch options.  Vietnamese sandwiches, gourmet meat and cheese, sushi, raw vegan, Indian, Middle Eastern, Belgian fries and burgers, crepes, juice/smoothies, tea, pastries- you name it.  The selection of grocery items was disappointingly small.  I had hoped there would be several stalls, but really there's just one dry goods vendor, a produce stall, a small meat and seafood selection, and a few of the lunch stands also offer their own grocery items.  There's not enough selection to do a full grocery shop, but if you need to pick up one or two things, you can do that here.  Especially if you want something nice!  

I wish there was more seating too, but everything I've had here - from Pastoral, Saigon Sisters, Loop Juice, Bello Tea - has been delicious.  Can't wait to try more!
review.author: Meredith A.

review.description:
C'est bon!!  Aisles of fresh produce and pastries shadowed by an Eiffel Tower backdrop, what more could you want?! 
Well, other than being magically transported to Paris itself...  As a back-up plan, check out Chicago's French Market...
They have stands full of fresh items you'd find in a Parisian neighborhood but along Rue de Clinton (and it's all sheltered for our cold winters, of course).  
Fresh seafood, croissants, pomme frites, artisan soaps, gelato, flowers, fruits of all colors of the rainbow!  If you're feeling cultural, try the traditional Galette des Rois (King's Cake) made of almond cream baked in a puff pastry (with possibly a hidden feve or trinket of a green French macaron which earns you a free macaron!).

Beyond the French theme there's:
-Sweet Miss Givings bakery (a business which supports those with HIV/AIDS)
-Chundys Indian specialties (I miss their location in Logan Square but they're back with pre-made Indian meals!)
-Fumare Meats which sells Polish Kisha on Saturdays and Fridays
-Pastoral keeps an abundance of their fabulous cheeses, breads and wines
-Flip Crepes has their sipping hot chocolate with, you got it, crepes, jarred jams and marmalades
-Raw and Chicago Organics keep organic products and foods available
-Holla for Challah on Fridays with Necessity Baking Company (also selling wine bags made of Eco-friendly oil cloth)
-Saigon Sisters flip noodles
-Buen Apetito has Mexican elotes and tacos (don't forget about the Mexican Chocolate Caliente)
-Tall grass-fed beef and Wisconsin cheese mart (be sure to try the Sartori Merlot cheese!)
-Pop has crunchy popcorn
-Navy Pier fresh roasted cinnamon nuts always nice and hot
-Candy from Le Chocolatier to finish off a perfect day

The website's map of businesses is a bit out dated so I guess that's a good enough reason to check it out in person!  Oh and although they sell wine, there's no alcohol consumption allowed (BOO!).
review.author: Richie D.

review.description:
Finally got back here, and I still enjoy this place like before. I just can't help it that they need to fix the issues with having better hours(pretty please stay open later Mon-Sat., AND also on Sunday at least till 5-6pm?), make the dining area on the east part of this place more inviting(I wouldn't mind at least a few TVs in that area kept on silent. and it doesn't have to be Milwaukee Public Market nice, but if it were only stepped up slightly...), plus have representation from at least a few non-Chicago vendors? It doesn't have to only be within Chicago ones, say like if they could invite a few that many people usually have difficulty patronizing(i.e. some of the vendors at Andersonville's farmers market, or the ones at Evanston and Oak Park), it'd be even better.

Negatives and how this place could potentially improve aside, I did try the Belgian frites place out(won't even try to spell the name), and it was great. Not as expensive as some of the other places I saw inside here(i.e. Indian food place that was a little past Saigon Sisters), and that was good. I'd like to try Fumare and Flip Crepes out, but I'm afraid it won't be as soon as I'd like till I return, due to the hours not being really good here. And for the love of God, please open till at least 5-6pm on Sundays, and also have slightly later Saturday hours! Don't be afraid to close later on weekdays, either. Take a cue from Milwaukee Public Market's hours, and make yours better.
review.author: Allan M.

review.description:
This was overwhelming for me. There are numerous vendors with every kind of food you could possibly want for lunch, as well as fresh and organic grocery items. I think I'd have to go back several times to get a chance to look at and try everything that looked interesting.
There's a space in the back with cafe tables and highboys so you can stay in and eat. I noticed that all the highboys were missing chairs, but then I saw people eating standing up. Hmm. Well, if it works for you.
I did enjoy my sandwich from Delightful Pastries, and oh that cookie! and the lunchtime people-watching was good too.
review.author: Jules L.

review.description:
I want one of these in NYC! UGH! I mean, I guess it's like a little/more open Chelsea Market, but still. This place is awesome. 

I was a bit overwhelmed by all the choices, mainly because I was in a hurry, but still fell in love with this little place.

All the colors, the fresh fruit and veggies everywhere. The meat stands, all the restaurants. Such a cool atmosphere. 

I ended up getting food at Raw, which was great, but now I want to go back and try everything else in there too! I am so jealous of my Chi-based colelagues who are just a block away from this. I would go to lunch here daily if I worked nearby.
review.author: Linda P.

review.description:
This French market is adorable- an oasis of tantalizing food and European cuteness between the Metra station and the Clinton El stop. 
There is an assortment of really anything you could want to eat here and plenty of seating in the back and at tables in the train corridor. One of my absolute favorite places to stop at is "Delightful Pasteies"- look for the baby pink shopping bags they use! They have an array of European desserts and food items such as soup (4.75 for a large portion with a slice of toasted multigrain bread), meat-filled perogies, quiches, frittatas and all sorts of tantalizing cakes, pastries, and donuts. Go check it out!!!
review.author: Julie Ann H.

review.description:
Wow .. such a nice place.
Quaint small restaurants
Excellent fresh fruits and veggies at a good price.  I always try to take my business there.
review.author: Taufiq H.

review.description: The French Market is not what I expected at all! In fact, not very French or European at all.  You walk in (connected to OTS) and there are multiple vendors selling a variety of goods.  From fresh produce to gourmet coffee your appetite is sure to leave happy after a visit here!
review.author: Sandra J.

review.description: Nice variety of fresh produce, meats, cheeses and food stands all in one place. I got there kind of late on a Saturday afternoon and many of the food stalls were closing. Sampled all the balsamic vinegars at Oh, Olive. The girl working there was super helpful. I sampled a couple of banh bao, recommend the beef with coconut milk.
review.author: Kari B.

review.description:
I had such a fun time at their tasting event! Tons of merchants all selling delicious cheeses, wines, meats, ales, and other tasty treats. All of the vendors were very personable and you could tell they enjoyed their crafts.

I thought the set-up was perfect too. The tastings were done in a separate area from where you made your purchases, so it was a low pressure situation when tasting, meaning i didn't feel like I had to buy a product simply because I took a sample.

We ended up with quite a haul - meat from Utah, wine from Italy, and whiskey from Few, a local distillery (hoping to plan a tour/tasting there soon!).

They offered free parking for an hour with a purchase of $20 or more, but we found a great lot just down the block from French Market - $6 for a whole Saturday! 

This is a fun place to go in the winter months when farmer's markets are scarce, and just as great a place when it's nice out. I believe this was the 3rd annual tasting event, and I'll be sure to head back next year for the 4th one!
review.author: Christina G.

review.description:
Maybe it's just that I like the convenience of one-stop-shopping and I don't go in there with the expectations of perfection, but I still stand behind the French Market. 

Last week I needed ingredients for dinner and I found all of them at the French Market. A veggie farmer for the sides, a butcher for the lardons, halibut (pricey, that fish monger), a lovely baguette, cheese from Pastoral for dessert. It wasn't cheaper than the grocery store and of that I am sure, but the quality was great and the location is convenient. I'm still a fan, and spring and summer crops will probably solidify that.
review.author: P S.

review.description:
I wish I work closer to this area! I finally had a chance to stop by when I took a week off work to take my sister around Chicago. We had lunch with my good friend, Ebs B. I was fascinated by the market. Did it make me feel like I was back in France? Um, not quite, but it was an amazing concept and experience nonetheless.

I finally understood where Saigon Sisters was located. Still, at $8 a banh mi sandwich, you've got to be kidding me. 

I ended up getting a sandwich from Pastoral. I ordered the blue pig n' fig, which has jamon serrano, Aderkase Reserve blue cheese, local fig and black tea preserve, whole grain dijon mustard and field greens. Sounds good, right? Unfortunately the bread is hard as a rock. I think I may have gotten a cut on the upper roof of my mouth from this. I wasn't very pleased. I liked the combination of ingredients inside the sandwich though. It was salty, savory, sweet, and down-to-earth. I loved it.

Ebs got us fries to share from a Belgium fries place, which I've forgotten the name of, with all sorts of sauces. It was pretty good. My sister loved it. 

Really, I wish I work closer to this area. I'd stop in for lunch (with Ebs, of course), and I'd probably stop in after work to do some grocery shopping. The place is like a foodie's paradise.
review.author: Jennie T.

review.description:
Yes, you should check this place out for sure...but was bit disappointed on their quality of food and vendors..

I think Vietnamese food was decent. macaroon was decent. we tried 2-3 other food vendor's item..it was A-OK.

Even though it is a fun concept you shopping, like groceries, EVO,..while you can actually eat and choose from various vendors...I rather missed NY's Eatery..I am looking forward that Chicago Eatery opening.
review.author: Grace C.

review.description:
My new favorite take-out spot!

I love that Pastoral, my favorite salad place, and Flip Crepes, my favorite crepe location, are in the French market. Two birds in one stone! Unlike the location at Lake and Michigan, the Pastoral in the French Market accepts foreign credit cards, which is a plus for me.

My major criticism of the French Market is that it closes too early and does not open on Sunday. Unless I get out of work early, I barely have the opportunity to come here.

Nonetheless, I would recommend you stopping by the French Market!

Food: 4
Service: 3
Decor: 3
review.author: May Y.

review.description: This place is great. It has some of the traditional aspects of an indoor farmer's market, but also provides access to some of the best restaurants, chefs, and food in Chicago via its stands. Some of the notable ones include Saigon Sisters and Pastoral, places that might be more expensive to visit in full-scale but that you can visit here for a little less. The one thing to keep in mind is that this place is REALLY BUSY during the weekday lunch hour, so if you plan to find a place to sit and eat you should go on the early or late side.
review.author: Anna P.

review.description:
Some of my favorite vendors here include Pastoral, Saigon Sisters, Frietkoten Belgian Fries & Beer, Lavazza, Les Fleurs, Fumare Meats, and even City Fresh Market. No, not everything is organic, sustainably produced, or all that much of a bargain but I have a weak spot for the setup here. It really does resemble les marchés en Paris and that is a far cry from Jewel. It's obviously very convenient for commuters and not too far from my building, so in a pinch, it's a very easy go-to spot for one-stop shopping.

Again, it's better than Jewel.
review.author: Mike O.

review.description: It's a cute place to go, but don't expect a very "French" environment. If you're a foodie and you work around here, I'd definitely check it out during a lunch break. There are many vendors here who sell food from belgian fries (pretty tasty!! with lots of different sauces) to vietnamese bahn-mi sandwiches to crepes.
review.author: Cindy W.

review.description:
If you love fresh food from any world influence, then Chicago French Market is for you! 

Try Fumare Deli for the best freakin Pastrami sandwich you've ever tasted. Try Saigon Sisters for a legit Bahn Mi you won't soon forget.

Among quite a few other reasons, this is the indecisive food lover's spot.  My boyfriend and I can never decide on what we both want to eat. This place provides a plethora of unbelievably tasty options, so everyone in the group can find yumminess!
review.author: Emmy H.

review.description: The Chicago French Market is a magical place filled with everything your heart and stomach desire. From Macaroons to Artisan cheese, this place is sure to appeal to all taste buds. Try as much as you are able (might want to wear stretch pants) or if you are local, just keep coming back to try more! If you enter from the train station it doesn't look like much from first glance, but just walk on back and you'll discover a world of "yum".
review.author: Jackie K.

review.description:
Came here for lunch with my good friend Michelle. Wow. It's amazing here! Lots of neat little vendors and O.M.G. PASTRIES! My evil enemy Mr. Croissant was staring at me in the face earlier..but I didn't cave in. Maybe another time we shall battle it out...

Anyway, I tried the banh mi at Saigon Sisters and some macaroons at Vanille Patisserie. I'll just review both places here...

Saigon Sisters:
Pretty tasty, but overpriced banh mi. Tried their Sun Tanned Cow (coconut milk braised wagyu) banh mi and it was good. However, I don't think I'd want to come back to fork over $8 for it...I just can't do it when there are cheaper, just as yummy, places =\ 

Vanille Patisserie:
Moving along, I split a Violet and Strawberry Lemongrass macaroon with Michelle and O.M.G. there was a party in my mouth! It was my first time trying French Macaroons and totally fell in love (damn you, Michelle! You got me hooked XP ). Slightly crunchy exterior, soft, melt-in-your mouth interior, sweet, but light and...and...you MUST try it if you haven't already. I liked both the Violet and Strawberry Lemongrass, but that hint of citrus in the latter made me favor that one more. Now...1.50 per piece is pretty expensive, but these little bad boys are worth every penny! Will definitely come back to try other pastries/more macaroons...Mr. Croissant...I shall battle with you next time, but you caught my eye with your dark brown, glossy exterior...

All in all, tons of cute vendors, a little bit overpriced, not overly noisy or packed, but this place was hopping on a Friday afternoon. Will come again to check out other vendors, but not going for the banh mi unless I'm absolutely craving one and I happen to be at Chicago French Market.
review.author: Jamie D.

review.description:
I think this place is really very interesting. 

Food- lots of different food available- tried the Korean place, Vietnamese, frites, crepes, almond croissants from all the different vendors. All is delicious but not amazing. There are really long waits during the lunch rush hour as well. Frites in particular not that great- wasabi mayo- not wasabi at all. 

Overall this is like a very upscale food court with corresponding high prices.
review.author: Helen H.

review.description: Stopped by here after PT, intrigued by the signs of something "French" and "markety" only to find that this was an overpriced boutique food court/grocery with mediocre paintings of Parisian scenery on the wall.   Part of the Metra station complex.   Pass.
review.author: Brandon B.

review.description: There are so many glorious things in this market. Go there now
review.author: Jessica S.

review.description: This is a fantastic addition to Ogilvie Station. They took a bunch of wasted space and turned it into a Euro-style market. You can do some light shopping, grab some ready to prepare dinner, or buy breakfast, lunch or dinner to eat there. I frequent Lavazza Espression for coffee and gelato, Pastoral Artisan Cheese, Bread & Wine for cheese, Buen Apetito for breakfast burritos, Saigon Sisters for Bahn Mi, and Vanille Patisserie for sweets. Plus, I aspire to try a whole lot more!
review.author: Ba R.

review.description: It's not very big but it sure carries a whole lot of flavor. If you can't find something to eat here, then my friend you where never really hungry.   It has some french food but we have Mexican and bubble tea and these little tiny doughnuts that they make right in front of you. Makes me want to salivate all over again. It's not far from downtown hotels. Good stuff.
review.author: Mike G.

review.description:
I used to buy produce from here all the time when I lived in the area. Of the two produce vendors, the one in the middle aisle (across from the crepe and smoothie stalls) has a better product. 

I've also bought lunch from pretty much every vendor there, and they are all really good for the most part. I wasn't crazy about the vegan place. The horchata from the Mexican food vendor is a must-try though!
review.author: James A.

review.description:
Finally checked this place out a few weeks (ok, probably more like a month) ago to see what all the buzz was about. The market is not authentically French, which is maybe a good thing, since the butcher shops in France that I've witnessed had meat hanging out in the raw, a prospect that would most likely gross out the lunch rush crowd just looking to hit up the vendors for a middday nosh. Overall the concept is solid, and it certainly brightens up an otherwise nondescript portion of the Ogilvie transportation hub. The desserts/pastries looked absolutely delectable, and I will definitely be back next time for a pain au chocolat! 

I sampled goods from the roasted almond vendor and the raw food vendor. Of course, after tasting healthy raw food, I would decide to go for the gold and get a crepe for lunch (featuring nutella, no less) but it was GOOD and the service was friendly, despite it being lunch rush.
review.author: Shanti N.

review.description:
Love wandering the French Market on my lunch hour.
So many new stands and foods to try. Pastoral makes wonderful gourmet deli sandwiches, and there's a gem of a crepe place right in the middle of the commotion.
Also...free gelato samples!
review.author: Brett E.

review.description: French Market has improved so much since I wrote this review and deserves 5 stars!
review.author: Candance T.

review.description: Really cool place with a wide variety of very good food.  I enjoy the Mexican place, but I'm not sure you could go wrong with any of the choices.  I'll even stop in for a green smoothie just as an excuse to head down there.  Wonderful for Metra riders that arrive in Oglive and an easy walk for anyone who works in the loop.
review.author: Andy H.

review.description:
I HEART thee French Market! 

I'd say that I cook more than the average urban dweller. At least, I simply like to cook and use fresh ingredients. I find the produce prices of the French Market to be ridiculously reasonable. At the time of this review, cilantro is 50 cents per bunch, tangerines are 10 for $1, ginger is $1.99 per pound (I bought a 2 inch piece for 8 cents yesterday), et cetera. I also go to Produce Express if the lines for City Fresh is too long or they're out of certain herbs. 

Being on my way to and from school, the French Market is very convenient. If you ride the Metra, it's the perfect place to pick up snacks like fruit, chocolates and croissants and even pre-packaged meals for work. 

To be honest, I find the prices of the non-produce items to be expensive. A chocolate chip cookie, for example, was over $2. Yikes. It was at Sweet Miss Giving's, and 100% of the profits go to the Chicago House charity. Pastoral has some of the best selection of cheese (with very knowledgeable fromagers), and high prices to boot. 

It's sad that the French Market seems to be struggling. I think it's in a good location, albeit over the river from the Loop. I think it has a lot of potential in general, but the produce quality and selection here is just fantastic. I'd come here over Jewel and even Whole Foods any day for the produce.
review.author: Jade T.

review.description:
You know, I had no idea this place even existed. I go to the metra quite frequently and never knew this place was even down there. I like the idea of having a market in the train station. It's a bit expensive. Actually it's pretty expensive.

I went for an 8 course brunch to see Alpana Singh. The whole sha-bang was really neat and they served a sample from each of the markets there. I have heard of Saigon Sisters and some other stores. It's one of those places that I would go and walk around, but to really shop there is too expensive for me. You can go to Argyle and buy a Vietnamese Sandwich for half their value. Or go to a supermarket and buy produce for half their value. The other venues\markets there are more gourmet and personally owned which is why their prices are jacked up, in my opinion. I'd go back just to browse, ONLY IF i had the luxury time.
review.author: Sandra W.

review.description:
I stopped by the French Market a few months ago. It's just kind of meh food. What I'd expect to get when trapped in a foreign downtown without any idea where to go. In all fairness, I only went to the indian place so far (Clay Oven?). I was extremely underwhelmed. The food was ultra-bland, and you've failed spectacularly when you have ultra-bland indian cuisine.

The retail grocery shopping is actually pretty good, so maybe I'll get the stomach to go back and try another eatery there.
review.author: Lee R.

review.description:
My faves (in no particular order):
1. Klay Oven Kitchen
2. The French Fries place
3. Almond croissants from Vanile
4. The Montreal style smoked meat

Do your own food tour and hit all of the above. You will be very very happy.
review.author: Esther Y.

review.description: Idk why i have never been here before because this place is freaking cool. Its almost as if you walked to a open street market at a neighborhood street fair mixed with a mall food court and a grocery store all at once. A bit pricey but everything is good quality so you don't mind spending the money. It is definitely a place worth checking out!
review.author: Seria A.

review.description: What's the draw to this place? It's a tiny little corner of the train station with a french theme and overpriced shops. There are a few varieties of foods, but nothing particularly french or exciting for that matter. So, don't let the name fool you. It's an overpriced food court. I went on a Saturday and several shops were closed. I have no reason to want to go back, except if I happen to be in that train station and need a coffee or something.
review.author: Samantha G.

review.description: Nice place to meet for lunch. They have a good variety of food options. Saigon Sisters had a great Pork Banh Mi.
review.author: Cheryl D.

review.description: I just adore Chicago French Market.  What's not to love?  I really miss this as Atlanta doesn't have anything close.  It's set up as a true "market" of little stores that you can walk around, indoor, and buy fresh deli, produce, or prepared foods.  I always go to get the Banh Mi sandwiches, and have gotten macaroons a few times as gifts for friends.  Love the little produce stand and the flower shop.  Want to try the crepes sometime, and I noticed a new Indian place too.  So it's not entirely french, but cute nonetheless.  Fun to meet up with friends and wander around for a more interactive experience than just meeting up in a restaurant.
review.author: Vanitha S.

review.description: I enjoyed a perfect crêpe with smoked salmon and a coffee, listening to some good live music. Doesn't feel like Paris, but it's a sweet place anyway!
review.author: Paola C.

review.description:
I live two blocks from the French Market and I've been going there regularly since it opened. I've seen vendors come and go, and I think the market is in a really good place right now. I feel like it's "filled out" lately and feels more vibrant and inviting. I love stopping by there for lunch, coffee or a snack, or to pick up something to cook for dinner--or even to just walk through and see what's happening. The meat/seafood options I've purchased have been really good quality, and the produce has been pretty good too. 

My favorite lunch options are probably Bowl Square, Pastoral and Saigon Sisters. The Mexican place makes decent tacos and the sushi place is good too. The Raw place makes great stuff, I just can't bring myself to spend what they're asking.  Vanille makes awesome macarons and croissants. And I love Lavazza! I'm excited to try the Indian place and the new soup spot. I LOVED Sweet Miss Givings and I'm really sad they closed. I hear they have some big things in the works, so hopefully we'll see them again somewhere soon!

My main gripe is all of the disposable plastic floating around that place. I wish there was a "dine in" option with reusable dishes, and/or use of more recyclables. My only other complaint is that some of the prices are a bit steep.

As a neighbor, I do feel like it closes too early on Saturdays, and it would be nice if it were open on Sunday. But, I know Saturdays are pretty quiet there and Sundays would be too, so I guess I understand. I'm really happy the market is here and I hope it's a fixture in the neighborhood for a long time to come!
review.author: Jennifer G.

review.description: Just a note that for the parking garage, you should stop by the parking attendant's booth and get a punch card for the French Market purchases (the stores will punch the amount of your purchases), so that you can get your free parking. I don't work or live particularly close by and only went here for macarons from Vanille (apparently the only place that sells them that isn't way north!), but I somehow missed seeing the attendant booth before I parked and left for the market. Came back to find a note taped to my window to pay at the booth. Luckily, I kept my receipt and he was fine with that. Would love to stop by here again for food - everything looks delicious and it does have a quaint market feel. Beaver's Donuts is here too!
review.author: Nan S.

review.description: Great market i ate the Montreal style pastrami and that was delicious. Definitely will come again. Just be careful with the parking and validate it when you buy anything and DO NOT leave your car after 7 pm otherwise you won't get it until next day
review.author: Ameer A.

review.description: The good-Saigon Sisters, India House, Da Lobsta, Sushi, all the fruit vendors, the variety and feeling of Europe in Chicago. Nice meat and seafood to bring home for dinner.  The bad-can be really crowded at lunch, really uncomfortable seating, sometimes it is dirty, some vendors (Loop Soup) take 4ever to get your food, others (Lolli and Pop) are just plain overpriced.  The point of the market (I think) is not to have French food, but the actual feel of a French market.  Which has been achieved.
review.author: jt s.

review.description: I guess its okay if you are in the area and need some place to eat but dont go out of your way to get there, you will be pretty disappointed.
review.author: Jessica H.

review.description:
This is a fun place. As a start-up, they're doing well. As a nice addition to the area I give it four stars. But the decor could use more work. 

Lots of interesting vendors, heavy on the eat-in foods (with lots of tables), sweets, and bakeries. Good selection of produce from multiple vendors. Seafood and meat selections reflect the lack of volume to support filling the display case with product. Plenty of patrons on a Saturday afternoon. That's a good sign - they won't be totally dependent on train station commuters. But I have my doubts how well this place does over time. I hope I'm wrong. 

And beautiful fresh French macaroons. Those I haven't seen in Chicago before. If you think chocolates are expensive, wait til you try these flavorful little bites, at $1.25 a pop.
review.author: Dennis S.

review.description: The selection here is quite diverse and of decent quality, but everything is over priced.  It's fun, but honestly not really worth the value.
review.author: Kevin H.

review.description:
So my friend and I took about an hour trying to locate this place, but that hour was totally worth it. 

ABSOLUTELY LOOOOOOVEEED THE PLACE! 
It's so homey and cute! It really does remind me of France in every little way. the cheese and meat market has so many amazing choices of cheese and meat. I'm such a wine, cheese, and crackers kind of girl so this place really blew me away. All the samples were amazing, and I especially loved the macarons from Vanille! (I know that should be a separate review, but it is located in the french market!) Everyone that works there is really nice and knowledgeable. My friend and I did go near closing time on Saturday so a lot of the stores were closed already, but I would love to come back when some of the other stores are open too!
review.author: Judy B.

review.description: wonderful place! very similar to the Reading Terminal Market in Philly. A huge selection of eateries, many offering relatively fresh and healthy options, many offering rather unusual or ethnic foods you won't find easily elsewhere..
review.author: Mark N.

review.description: This place is awesome! It's probably the best food court downtown. There are so many wonderful options to choose from. And its not your typical food court places. They are high quality food shops like Pastoral and Little goat
review.author: Wayne H.

review.description:
I didn't stay long but I'm a fan simply because of all the dessert options in this small open marketplace. I'd say 75% of it is occupied by storefronts, mostly operating out of somewhere else. I enjoyed the Vanille Patisserie, the Lavazza gelato options, the Canady chocolate beauties, and the delightful pasteries array. I know there were some hearty options in there but sweet tooth I am was distracted. Easily. 

I don't think there are many "french" options in there but if you want semi-lux food product you can probably find something here. At least the sweet tooth will be satisfied.
review.author: Mary P.

review.description: Like most people that review this place you would never know its here and its right in the heart of a very busy area. I have visited the city many times and have never even heard of this place. Tons of food options crammed into one building. If your looking for a variety this place has it and not cheap gimmicky fast food but good quality and fresh made options. Definitely worth a visit.
review.author: Nick K.

review.description:
Finally a place in Chicago along the same lines as Reading Terminal in Philly!! 
By no means is that a comparison but I hope this place grows and develops more variety. 
Everything looks, smells and tastes delightful!
review.author: Ivanka B.

review.description: Excellent offerings, including fish and meat counters, gelato and cheese. However, $12.26 for a jar of coconut oil that is closer to $7 at Mariano's is an example of what make this place a difficult regular shopping destination.
review.author: Jason P.

review.description:
What a great find... I have been living in Chicago for nearly 2 and a half years and this weekend was my first venture to the Chicago French Market.  I had heard about it a few times from co-workers but never experienced it myself until now.  So much great food inside, not only produce and pastries but cheeses, meats, crepes, middle eastern food and Vietnamese food!  Saigon Sisters is amazing, try their bao combination plate (on Saturdays only) it's to die for and Flip Crepe has the best original crepe I've had in a long time.  Vanille has amazing French macaroons, supposedly on par with Laduree!  Their fish looks amazing and is pretty reasonably priced!  And even on a Saturday, when I would expect this place to be packed, it wasn't even crowded. 

Catch me there this week, picking up more macaroons and maybe another crepe ;)
review.author: Marisa S.

review.description: Not everything here is "French", but it's still a fun place to explore, especially during this crummy winter! Where else can you get macarons, Indian food, sushi and fresh produce all under one roof? My favorite part of my last visit was walking past Vanille and seeing a huge plate of pretty pink macarons with a "Free Sample" sign. They have the best macarons in the city and it's both good and bad to be so close to them now! Goodbye paycheck, hello fupa....
review.author: Bri A.

review.description: Wow life is too short not to do yourself a favor & get over the French Market. It has everything. So many incredible options!  I am a big fan of the green smoothies they're the best I've found downtown and the sushi place is generally pretty good value.  The samples alone are worth it -
review.author: Anthony A.

review.description: Even though it is a little pricey, lots of options.  It is amazing what you can find. It never gets old.  The last time I was there I got a pulled chicken sandwich on a brioche bun with spicy bbq sauce and with cheese grits with bacon on top.  Yum!!  Definitely worth the prices.
review.author: Cameron H.

review.description:
If you're spoiled by Queen Victoria Market in Melbourne, Australia and Borough Market in London, England, you will feel that Chicago's French Market does not even come close. At all. That's how I feel.

Better than no French market at all, I guess. There are two vendors worth visiting: Pastoral and another one located next to Pastoral (I forget the name). The latter has prosciutto, chicken ham, chicken head cheese, veal sausages, etc.
review.author: Teri Y.

review.description: I appreciate seeing the fine developments at this market.  In its early years, I had concerns about the limited traffic and whether it would survive. My visit last Friday lunchtime found the market busy. The addition of many new stands and the sheer variety and freshness of foods makes this a wonderful asset to the area.
review.author: Mike G.

review.description:
Woo woo!  It is open!  I felt like a a child awaiting the first trip to Marshall Fields' toy department during the Christmas season.  Yes, there are kinks to work out, but heck, it's only been open 4 hours!  

The produce is beautiful and a good value.  Picked up some Wisconsin goat cheese dusted in cocoa,which was delish with my bread, apple and coffee for brekkie when I got home.  Oh, and the baked goods...my, my.  And check out the Soap Lady to take home a sample.  

Very much looking forward to experiencing the restaurant elements.

UPDATE:  We went Saturday for "brunch", but really grazed the food stalls.   

The ban mi "the Porky" from Saigon Sisters was divine with tasty pork belly.  

The "Maple Bites" crepe from Flip was nice....would have liked a bit more in the fillings.

Lastly, the chorizo/egg tacos were just okay.....
review.author: Beth E.

review.description: Went to see Frietkoten, famous for its fries. Ordered a "small" one.. and it was more than enough for 1 person! Luckily I hadn't ordered anything else. To describe the fries in one word: geweldig! They were fantastic although a little bit overdone. I know they need to be fried twice to get the required flavor, but they were a little bit too dark. Still, they tasted great with the mayo that was served with it. You also get ketchup, but I prefer the mayo. Will eat this ANYDAY over the fries that come with Yehuda Flight from BenYehuda!
review.author: Malachi V.

review.description: A great place for a wide variety of food options. There's not a lot of seating and the prices are a tad high for lunch, but the food is so delicious that it is still worth a trip. High quality food for a short wait.
review.author: K E.

review.description: Very crowded at lunch. If you don't know what you want, it can be super overwhelming. Check it out at off-times so you can stroll instead of constantly dodging people in the aisles.
review.author: Kellie M.

review.description:
A bit sad, it's much worse that my initial experiences.  A few stores went away and produce prices increased to Whole Food levels.  After a few times I went last year, and it getting worse every time, I've not had any desire to come here again.  The decor still is a weird amalgamation of industrial with Old World (and not in a good way).

They still have the two best places I think, but its not unique enough as I like Pastoral and Vanille stores better than the ones in the FM.

I still think its a great idea, but my enthusiasm (and likewise recommendation) for FM has dropped preciously low.
review.author: Dhruv P.

review.description: I love places like this, because I have a really hard time settling on just one category of food for any given meal, and the French Market allows you to have it all! I was led here by the promise of a delicious green smoothie at Chicago Raw (DON'T MISS THIS PLACE!), and ended up wandering the aisles and stopping to check out all of the diverse genres of food- Gelato, sandwiches, coffee, fresh meat and seafood! This would be a great destination if you had a big group who couldn't bear to compromise on any one food option. So, if you're in the area and want to pick up a quick bite, definitely stop in and explore everything that the French Market has to offer!
review.author: Margaret L.

review.description:
Okee, Yelpers. C'mon. 

Not everything can live up to its name EXACTLY. Is the Chicago French Market going to magically whisk you away to gay Paree? Nope. But will give you a unique and intriguing spin on finding a quick bite in the Loop? Oui.

I'm actually surprised at the backlash here. I thought this was a great idea. It's 'French' in the way that little French markets offer a plethora of options, from a bite to eat to fresh produce to a relaxing place to kick back and sip on something bubbly. Check, check, check.

Plus, with really tasty vendors serving up above average food, what's not to like? Saigon Sisters' tangy, zippy sammies, vegan/raw bar for you crunchy folks and the Belgian style frittes and bier stand... awesome. I feel like there's a little something for everyone here, which makes it a great place for coworkers to flock to for a different type of lunch hour away from the office. 

The space itself is unique too. It's a little hard to find way down under Ogilvy station, but the adventure of seeking it out is part of the fun (and the location by the train platforms actually gives it more of that continental feel). Despite being 'underground,' the space is open, bright and cheery. 

And the little old accordion player is the coup d'gras in my book.

So overall, no, spending an hour at the Chicago French Market is not going to replace watching the sun set over the Seine, but it is something different and special--a happy departure from the usual same ol' same ol' of Loop luncheons.

C'est le Yelp.
review.author: Evan Thoreau H.

review.description:
The place where I discovered Vanille Patisseries and their awesome macaroons.  There are a good variety of shops here, from gelato to banh mi.  I also enjoyed the belgium frite shop in the back with some tasty truffle mayo.  There's a wide variety of places to check out, so get ready to eat.  I went on a weekday night and it wasn't that busy, which was nice.  Definitely a great stop, while showing guests from out of town around Chicago.

If I worked in the area, the French Market would definitely be one of my lunch choices.  It would definitely help with the lunch dilemma my coworkers and I sometimes have.  Something for everyone.  I know I'll be back for sure to get me some macaroons.
review.author: Phill C.

review.description: Definitely a ton of food at this place. I had a great time exploring. It does have a funny a name for a market with many other vendors but that's not the point. Experience here was wonderful. Everyone was really nice. Prices are not bad. Desserts were amazing. Had milk tea and they had a huge selection.
review.author: Samantha S.

review.description: Everything is expensive. I once saw a gofer fight a raccoon in here.
review.author: Ryan M.

review.description: Amazing selection of organic, fresh and ethnic food. Loved the raw food restaurant! Best raw food I've ever had! Delicious!
review.author: Julia A.

review.description: This place is fabulous! I'm vegan and my husband is not. So we both found lots of delicious options (so many to choose from) and were then able to enjoy lunch together without either one of is struggling to find something we like.
review.author: Shira C.

review.description: Love this place! First found it a few years ago and since then I have been coming here regularly. This place literally has everything one day I got BBQ, beef jerky, bought flowers, had a French sandwich and then bought a fresh cut of filet for dinner. This is a local haven and the perfect place for lunch if you work on the area.
review.author: Brandon M.

review.description:
It's nearly four years since it opened and I reviewed this place, and it has really turned itself around. The stalls are full, the food is delicious, and the place is buzzing. There are still a few sad stands that don't seem to ever have customers, but there are multiple hoppin' places. 

I highly recommend it now! Check out The Little Goat, Saigon Sisters, the frites place, Fumare, etc. Mmmm.
review.author: Michelle T.

review.description:
Disappointing as a French market, passable as a food court located in a train station. I thought I might find coffee made through a French press, no luck, perhaps a reasonable selection of pastries, an adjacent donut shop has better fare.

I suppose if you're waiting for your train and you don't mind banality, you won't notice the ennui this location exudes.
review.author: Andrew A.

review.description: Cute french market! We went here hoping for it to mirror the Chelsea Market in NYC but it was nowhere near the size or number of vendors but it was cute nonetheless! Great for grabbing a bite and a coffee in the morning :)
review.author: Rebecca M.

review.description: Hidden under the Oglivie Station metra tracks you'll find Chicago's French market.  The market is my #1 place to kill time if I miss my train and have 20-40 minutes to fill.  In the market you will find a little bit of everything. There's fresh produce, deli goods, beer, wine, artisan meats and cheeses, french pastries, cookies, cakes, vietnamese, japanese, american...so many options to choose from!  The market is more of a sight to see than a full on market/weekly shopping destination.  I'd say this is a great place to pick up a bite to eat (to stay or to go) and maybe some snacks.  There is much to see and the selection varies, if you have anywhere from 20 min to a couple of hours to kill, this is the perfect destination!
review.author: Nicole G.

review.description:
First things first: Get rid of the notion that this is a 'French' market.  It's not.

Now you can probably appreciate French Market for what it truly is: A glorified food court bringing Loopy Lunchers good food all in one location.

Now we can continue.

I rarely step out of the office for lunch (I'd rather brown bag it), but when I do, I want a goooooood lunch.  I'm so over all the places, like, right outside my office door so I took a stroll down to the French Market to see what was crackin'.

YUMMER EXPLOSION.

So many options and I love it!  Sushi over there, crepes over here.  Pastries (lemon bar, holla!), sammiches, banh mi, fresh produce, candies, hot dogs, soup, salads... really, pretty much everything is covered in this arena.  Hell, even Chicago's self-proclaimed Sandwich King (Food TV's Jeff Mauro) came here to get his eat on.  I trust it.

A rare craving for a tuna salad sandwich brought me to the Fumare Meats outpost where I indulged my gluttonous desires.  The sandwich was large and in-charge, super messy and utterly delicious.  Tuna salad can be dicey because I always fear too much mayo and an overuse of celery, but the recipe at Fumare is perfect.  The purveyor of Fumare is kind of a wacky guy that reminded me of a mad scientist.  A sammich with a side of loony.  I like it.

So basically you should come to French Market for a nice change of pace.  French?  Not so much.  Fun?  You bet!
review.author: Angie M.

review.description:
Wow.  Just wow.  This place is amazing!  Almost very type of food you can imagine from fresh fish, two cheese places, fresh vegetables, at least two bakeries, Vietnamese, Mexican, a creperie, raw food stand, Sushi and a deli that was sublime - plus others that I cannot remember.

Why oh why wasn't this place around when I worked downtown just across the street six years ago?!?!?  The prices for everything were amazing!  You can get a delicious fresh made lunch with quality ingredients for about the same price that you would pay for the substandard dreck that you would get at a fast food joint.

When we were there it was a Saturday morning just as a majority of the standswere  starting to open but we only had a banana and nutella crepe as we waited for Fumare Deli to open to try their "Montreal Smoked Pastrami" - their sign enticed us to wait.  And we are sooooo glad we did.  I have two words for it - MEAT CANDY!  OMG, I am drooling again right now thinking about it!

We will definitely be back, I just wish that it was closer to us (and that it had opened when I was still working downtown across the street)!
review.author: George H.

review.description: I finally checked out the Chicago French Market a couple of weeks ago and was very impressed with the variety and the quality of food and produce available. My husband and I spend a couple of hours and had the whole experience: tour of the market, lunch, coffee and dessert, and bought a few pastries to enjoy later at home. We are already talking about going back here for lunch soon!
review.author: Ermelinda C.

review.description:
FIRST TIMERS: COME EARLY!!!
I had about 20 minutes to spend here on my way from Union Station to the Opera and by the time I circled around 4 times trying to figure out what I will have for dinner, most of the vendors closed. I was left with choices that were less than thrilling, considering I could get them anywhere else...except for the raw food counter. I decided to take the chance...who knows when I will actually go for a raw food option when there's a lot more delicious...warm...foods to choose from, especially since I don't say no to trying new foods!!

Result: pleasantly surprised! I had one of the assortment boxes with zucchini "pasta" w/marinara, "falafels", "dumplings", and a yummy dessert. Quite filling, actually!

Real dessert: AMAZING MACAROONS in a great assortment of flavors from the pastry vendor at the entrance to the market.
review.author: Sofia J.

review.description:
MADNESS!

I made the mistake of stopping in during the lunchtime hour on opening day.  Opening day was packed with barely any room to move in between stalls with a french mime creepily hiding behind people and items, an adorable accordion player and media peoples all around!

I was glad to see the familiar places like Pastoral and Vanille and several new places!  I love the convenience factor of this location!  The fish stand people joked with passerbys to put their order in now and pick up their seafood on their way home after work!
review.author: Minna A.

review.description: Love the French Market for the variety of foods and fresh taste however, I wish they would extend their hours of business until at least 8pm. I'm always disappointed when they close at 6:30 on a weekday, leaving work at 6. The crepe station is amazing and they have the best apple cinnamon and tuna crepes. Don't miss it!
review.author: Heidi R.

review.description: I like the variety of food available. Today I tried a crepe with salmon which was very good and healthy. The downside is parking. The lot next door allows 1-hour free parking with a purchase receipt.
review.author: M S.

review.description: Love, love, LOVE! Being a recent weekday Loop immigrant I can't believe this place didn't always exist. I mean, it's always busy and is happily overwhelming with its diverse and delicious lunch options. Want Southern barbecue, Vietnamese, Indian, Korean, Cajun, French crepes, lobster rolls, artisan sandwiches, Croatian burek, Montreal smoked meat sandwiches, Belgian frites, Jewish deli fare, gourmet grilled cheese, sushi and tons more? Then come on in! There's climate-controlled seating in and outside the market so you can enjoy there or everyone will pack to take back to your office. Lots of fresh meats, seafood, fruits and veggies and very reasonable prices make this a great spot to hit before heading home to make dinner too.
review.author: Scott H.

review.description: My first time here and it's the 4th Annual Pastoral's Artisan Producer Festival. Best free event in the city and the food & drink are fantastic. No favorites!
review.author: Greg L.

review.description:
If I lived in this drab, faceless and quasi-industrial neighborhood, I would be thrilled to death to have this market close by, but as a destination, I think not. The variety of products, though not all French, takes you through pastries and actually many baked goods, French breads and cheeses, wine, a Vietnamese restaurant, and fresh produce. But the place itself has all the charm of, well. a train station. It is not located at the intersection of anything, so you don't have the excitement of crowds, people watching. The eating areas are not at all "intime" or quaint, or special like a real French Market.

Although I knew there  was no Burnham make-no-small-plans kind of inspiration found its way into this project, I had expected something more of an escape, ambiance-wise from the emptiness outside. I can't help thinking of Pike Place or Granville Market in Seattle and Vancouver, and how exciting it is to just go there and spend a few hours. I still long for that kind of real open market here in Chicago. Oh, well. Even if indoors. 

I poked around here, decided not to eat lunch in the bus station-inspired eating areas. I did spend some time at Pastoral, the cheese stop, and got some wonderful advice and a couple chunks of fromage there to take home. But I can go to their other more charming store on a quaint block of Broadway in Lakeview. Can't imagine making a trip back here unless I suffer from amnesia, and somehow wander into the area again. Or if I find myself taking Metra downtown.
review.author: Jack P.

review.description:
I don't care what anyone says, I like this place.  Really, its the best thing at the train station.  I've passed through here on my way home many times to get little treats.  

Its a nice change of pace.  Easy in, easy out.
review.author: Erin D.

review.description:
Went here today and I just might be in love. 
The fruit-very sweet and juicy!
The crepes-light and flavorful
The paradise brownie-f!@#$%^ scrumptious
The cheese and meat selection-fresh and full of flavor
I can't wait to return!!!!!!
review.author: Nicole H.

review.description: Still love this place and it is getting better. Great place to stop while in Chicago! Wide variety of food choices with vendors from some of Chicago's top restaurants. So many choices...something fro everyone. Wine, cheese, coffee, gelato, bbq, crepes, vegan fare, fruits, vegetables, soups, salads, sandwiches, sushi, pastries and much more...all under one roof!  Service was polite and friendly at every booth I visited. Went there for lunch on a Saturday afternoon and there was even a jazz musician singing in the seating area in back! What a treat! Close to the L and in Oglivie Train Station or ride a Divvy bike (Chicago's new public bike sharing system) there is a station right in front. Definitely something that you should check out for an afternoon lunch or early dinner or snack.
review.author: Donna M.

review.description:
I actually  like The food court, Our office was down the street and for years there limited choices for lunch, mostly just garbage food unless you wanted to go to a sit down restaurant. When the food court opened we finally had a lot of quality choices.
We found some of the vendors a bit clueless and the soon closed up but we also made some good friends with regular vendors, the french bakery there was one and the coffee shop Lavazza has good sandwiches ready made.

The best shop there is Pastoral of course, artisan sandwiches that are expensive but truly gourmet.   next to Pastoral there is another sandwich shop that has an authentic Montreal roast beef that is really good.
review.author: Joseph B.

review.description:
DIdn't get to go before I (finally) left Chicago. It's one of the only things I will miss. Freikoten for Belgian-style chips with curry mayo and either an Allagash White or a Two Brothers' Bitter End was the best lunch ever in that town. (Though the now-defunct "ciao bello" portabello sandwich at Pastoral and the "Montreal style" pastrami were killer. The Vietnamese was good, but some of the other booths were better.)

I guess I'll have to say that I will miss Chicago after all, dammit. Just a little. 

The guy who mentioned expecting an indoor version of Boston's Haymarket--I love the Haymarket, but I wish it had a Belgian chip shop (though, actually, there is now one around the corner--haven't been yet; am waiting for them to get a liquor license so I can get my Allagash or Ommegang or Chimay).
review.author: Matt S.

review.description: With a ton of different eateries this place had it all.  Today was Lobster BLT and chocolate macaroons. We also grabbed some beer fries.  This market has many different types of food so you are sure to find something that you like.
review.author: Brian B.

review.description:
I'm lucky enough to work in the same building as the French Market, and it is honestly the best thing to ever happen to lunch! There are so many great places to eat and over the past year I've only seen it get better and better.  You enter to a more traditional "market" setting where you can buy drinks, produce, pasties, and breads but then it opens up to at least 25 food vendors.  

Some of my personal favorites:
- Little Goat Bread: New to the French Market, this place always has a line, but it's worth every second! A satellite location for the diner on Randolph, Little Goat bread has some of the best sandwiches I've ever had.  The shrimp is by far my favorite, but the tuna is also awesome.  They add interesting twists to the sandwiches by adding ingredients like cheeze-its. Althought I've never gotten the bread, the muffin I got was out of this world.
- Soup Monkey: Grilled cheese and soup, can't go wrong.  The soups are either pre-made (like clam chowder) or make your own with tomato or veggie broth bases.  You can add cheese, pasta, rice, meat, vegetables and more.  This is the only soup place I'll actually go to on a regular basis in the entire building.  The grilled cheeses are also great-- the caprese is my go-to, but every now and then I'll get the Trust Me.  Although cheese and jam might not sound like the best combination, it's awesome! Plus the staff is great!
- Pastoral: Again, awesome sandwiches, but I go here for the cheese. Although there are other places with bigger selections, the staff here is awesome about helping you find exactly what you're looking for.  
- Sushi: I have no idea what the sushi place in the French Market is called, but it's great sushi (especially considering it's under a train station!)...but be warned, you'll be waiting a hot minute if you order your own rolls over the pre-made ones.  

Biggest piece of advice: Go early.  This place crowds up fast at lunch hour and stays crowded for awhile.
review.author: Annie M.

review.description: Great lobster rolls and clam touter soap. Many varieties of food. All nationalities   Good prices. Easy walk in downtown Chicago
review.author: Doug R.

review.description:
Cute market place, located in a metra station.  Went here for lunch the first time to sample the fare.  Here's my personal tour de French Market...

For the sandwich lovers, hands down, my favorite was the MONTREAL STYLE sandwich!! (Located next to "Pastoral Cheese".  Simple, hot sandwich.  OHHH, SOOO GOOD.  Warm, tender, chunks of PASTRAMI between 2 slices of rye bread. Eat it with a side of yellow spicy mustard. Gone in 60 seconds. ;P (not created in Montreal, btw. The chef made up the name cuz he liked it:)

Next up..Bahn sandwiches at Saigon sisters-I sampled the VBQ  & Hen House.  VBQ was featured in Chicago tribune.   i was not impressed. tasted too..americanized.  alluring me with it's waygu beef, but leaving me wanting.  The Hen House (chicken sandwich) was much better..watch out for those jalepenos though..hot stuff!

Belgian Fries-tasty! comes with a couple sauces. i ate them plain.

Vanilla patassarie- i tried four flavors (red velvet, coconut passion fruit , chocolate, vanilla mousse.)  I decided..i am NOT a macaroon person.  too sweet!!  If i had to pick one, coconut passion fruit was the best.

Now Gelato..YES, PLEASE! Check out Lavazza for dessert-Pistachio and Hazel nut ..mmmm...reminded me of Italy! 

Overall, cute atmosphere. Pricey for lunch (& groceries), but fun for quick bite or out of town guests.

Fun Fact:  The Market was Featured as one of the Top 5 things to Do in Chicago in the Tribune.
review.author: Joanne L.

review.description:
Having had the day off yesterday, I decided to check out the French Market.  Ogilvie was creepily deserted due the holiday, but the market was open.  

Walking in I got the feeling the atmosphere they were trying to capture was like the Public Market in Seattle.  Except this is in a windowless, airless space, with fluorescent lighting that was too bright, too harsh.  The dining area was sad and boring and looked like an afterthought.  The vendor stalls were nicely set up though and offered a nice selection of wares.  There was a Pastoral cheese stall, a Vanille Patisserie stall, a fruit and veggie stall, Lavazza, meat and seafood, as well as various stands where you could buy ready made food such as Mexican, Asian, baked goods...even a raw food stand!

But the very best part about this place (and the main reason I am so very, very thankful I do not commute by train) is that they have a Belgian Frites stand offering amazing dipping sauces such as truffle mayo, peanut sauce and green chile mayo. The servings are huge - I saw a girl order a small and it was enough for two people easily.  Dangerous. 

They do offer validated parking in the garage just north of the train station but I didn't know about that until I had already parked on the street.  Cute place all around, I would definitely return.
review.author: Carolynne M.

review.description:
I'm a market addict. My dream is to check out all the major markets around the world. Which is why I was overjoyed when I found out about this place, and headed over after work one day. Maybe because it was late in the evening, so there wasn't many people, and some of the food stalls are getting ready to close for the day. I thought Pastoral cheese shop looked interesting, and the seafood stall was well stocked, though I can't tell how fresh the offerings were since they were behind glass. Prices are actually a little cheaper than Wholefoods.
