Overall it reminds me of Chelsea market in NYC, not a lot of produce offerings, mostly cooked food, and not crowded enough (doesn't have the hustle and bustle of traditional markets). I wish they'd have more local produce rather than imported. The indoor setting make them a perfect substitute for farmer's markets during winter months, and would really set them apart from regular grocery stores. All in all, I think it has potential, but not quite worth a special trip yet.
P.S. There's validated garage parking next door with $20 purchase, but on Thursday night around 6p there were also plenty of street parking. Right next to the pink/green line El stop.
review.author: Jennie C.

review.description:
So I've never been to France, and I would have no idea what would exactly be considered a "French market."

But I like this place for what it is, regardless of its name. A big appeal of the FM is the atmosphere and experience--there's nothing else like it in Chicago. It makes for a great place to take visitors, or a great lunch spot when you are with a bunch of people with different kinds of cuisines in mind for lunch. 

Pastoral is a great stop for cheeses and breads. Saigon Sisters rocks in the bahn mi department. And Karyn's Raw is a great adventure for those wanting a different take on food--I'm not vegan nor do I follow the raw food trend, but it's great to try something different. There are always plenty of samples about for tastings. 

Weekday lunches can be a bit chaotic, but there is plenty of cafeteria tables to sit and eat. Or, like me, if the chaos gets to you, get it to go.
review.author: Amelia B.

review.description: I really don't like the French Market, as a European person I think it's really tacky and doesn't really have many "French" offerings. There's 2 or 3 French bakeries...and no one there speaks any kind of European language so when I order in French and you look at me like I'm crazy I have to look around and wonder where I am. There's a crepe place as well. It's a "French" market, but there's sushi, candles?? They need to rename the place the Multicultural center. It's always packed, it smells awful and after multiple trips I really don't recommend this place to anyone, it's really overpriced and a lot of the offerings simply aren't good or even European. I should also mention it's really small and really overrated.
review.author: Emy F.

review.description:
Stopped in a few weeks ago to check it out. Had heard of it and decided to check it out when I was in the area. I was expecting something like Pike Place in Seattle or an indoor version of the Haymarket in Boston. It's not either. It's basically an indoor farmers market. Seems kind of industrial in my opinion. They definitely need to spruce it up a bit.

We walked around checking out the vendors and I was pleasantly surprised at the diverse selection of goods. Pastries, fresh veg, sandwiches, fresh meats and seafoods, and cheeses. Prices seemed in line, maybe a touch high. 

It's worth checking out if you are in the area. It's a nice diversion and you have plenty of fare to choose from. Not sure I would go out of my way to go there, but if I'm near the OTC, I would go in and browse.

Cheers!
review.author: Brett C.

review.description:
What is it about this market that makes it "French"?  I saw some gelatto (not French), some Belgian chips (not French), a Mexican restaurant (not French), and a crepe stand (not Fr...erm...nevermind.)

The best thing about this market is Pastoral.  Everything else is meh.
review.author: Amy H.

review.description:
Loved my first visit to the Chicago French Market!  Each one of the vendors has something unique to offer, and everything looks and tastes delicious!  There was one vegetable vendor whose items were a little over-ripe, so I stayed away from that, but everyone else's wares were great.  

You can pick up amazing cheeses (foreign & domestic), olive oils, a variety of pastas, Italian coffee & gelato, vegetables & fruits, sausages, breads, and so many tasty chocolates & desserts, your head will spin!  There are also several options for eat-there items, including sweet or savory crepes, pizza, sandwiches, and ridiculously-good Belgian fries with dipping sauces.

I was surprised that it was as affordable as it was; granted, I decided NOT to pick up that small Apple-Rosemary jam bottled by a little old woman in Italy in her home kitchen for $15.  There were some pricey items, but most everything was not as expensive as I had anticipated. 

In general, the market is a little small, and I'd like to see it grow, to include even more vendors.  But it's a good start. 

If you're hankering for a taste of France/Europe, and like the feel of those type of markets, the Chicago French Market is the place for you!  (and me.)
review.author: Brittany L.

review.description: I really don't 'get' this place - more than half of the booths are not at all French.  Beaver's Donuts?  Lilly-Q?  The Vietnamese and "Raw" place?  Come on.  Heck, even the French leaning places aren't all that impressive.  Add in the horrendous 1990s pop-soundtrack and Sunday closures and I really can't see how this place stays afloat.
review.author: Michael U.

review.description:
I'm so annoyed with this place. 

I work right across the street and wish I could eat lunch here more often but I don't. Why? BECAUSE THERE'S NO WHERE TO SIT DURING LUNCH.  So I have to lug my food back to my office and eat at my cube. 

The really annoying part is there is PLENTY of space but management puts a sparse amount of tables and chairs in the dining area. If you're not there by 11:45am, you're screwed. 

I've sent emails to the management but they go unanswered. It's a shame for the vendors here who are trying to eek out a living. Seems several have gone out of business and management is not helping the situation. 

Unless I get there early, I refuse to go now. It's a shame because I really like some of the dining options there. 

Anyone else have this issue?
review.author: David K.

review.description: I don't see what there is to dislike about this place. It may not be a "real" French Market but it's close enough. It's actually like an indoor street market. We had a Groupon for Flip Crepes. I'd never had crepes before, but from what people told me, I wasn't sure if I'd like them. To my surprise, they were AWESOME. I ordered the turkey roma crepe melt and my boo ordered the Mumbai crepe melt. Both were delicious! We sat in the eating area, which was set up like outdoor seating, by the Belgian fries place and a mini market. I saw some people getting food from there and it smelled and looked really good! That'll be my next thing to try. Overall, everything in here looks like it's worth a try; it's a great place to come for lunch. They have everything from crepes, to desserts, to fruit, to gelato. Check it out!!
review.author: Taeler H.

review.description:
Came here on a Friday morning with the boyfriend, and we spend about three hours here!!!  I didn't expect that!

There really are a variety of vendors here, some selling some exquisite food products, many offering samples, and there will be a million things you'll want to "buy a little just to try".  Such as: Powdered cocoa goat cheese, raspberry chocolate pasta, citrus fruit pasta, gypsy bacon, the seafood they'll pack right on ice for you, asian pears, and those delicious sugar roasted pecans you get at Navy Pier.

This place is fun, it's good for little gift ideas, it's reasonably priced, it's indoors, you get parking validated if you spend over $20.  Check their website, then head out to have some fun and try some yummy items!
review.author: Chrissy N.

review.description:
I'm gonna give French Market that 5th star for good management now that it's been open for a while. Yes, it's still expensive. No, not everything is French in here. Yes, the "vegan pizza" samples at the raw store are godawful. No, it's not as good as Chelsea Market, the Ferry Building, Pike Place, or really any small-stall market in any other big city. Well, so what? It's a good start.

I am giving a "good management" star for adjustments. Most notably, signage has been improved and walkways kept clear. There was also a summertime problem with fruit flies at one of the vendors, but this has been fully resolved.
review.author: Stephen F.

review.description:
I love the selection and variety at this market. Not only is there excellent produce (at really great prices) but there are also very good food and sweets options. 
Walking around, picking up an item here and there is the best part. All of the vendors are friendly and helpful which adds to the pleasant experience of being in the market itself. 
I love picking up pastries and other baked goods to take home, and I love that most vendors are more than eager to share a sample with you. Love that!
review.author: Candyce P.

review.description: I love small business and locally grown. I love the spirit, community, and variety of the french market. I stop here on the way home almost every day and can find everything from: deserts, produce, meats, crepes, nuts, coffee, soap, fruit smoothies, fine cheeses, flowers, and ever some killer grilled cheese. I love this place and the people who make it happen.
review.author: Brian R.

review.description:
This is such a cool place- I highly recommend it for a different type of date or for people visiting!
Fumare Meats is amazing.  Their pastrami is THE BEST meat I have ever had in my life and I don't even typically like meat!  I feel like I could eat this everyday!  It is so tender and delicious- stop for a taste.
Definitely ask for some tastings because you will end up buying- this place is fun and interesting and I love how they combine a little of everything!
review.author: Jenna H.

review.description:
Little old lady walking around playing the accordion.  

Cheeses, meats, baked goods, organic produce.

The best BANH MI i've ever tasted (although it's not all traditional banh mi)

Belgian Fries!  Croque monsieurs! Crepes!  Even a very popular Taqueria!  European sandwiches!

I love this place a lot - it's such a delightful place to spend for a quick lunch on your workday, or to wile away a free afternoon.  

I only wish it were bigger and that there was more in the line of french onion soup and quiches.  More dining options please!
review.author: Melody C.

review.description:
This place is getting on my nerves.

Last Saturday I arrived at 4:15p, and I would say 80% of the vendors were shut down.  Oh, you could still find people working, but the food was either removed entirely (most noticeably, City Harvest -- all fish removed and trays cleaned) or covered up, giving the impression the vendor didn't want to sell to you.  Some were audibly counting down their drawers.

Big props to Vanille, who seemed happy to serve me.

What's the point of stating your stall closes at 5:00 or 5:30 if by four o'clock you're tired of selling to folks?
review.author: Christine S.

review.description:
Here's how to appreciate this place: get excited about the idea of a French market somehow transplanted to the heart of Chicago. Then remember it's sort of in a Metra station.

Yeah the food's great and the prices are decent, but that's not really what anyone going to a French market cares about, is it? Now the environment was the part I'm a bit underwhelmed with. Don't get me wrong, I'm not expecting hairy women and  baguettes, but I can't say I was expecting some sort of glorified food court either. That said, when you first walk in, they do a good job of giving you a half-decent market. But why did I rate this place so highly? Because it's great at what it's meant to be; a place for the hungry stranded Metra rider or time-crunched Downtowner. You'll find a wide variety or great, fresh tasting food and a clean (too clean in my opinion) location.
review.author: Blake K.

review.description:
I'm giving this three stars because I want to like this place a lot more than I actually did, and because I want to encourage people to go there so it has a chance to thrive and maybe (!) grow.

Like a lot of other people here, I've been continually bummed by our fair city's lack of a real market when everyone else seems to manage it. The French Market doesn't quite fill that need: there seems to be a heavy focus on prepared food, which is fine provided you just need a good lunch place. (Also an expensive lunch place. $7 for banh mi? I know we're downtown, but come on.) As a vegetarian, I would have a hard time assembling interesting dinner ingredients here - I'm better off at Harvestime. (Although there is a lot of amazing-looking cheese at the French Market that you can't find up in Lincoln Square.)

But, you know, the market will grow and that problem may solve itself. As long as people FIND this place. What is a French market?? I commute through Ogilvie, and I had NO idea what this was until I looked it up on Yelp. I saw all the signs hung up around Ogilvie and the West Loop, but I thought it was, you know, a French market. Where they sell French stuff. Imagine my surprise when I realized that it was Chicago's attempt at a market like the ones I enjoyed when I lived in Los Angeles and Ireland! (And then my inevitable disappointment when I actually went in and looked around.)

I can't be the only one with this problem. There are so many people in that area, and when I visited - around 4:30 p.m. on a weekday, when Ogilvie is packed full of commuters - the place was totally deserted. That, combined with a bunch of empty stalls, made for a sort of depressing experience. Again, I would love to see the market succeed, and maybe it just needs more time. I hope so, because Chicago could use a place like this.

I'm keeping my fingers crossed for you, French Market, but I am not getting my hopes up.
review.author: Amanda C.

review.description:
What's with the bad press?  I think it's another case of Chicagoans' (and their suburban counterparts') overly-catered-to unreasonable expectations.  Might the "French Market" be a misnomer?  

Well, I'm not French, and I've spent about all of three days of my life in Paris, but to me it really DOES resemble a European market inside of a transportation hub. (Speaking of transportation hub, heck you Ogilvie riders have it made! That's like the glitziest, most gleaming public transit space in Chicago. Union Station is like a McDonald's rest stop by comparison.) So why wouldn't all those North Shore folks wet their panties when they heard about this new market offering organic produce, artisan cheeses, freshly baked breads and pastries?  

It's just not enough.  It's not an effing supermarket where you can get all your Target brand, jumbo-sized, 24 packs of zero calorie, flavored-water-needs met.  Riiiiight.  That's because it's a FRENCH market.  You pick up the stuff you need for tonight's dinner, not for little Madison's Jonas Brothers themed birthday party next month.  

The food I tasted was solid.  For $6 the green rice bowl at the Korean stand was scrumptious.  Not $36 scrumptious.  But delightfully $6 worth of satisfaction.  Crepes, Pastoral cheese and meats, fresh squeezed fruit juices, gelato.  I beg to differ with some of you yelpers; it's a large selection, in maybe not the most elegantly lit showcase.

The best part-- the fresh fruits and vegetables are actually cheap!  Yes!  (Although cheaper than Jewel, Dominick's, and Whole Foods isn't surprising.)   Huge, bright red tomatoes under $1 a pound.  Avocados 2 for $1.  Fresh, juicy Sunkist oranges for I dunno but cheap 'cuz all that was about $5-6.  Oh, and the fresh loaves of artisan breads-- buy 1 get 1 free at the end of the evening.  

Enough food for one (self-righteous) American.
review.author: Amy G.

review.description:
We stopped in here Friday night to pick up some fresh shrimp to add to our pasta for the evening. The shrimp were a very nice size and a pound was more than enough between the two of us. They were already cleaned, peeled and de-veined, which was nice. After being cooked (perfectly let me add), they were just as fresh and succulent. We referred to "those shrimps" for the rest of the weekend. DELISH! 

This market is a great spot in the west loop if you live close by. They had fresh produce, some food stands and a Gelato stand!
review.author: Kori E.

review.description:
After a long work stint in Philadelphia almost two years ago, I envied Philadelphians (?) for having a place like Reading Market. It was a huge indoor farmers market with a ton of vendors that I didn't know what to do with myself. Naturally, I was a wee bit excited to hear something similar was opening up in Chicago.

The market is located in a part of Olgivie Train Station I didn't know existed until now. Uh, I'm not much of a train rider. I got a bit turned around (don't ask, but thanks Yelp map for getting me back on path). Anyway, the place wasn't as big as I thought it would be but has enough to see and eat. 

My first stop was City Fresh where I got some vegetables and steak with chimchurri sauce for dinner. It had a great selection of produce, meats, and seafood. I'm not much a cheese person but the vendor across from City Fresh had plenty of it, which my dad would probably enjoy. Then came desserts. There's much to choose from. I read previously that Sweet Miss Givings is the place for red velvet cupcakes. Unfortunately, they didn't have any at the time, but I chose a brownie (still to be consumed) and a mocha from Lavazza for the road. The dining area is a little small. Luckily, it wasn't crowded. I snagged a table to munch on my chicken tostada from Buen Appetito Taqueria before I left. 

I believe the Market added a couple of new vendors recently, and I hope to make many more trips back to see how (and if) big this gets. That and the chimchurri steaks were very well received. Heh. Now where's my brownie...
review.author: Mickey A.

review.description: I love the atmosphere here! Lots of different vendors (crepes, vietnamese, korean, produce, meat, bakeries,etc), good music (there was a live performer on Saturday), and fake French street signs. I've yet to be impressed with anything I've eaten at the bakeries (Delightful bakery and one more, I forget the name). I want to try the Banh Mi and the crepes there next time. The boba tea was pretty good. Pastoral has a corner there, enough said. : ) Their cheeses and sandwiches make me happy. It's on the expensive side, but it's a nice place to spend 1-2 hours, especially in the winter.
review.author: Sneha P.

review.description: Went Saturday for Bastille Day so parking was not an issue. Definitely not a "French" market but more like a smaller version of the Reading Market in Philadelphia. They have a variety of food options like picking up an incredible sour dough loaf from Little Goat, Montreal pastrami (OMG), Beaver's fried doughnuts covered in Nutella, pulled pork at Lillie Q's, and some Lavazza espresso. Definitely, I would go back if I'm in the area.
review.author: Laura M.

review.description:
Summary: Fun selection of small shops.

Came by on a weekday afternoon. Fun selection of small shops (patisserie, cheese, bakery, grocery, meats, vegan, raw), but the atmosphere seemed a bit dreary. Maybe because there were a few empty stalls or not many customers at the time. 

Cool idea though, and convenient location.
review.author: Gary Y.

review.description: what a gem!  if i worked in the city and went home to a fam in the burbs i would buy dinner here every night instead of going to the grocery store.  I went with friends before the Opera on a Friday night and it was perfect.  Crepes from Flip Crepes and walking around looking at all the different options was the perfect start to the night.  Easy going, not crowded, good/ interesting selection.  I wish i were cool enough to like make this a regular thing,which i know i won't,  but i'll definitely make it a stop if i am down at Union Station for some reason..
review.author: Judith N.

review.description: Why all the bad reviews? I thought this place was wonderful!!! Everything was fresh and organic. The market area was very clean. There was plentiful open seating for the public and the tables and chairs were all very clean as well! The was a good assortment of different food, cuisine, and other items in the market.  They have cheese, wine, a florist, baked goods, chocolate/desserts, clothes, bags, organic food, raw food, crepes, as well as different cuisines (Korean, Thai, Vietnamese, French, Belgian). Prices are very reasonable and the market is easily accessible by the CTA (Green line).  I tried Raw, Saigon Sisters, and Flip Crepes. Everything was so yummie! I will definitely be back to pick up some more food to take home.
review.author: Janet E.

review.description:
The Chicago French Market is a great place for a foodie like myself.  I savored cheeses, vietnamese soup and sandwich and cured meats.

I didn't stop there. Dessert was tiramisu, cookies and macaroons.

It's pretty pricey, but remember that you're paying for the convenience of a one-stop-shop.

Oui Oui!  I'll be back.
review.author: Annie K.

review.description:
LOVE this place! I didn't even know it existed until recently. My mom, sister and I visited one Saturday and happened to be there when they had a tasting fair occurring. 

This is truly a wonderful Chicago attraction-though it can be a bit hard to find. We took the train to the city, then when getting off the train, we turned around and walked towards the tracks. It may seem like you're heading nowhere, but a staircase appears in the middle and will lead you underground. 

The Chicago Market is full of great vendors- fresh pasta made to order, organic produce, a patisserie, gelato and coffee, crepes, a florist, chocolatier, Korean, Belgium fries with truffle mayo, raw food, and more. 

This is a great place to come do a bit of grocery shopping (if you live in the city), or grab lunch. We enjoyed lunch from Saigon Sisters- I had a lemongrass chicken banh mi which was delicious. My mom and sister both had rice bowls. 

I can't wait to go back and try other places.
review.author: Ms G.

review.description:
Last month we were in the midst of New York's Chelsea Market and I lamented "Why doesn't Chicago have a market like this?"  or Zabar's for that matter.  Little did I know that French Market has been opened since December!!!  December?!  We made our first sampling of their goods from Pastoral Cheese which we brought to the Ferris Bueller movie showing.  Yummy.  A mushroom brie and chevre with whole wheat sourdough?  Yes please!

This morning we took the morning to explore the whole market.  Yes, everything is new and sparse.  Yes, some of the items are a bit heavy on the pocket.  Yes, it won't compare to Chelsea or London but to have a French style market(which for the lady who reviewed and didn't understand why there wasn't more French foor there.)where instead of the superboxes that carry everything you encounter different vendors that specialize in their particular wares i.e. cheese, meat, flowers, pasta, etc.  We walked in around 11am and there were a few people milling around but the market was far from crowded.  As we sat and ate the area seemed to have all woken up and walked over.  

Here is where we visited today - 

Saigon Sisters - I have to give it to these ladies(and gentleman) but their $8 Frenchman sandwich with mustard seeds, duck,  candied kumquat and jalepeno.  I am not a sandwich girl but this concoction may change my mind.  By far Saigon Sisters and the Pastoral Cheese counter seemed to be the busiest locations.  Look for their restaurant opening soon on Lake.

Fasta Pasta - How can you go wrong with Portabello mushroom ravioli with a vodka cream sauce?  Just on price. ;)  Premiums items pumped this dish up to $11!!  Good? Yes.  But a pricey lunch item for sure.

Juice Bar - A standard strawberry banana smoothie.  All fruit.  Good price but Jamba Juice on Halsted still has my dollar.

Lavarro - Finally gelato for dessert.  They have a nice coffee bar inside Ogilvie.  The hazelnut and limon were generous portions and more than enough to satisfy my palate.

Papardelle's Pasta - what an array of fresh pasta!  I am so excited to try their different mixes of orzo.  Today we got porcini mushroom linguini with marsala cream sauce with champagne mushrooms.  Very excited to try these and the vendor had nothing but praise for the sauce.

City Fresh Market - has the primo location into the train station and takes up a large portion of the entire market.  They have a large offering of produce, meat, fish and pre-made selections.  Asian noodles for me as well as varied fruit and veggies ran me a measly $7!!  Who has nectarines the size of your fist for 99 cents a pound anymore?  

All together one of my new favorite spots.  20 bucks spent on lunch there and another 20 to make dinner tonight.  There is still a lot of room for retail and restaurants galore.  I hope that it will continue to thrive and grow.  Definitely a good spot to browse on a rainy day like today!
review.author: Laura L.

review.description:
They continue to add stores so if you went there right when they first opened, give it another go. I think once the rest of the plans for that area come to fruition it's going to be awesome! 

You can get everything from fresh produce, to fresh flowers, wine, cheese, coffee, desserts, lunch and a ton more. 

My two reccomendations are Papardelle's pasta. They have a billion dried, flavorerd pastas. I bought the lemon-garlic fetuccini and cooked it up that night. The lemon flavor really came though! I cant wait to make the whole wheat toasted onion papardelle pasta. My other favorite was Gramp's Pickles. Free samples-a-plenty! Try the horsradish pickles. They're like nothing you've ever tried...probably...but what do I know about what you've tried. I havent made it yet but it was suggested that I use the juice to make bloody marys. In fact, the juice for bloody marys is soooo popular that they sell jars of juice only. How about that?
review.author: Kymberly J.

review.description:
This may be mildly exciting for the city considering we don't really have any great markets all year round. However, for anyone who has been to any kind of market in Europe, you will be disappointed. None of that market atmosphere is here. Shame on you for calling it "French". 

Now that the "hype" has fizzled (that was quick?), this place was totally empty when we visited. The stands are a little sad looking - almost like the goods are there to be on display, not actually purchased by customers. 

CFM is also extremely difficult to find. We looked all over Ogilvie for ways to get there and only when we were walking on the platforms where you board the trains did we see the signs that lead you down the stairs. 

The only redeeming thing about this place is the big Pastoral corner. Meats and cheeses? Yes please!
review.author: Yanyao N.

review.description:
This is the best idea that public transportation in Chicago has had in decades, I am convinced of this.  When you go to the Ogilvie station for a Metra ride, you can now head downstairs (by the trains, not the food court area) and be treated to very high-quality produce, meats, patries, wines, cheeses, nuts...you name it.  I particularly like the frites place with genuine Belgian style French fries.

I like this place so much that I am concerned about their really poor marketing and advertising.  I'm worried they will close if they don't get enough business.  What they need is sampling stations where vendors can let people in the station try the products and then provide CLEAR directions for where the French Market is located.  The signs they have now are almost invisible.  They also need PHOTO boards showing people what's down there.  C'mon...it ain't that hard.
review.author: Adam C.

review.description:
*****Warning: this review requires an effort on your part.
DO NOT read if you are mentally exhausted.*****

So. 
Imagine a nice, wonderful, yummy cheesy/chocolate-y/X-y souffle sitting in the oven. It smells wonderful, looks wonderful through the glass door, you have been working at it for a while, whipping the egg whites, folding them lovingly in the batter, anticipating the magic in your mouth.
And then - it falls.

It's exactly how I felt walking through the so-called French Market yesterday. I appreciate the effort, but the execution leaves a lot to be desired.
The space is unattractive and lacks definition, there are 6 bakeries/pastry shops, the butcher stall is a joke as well as the fish one...
BUT Pastoral is the saving grace. Wonderful storefront, neat and professional, worthy of all the covered markets I visited in the past.

Severe review, I know - but sometimes you need to be stern to see improvement. That's the French way, talk about it to school kids and you'll see.
Grow and rise, French Market souffle!! I am waiting for you.
review.author: Aurore L.

review.description:
Very interesting little marketplace. They have quite a selection of food/produce/etc. here and is quite a convenient shopping locale for us as we live in the area. It's conveniently located inside the Metra Station so I can imagine it gets alot of traffic during commuting hours.

We usually frequent this place on weekends to pick up fresh produce and also to hit up some of the vendors such as Flip Crepe and Pastorals. There are many other vendors in this little market that make it a worthwhile trip so all in all whatever you're in the mood for, anything from asian-sandwiches-crepe-pasta-pastries-healthy cuisin (RAW), this place has it for you.
review.author: Tom X.

review.description:
While the open-air smells more of city and train fuel mixed with baked goods, and the light comes from bright overhead lights, you get a sense of what this market is trying to be.  

Just opening today, the market was bustling with morning commuters as I did a walk-through on my way to work. There's such a variety of stands and I love that most are local vendors.   Shop local when you can!  

I stopped by one of the bakery stands and am now enjoying a locally baked Danish.  I spied some fantastic looking zucchini breads and other goodies in their case for future visits.

With its location in Ogilvie station, it couldn't get more convenient for stops before or after work!  Need some sushi grade tuna, cheese, and some fresh fruit?  It's all there.

Go now, go over lunch, go after work, or go on the weekend.  Just go.  Since it's year-round, there's no rain or snow to ruin your experience.  Allons-y!!
review.author: KELLIE K.

review.description:
I don't know how French this market is, but I really really enjoyed stumbling upon this place by accident, and would make my way up here again. 

They pack so many interesting and lovely vendors into one space that it really makes for a fun and taste bud teasing experience. I was really glad to see Canaday Le Choctier was here! Pastoral which offered samples of their cheese fudge, which was like eating a piece of cheesecake. A really awesome artisan bread shop. A bakery or three, and slew of lunch spots. I really like it because a few of the vendors would otherwise be a huge hassle to get to, me being a south side person and all. Vanille for example, now doesn't require me taking four hours out of my day to pick up something sweet, instead I could take the half hour or so trip here! 

Nice place, I really don't understand all the backlash. I think it should be appreciated for what it is.
review.author: Charlotte O.

review.description:
Not bad. I wish Chicago had a large fresh food market like other big cities. San Francisco, Seattle, Vancouver... 

I said "wish" cuz this place aint it. The vendors they do have look ok but there aren't many of them. You can literally walk the entire place in about 5 minutes.
review.author: Daniel L.

review.description:
Good to see they've figured out how to use this space.  Decent selection of food.  But nothing really special.  I guess if I live near here it can serve as a "market" but with the prices they charge for food, I can't imagine it being an option for most people.

Food is mediocre at best but the prices are outrageous. Perhaps the rent is really high for such a tiny space.  I've already seen vendors close shop.  Not a good sign.
review.author: Sam Y.

review.description:
Wow, I walked into heaven........a heaven full of fruits and vegetables out of season and still ripe, pastries, and wow its even raining crepes! 

There is so much to choose from its smaller than I thought but it made up for it with quality. I was surprised they had so many free samples. I mean fresh hot apple cider donut samples right next to raw foods brownie and hummus samples....truly heaven..... 

It was not packed at all. I would recommend a Saturday when that part of the loop is dead. We ate crepes and my partner had the strawberry cream cheese crepe and I broke the traditional mode and got a crepe hot dog that was giant! Everyone was friendly and there was a good amount of variety. A great addition to the loop.
review.author: Lindsay R.

review.description:
Talk about sensory overload when you want a quick bite to eat.  Everything looks and sounds so wonderful!

We decided on frites at Frietkoten with curry mayo and some ketchup to just have something 'normal'.  They were wonderful!  Though they took forever to come out of the fryer.  They had four fryers and each one holds an order?  Seemed odd, thought perhaps it's different during the rush periods.  

The produce was a bit scarce, but hey, it *is* January.  Some things aren't meant to grow right now.  Pastoral as always looked busy, so I'll stick to the Lakeview one by me with the tinier time.  The raw bar looked scrumptious and the Saigon Sisters had some awesome sounding sandwiches.  

All-in-all I think it's off to a fantastic start!  The butcher could use some work instead of being mainly deli meats.  I mean, if the tiny Andersonville market can have several meat choices on hand, I think this big one could do so as well.  I wanted some cornmeal and saw none which was sad.  LOTS of bakeries which don't raise the score any for me.

Most places take credit cards, and if they don't the front entrance has one for you!  It's out of my way to get here, so I don't know how frequent I'll come in, but I think that for starting out, this place looks GOOD and my pocketbook will be thankful I never come around this area too often because those Wisconsin cheeses looked goooood!
review.author: Lindsay S.

review.description:
Love going here. Go about once a month.

I'm sure you'll read in all other reviews, either go to Saigon Sisters or Pastoral. I tried the Korean guy's food once and wasn't that pleased.

The Belgian fries were really great though. 

I usually buy some veggies to take home as well.
review.author: Jared J.

review.description:
This place is honestly quite kick ass. The variety of food is only matched by the hilarity of how the people dress inside. I mean people dressing like a mime? lol.

Meanwhile, I had excellent mexican food at the french market. Yes, Juan made me excellent Quesadillas. 

The macaroons are amazing. Imagine being a diabetic, taking a bite, loving it, and entering a coma. Would it be worth it? That's debatable. Meanwhile, they're pretty darn good. Did I add they aren't actually Macaroons in the Jewish sense? These are Parisian Macaroons. There was a place called Delightful Pastries, and they deserve a major shout out for awesome food at substantially discounted prices. They had some kind of Spanikoptika equivalent with a pretzel dough.

I think this market is so huge that each store kinda deserves it's own yelp reviews. Even if not, this French Market is an absolute go to for anyone who says "I don't know what kind of food I'm in the mood for" because there's a pretty good chance you can cover whatever you decide in the French Market.
review.author: Matt R.

review.description: Where else can you go and walk around in A/C while getting to choose from SO many yummy options.  Who doesn't like options, right?! 't you want a create your own pasta/sauce?  Do you want a yummy dessert? Do you want a raw/vegan meal?  Do you want fresh juice?  Do you want some mouth-watering meat?  Do you want fresh meat/seafood?  Do you want some jerky?  Do you want sushi?  How about a salad? YES, they have all this and more.  I literally use the place like a buffet.  I walk around and order a little from each place.  I leave a happy and fat man every time.
review.author: Josh G.

review.description: Nice little market, great smells and options for cooking and quick dining alike.  Smaller than I though it would be, but that didn't detract from the overall experience.  Would definitely go there more often if I lived downtown!
review.author: Chris G.

review.description:
I've had the bahn mi, the belgian frites, the gelato... all pretty average, they also had failed to hire someone to change the trash on my last visit.

But I desperately want you to not just survive, but THRIVE FRENCH MARKET!  There is some promise under your florescent lights and within your gaping unsold blocks. 

From now on I'm sticking w/ the groceries and staying away from the prepared foods.  I've had my eye on the meat counter, good looking short ribs and chorizo sausages steps above the local Dominick's and Jewel.  

Pastoral is always a win, the baked goods/desserts options look amazing and the produce prices are seriously competitive, and convenient!  

I'm going to support you French Market, because you need it.  But if you cross me...
review.author: Angela J.

review.description:
Very nice little market. Food was
fresh and delicious. Tried City Fresh seafood and burekas which is highly recommended. Also enjoyed Indian take out.
review.author: Tania B.

review.description:
LOVE IT! 
As a visitor to the Chicago Area, it was a great place to stroll around and taste a variety of different types of food. I picked up a few items from different vendors and shared them with my friends. We loved RAW and the Saigon Sisters.
review.author: Maria C.

review.description: I finally made it here! We stopped by late on a Saturday afternoon. Loved the concept.  Many great food finds: pastrami from Fumare meats, Belgium fries, macaroons, grilled cheese, goat cheese from pastoral to name a few.  This is a great spot to pick up a sandwich for a picnic or outing on the lakefront. I'll be sure to return again!
review.author: Janet K.

review.description:
Any number of not-so-major cities seem perfectly capable of sustaining a meaningful food market: Milwaukee has a cute one; Cleveland's is even better; Vancouver has the best one on the continent. But Chicago? We just don't get it ...at least so far. 

Whatever high hopes are contained in the concept of a downtown market are quickly flailed by the atmosphere: fluorescent, quiet, lifeless--more loft space than gathering space. What sounds tasty on paper is vanille in execution: Whole Foods without, you know, people. This place seriously needs a spark--let's hope growing season brings a farmer's market into the space. Anything, please.

This is not to say the offerings are in anyway subpar, for Saigon Sisters is turning out a nice, slightly upscale pork belly banh mi, and Pastoral has good salumi and cheese on offer; Lavazza ensures a decent cup of coffee and gelato can be had. But you expect something special at this price, and yet CFM has no sense of place or reason for being; it is quite disconnected from the neighborhood--of which I'm a resident--and offers no compelling reason to become a regular (which is what they'll need to make it). It's telling that the Market has gotten very little press since opening.

Yes, it needs some time. But I'm still skeptical.
review.author: Brad C.

review.description:
Note, I've never been to France, so I have no basis of comparison. I'm the dope who had to look up how to say "I love you" in Fronch on Google for a past review.  I'm also the dope who gets a kick out of pronouncing and spelling the word "French" as "Fronch".  Just had to throw that disclaimer out there.

Anyhow, I went to the Chciago Fronch Market to meet my friend Jared who was hanging out there allowing friends to trickle in and out throughout the day and wish him well before he left to teach in Saudi Arabia.  It was actually an ideal location for something like this because he could hang out in the cafe and read while he waited for people, but once someone showed up for a bit, we could walk around and look at things.  

So when I got there, we made a few laps around the place before I decided to start shopping for food. I enjoyed a few phenomenally delicious chocolates from the chocolatier, then got to finding dinner food.  I was very impressed by the pasta stand there with all the flavored dried pasta, and left with both red onion and basil infused pastas.  Then moseyed over to Pastoral where I found some old-styled craft beer (note: do not confuse with Old Style, not the same thing) where they use spices instead of hops, and some crusty bread.  The bread was a bit too stale but that was my only beef.

I also got some fresh veggies over at the produce stand and then just bounced around with my bud for awhile before saying goodbye.

The resulting meal, while a bit expensive in its entirety, was incredibly delicious and I was very fond of the beer.  While there may be some Fronchier Fronch markets out there (probably in France, I'm guessing with my super genius skills), I had a good time at this one.
review.author: Emily C.

review.description:
I received email about its opening before it did, so I was looking forward to it. I work 2 blocks away at night and desperately needed something different for dinner.

Love the vendors, all of you!!!

Now that I've got everyone at work going sometime during the week, all the prices have started to go up????

The bread is $2 more than two weeks ago, the soup and sandwich is $2 more than two weeks ago, the apples from the guy at the end near Canal are 50 cents a pound more than a week ago. The jar of beets was $8.00????

WTF?
review.author: Milo M.

review.description:
My Mom and I came here because she was visiting and had read about it prior to her visit.  Since it's kind of off the beaten path we decided to drive and park in the garage.  The garage is very dark and you park yourself.  The attendant insisted that I give him my keys even though I was in a parking spot and the garage wasn't full.  That made me a little nervous.

If you're looking for lavish pastries you're in the right place.  Being that we're both on diets we passed on those.  There's several booths which include fresh fruit and vegetables, ready made food, cheeses, pastas, sushi, gelato, and a GORGEOUS meat counter.  The prices on the meats and fish seemed really reasonable and I would definitely go back for that.  There's only a few places in the city that you can buy live lobster and The French Market is one of them.  You have to spend $20 to get free parking and since all I bought was a small coconut gelato (heavenly by the way) we had to pay $14 for the half hour we were in there.  The French Market is definitely something to check out but if you drive go wanting to spend $20.
review.author: Kelli B.

review.description: After coming back from Paris recently, I was curious to visit the new Chicago French Market, apparently connected to the north end of Ogilvie Station. I guess it was somewhat dead when we stopped by for a quick bite after work, but it appears to be a work in progress. The mural of the Eiffel Tower at the seating area is a fun touch, and it is good to see a variety of semi-upscale food vendors that is a step up from the train station food courts nearby. We tried out the spinach and feta burek and the liquid yogurt from CityFresh Market. The burek was not bad, but perhaps it was an end-of the day burek and was not as flaky as it could have been. Still, I look forward to a return visit to check out some of the other vendors.
review.author: Bill M.

review.description:
Went to the French Market to figure out what the hype is all about! When you have those days when you're not super hungry but still have to eat coz we love eating and your taste buds cant decide - French Market is your cure. Options and we all love them. From Italian to Belgian - they've got you covered. Its a fun experience to walk through the market, pick a few items to taste and do your groceries all at once. 

We tried the veggie Vietnamese sandwiches at Saigon Sisters. I can't say I loved it but I'd go back for more. Fixed our sweet tooth from the Italian gelato place. 

There is something for everyone! Its a great place for an indoor picnic during the cold wintery days in Chicago :-)
review.author: Asha V.

review.description:
DANISH BACON. That is all I need to say. 

Seriously, though, while people complain that French Market may not be as sophisticated, cheap, or full of variety as other, more established farmer's markets around the country or even the world, it's trying and it's only the opening week.

I stayed away from the more upscale bakeries (ahem, Vanilla Patisserie, anyone?), and got a honeydew for $2 (in the winter!). A bag of fingerling potatoes for $3. $7 for a pound of giant, domestic shrimp, which the fishmonger packed in ice for my bike ride home. Some of the scallops were literally the size of my fists. And I found POLE BEANS, which I love love LOVE and haven't been able to find around my neighborhood. 

I do hope that as they work out the kinks, we'll get more variety and maybe more vendors, but for now, I will happily return for my Danish bacon from Fumare and other grocery needs.
review.author: Kai Z.

review.description: Everything here is priced at a 40% premium, but where else can you get a bag of smoked meat, sushi, cupcake, burrito, crepe, slab of salmon, alfagado and block of stinky cheese all in one lunch break?
review.author: Ray S.

review.description:
The French Market is a great addition to the West Loop/Fulton Market neighborhood! We're spoiled by having two very new, big box grocery stores right near by (Dominicks on Halsted, Jewel on Desplaines)...and the French Market is the perfect cherry on top to find those great extras that make meals a little more special. 

They have a great assortment of stands, and I've been particularly impressed with their cheese and bakery selections. We sometimes have a little wine and cheese before dinner, and every cheese we've selected has been high quality and well-paired (thanks to the great recommendations of the vendor).

The bakery is always fresh, and they have some great desserts, perfect to bring along with as a party-gift for the hostess. I've bought a boston creme pie, a kringle and kolacky cookies (cheese and raspberry) and all have been delicious.

I have only bought protein from them once, and it was good but definitely more on the expensive side. I've also had a mixed experience with the fruit, some of which has been overripe. But as I said, for most things I depend on the other big grocery stores, and this is more of a place to swing by for your specialty items. And you can stop at Lavazza (yummmmm) and get a coffee before perusing the market!

Chicago French Market is a great speciality market, and it's especially convinient if you live in the West Loop.
review.author: Gwen P.

review.description:
It's not exclusively, or even primarily, a "French" market, if you look at what type of businesses are there. Other notable ethnicities represented are Indian, Vietnamese, and Italian. The aromas that you will notice in the air are cilantro and curry. Is this fact like a commentary on globalization? 

There is a large seating area which has a panoramic painting covering the entire walls, which is a simulation of being inside a mezzanine level of the Eiffel Tower. In the background they play a mix of French pop and classic cabaret chanteuse songs on the sound system. 

At noon on a Saturday it was not very crowded, just about the right number of people to make it seem lively, but not crowded and didn't have to wait long for anything. 

The "Belgian Fries" at Frietkoten are basically what we would call "French fries", but they were pretty good, and they have a wide variety of dipping sauces that you can get with them. Tomato Basil Soup at Chicago Organics was not good, tasted canned and can't recommend that particular meal. 

"RAW", adjacent to the public space on the right, is fantastic, it is the new venture of one of the nation's leading raw-food chefs, and they frequently are offering free samples of their raw-vegan creations. 

"Pastoral" is a cheese, bread, and wine shop which is probably the most-French themed of any of the businesses, and does have an excellent selection.  There is a creperie, and there are several pastry / bake shops which have, among other things, some pretty good renditions of well-known French pastries. 

In summary, it does not remind me of my travels to France, and the true francophile will be disappointed on that count. But it is a nice new place, and it's amazing that this is located in the Metra station. If you are going through that station anyway then of course you should go into the Market.
review.author: Andrew K.

review.description:
I thought the market was small, with lots of options, even though some are not French. We came after drooling over pictures of pastries by Vanille Patisserie. The market was clean and in a convenient location, between the highway and near all public transportation stops. We had a the duck confit sandwich from Pastoral and the curry beef and vegetarian samosa (clearly not French related) from Chundy's Bistro. All items were fresh and delicious. I just wish my stomach was bigger. We also purchase 2 pastries from Vanille patisserie, and they were absolutely divine. Will go to back from fresh, organic food selections.
p.s. The garage is North of the market on Clinton, and it only requires $20 combination from vendors for 1 hour (it is quite easy to spend that much quickly here). Otherwise, street parking is $2.50 per hour and quite easy to find.
review.author: Char Y.

review.description:
I was really excited when I heard that the Chicago French Market was opening. I was like, finally, Chicago is going to have a proper year round public market. The thought of farmers/vendors selling varieties of fruits and vegetables, meats with so many different cuts you can hardly choose, and fresh fish from actual fish tanks, kept me waiting with much anticipation.

Then came the opening weekend. I couldn't believe what I walked into. "That's it?" I said to my mom. It's a tiny area, probably a third of the size of a regular grocery store like Jewel or Dominick's with a lower ceiling and narrow aisles. We walked past a bakery near the entrance selling unimpressive pastries. I was really hoping for a proper bakery selling bread, baguettes, croissants, or boules so fresh that I would walk 8 blocks every morning, even in the bitter cold, for breakfast. Nope, that's not gonna happen.

The next crucial staple of a good grocery store - a fish monger. While they look fresh, the seafood is expensive and I could pretty much get those anywhere in the city. There goes my hope for buying the catch of the day like many real fishmongers would offer. Chinatown can do better. At least they have seafood so fresh, they are swimming in a fish tank.

OK, fine. Maybe the butcher could offer something better. They are in fact run by the same folks who sell the seafood. I was sorta expecting a big block of meat that is cut-to-order, you know, like what you would see in a proper butcher store like Gepperth's in Lincoln Park. But no, they are pre-packed like Jewel's for your convenience.

Oh, and the vegetables, they look wilted and dry. Fresh fruits and vegetables are quintessential items in a market. If they can't get that right, why am I even going there? Certainly, not for pho or Lavazza coffee.

So basically it's a big disappointment. We should probably get Green City Market their own market building.
review.author: Kwoky L.

review.description:
This is a great addition to the neighborhood.  I love that you can get fresh produce, chocolate croissants, fresh tacos, some crepes, fresh fish, gourmet sandwiches, and local clothing all under the same roof!

It is a bit overwhelming on the first go around. Lots to take in and lots of food choices.  I live in the hood so I know I will be frequenting this place and it will become a little less daunting.  

It is so nice to be able to get fresh local produce in the winter.  The food was really fresh and delicious and the prices were not outrageous.  

Looks like the surrounding business appreciate a new place to grab a bite for lunch.  It was really busy at noon.

The clothing is all locally made by local artists.  They have a great selection of tees, soaps, and other hand-made items.

Definitely a wonderful addition to the neighborhood and the city for that matter.  It does remind me of a European market where you can get lunch while picking up fresh groceries.  

Check it out!
review.author: Cat B.

review.description:
The other reviews are very accurate regarding the size, selection, and price of vendors in the Market.  They definitely could have done better.  So I'll avoid piling on and instead focus on Frietkoten-- the Belgian frite stand.

I've walked around the French Market several times since it's opened, hoping to pick up some frites for the train ride home.  Frietkoten seemed to be one of the most publicized features in the articles I read about the Market.  However, the space reserved for it was always completely empty, as if it could be months before we'd see it open.  I stopped by on New Year's Eve, and I was excited to see that it was open.

The basic menu is very simple: regular and large.  There are also a variety of toppings (spicy, mayo, ketchup, etc), but I opted for the "standard" order to see how it would compare to street vendors in Brussels.  After a decent wait -- it appears that all batches were made to order, nothing was sitting under a heat lamp -- they slapped on some ketchup, mayonnaise, and chopped purple onions.  My initial thought was that their "standard" frites should be served with mayo only, but the ketchup and onions weren't bad either.  The frites were perfectly crispy and served in a paper cone with small wooden forks.  I'll definitely return again, but I will opt for mayo only or 'spicy' next time.

They weren't serving beer yet, but they had two taps set up.  Apparently, they will be offering some Goose Island draft selections including Matilda.  Additionally, "many" varieties of Belgian bottles will round out their selection.  I was given an estimate of late February for when that will start.
review.author: David B.

review.description:
Well, kudos to Chicago for tying to create a somewhat indoor market in a bustling, busy, no-time-for-anything city. But...I think I would like to come back when this market figures out what it's trying to do. 

As I write this, the market has only been open maybe...2 weeks, so I expected things to be patchy and rough, but not like this. 

Here are the good points: I am a fan of anything sweet, so the chocolate, gelato, crepe bar, and pastry stall immediately caught my attention. I tried a small pastry and it was pretty good. I want to get some chocolate there sometime but then I think about the bad points and it hinders my wanting to go back. 

So...the bad. It's a mad house at lunch because there are several stands that make fresh sandwiches, juices, soups, etc. to order so it seems all of the business people, tourists, and school groups that are in Chicago are gathered in this tiny space between noon and 1 pm all at the same time. I am not kidding. This leaves NO seating room at all, which is sparse to begin with. You would think with all the people jamming into here to eat there would be seats galore, but no. My boyfriend and I were forced to sit outside of the market on a dirty bench while people rushed to get to their trains and homeless people shuffled by.

The produce, meat, etc, is somewhat underwhelming. For the prices of fish, meat, hand made soaps, and breads that are sold here, I can get better at let's say...Whole Foods. The grapes looked like they had been sitting out for a day or two and I didn't really see anything that looked exotic or special. Maybe I'm being picky, or maybe we came at a bad time, but we left feeling like the food being sold wasn't anything we were eager to cook or eat. That, and the fact that there seemed to be hordes of teenagers pushing their way around and making sarcastic comments the whole time. Meh. 

Also be wary of using your credit card at some of the places, since a few do not yet (or may never). There is an ATM at the entrance and at the CVS station across the hall, so they are your best friends. 

It's still new, and maybe I shouldn't be so critical yet. So if I find my way down there again in the future, hopefully things will be a bit cleaned up. A part of me really wants this to work, because I really want to try those crepes.
review.author: Andrea B.

review.description:
I wish I would have discovered this place sooner.  It's a hidden gem in Chicago.

They have a great selection of food, deserts, cheeses and wine.  The banh mi sandwich and the Belgium fries with truffle mayo were excellent (two different vendors).  Also, the prices are reasonable there.

I will be back to try out all the other vendors.
review.author: Joe I.

review.description:
I am giving the French Market 5 stars SIMPLY for the little restaurant back in the farrrrr left corner called RAW. Who knew raw food could taste so good.  Their hummus is so delicious, with a bit of a kick to it.  Try their "spaghetti" as well.  

I also had Buen Apetito - veggie taco w/ rice & beans.  The rice was average but the tacos and beans were both superb.  It took a while to get my order, but the taste & freshness of the food made up for it.

While the market may not be much now, at least it is something for us West Loop workers and train commuters.  I don't think they are trying to be a large market like the Reading Street Terminal Market - only three lines are serviced through Ogilvie - there are 12 lines serviced through Reading Street Terminal.  

Anyway, it is what it is for now - let's hope that some of these vendors beef up on what they offer.  The quality of the food that I have tried has been quite impressive.
review.author: Kel W.

review.description:
Yes, it's not the prettiest place.  And perhaps naming it a "French" market may set unreal expectations in consumers' minds.

But I did like this place.  If I regularly commuted into the city, I would definitely shop here often.  For someone living in the burbs, having the convenience of picking up fresh, organic food and a bottle of wine for dinner is a true time saver and the ultimate in convenience. Honestly, just that alone makes this worth 4 stars, as there is nothing worse than jumping off the train at 6pm and having to make a trip to a grocery store before getting home.

And I was impressed at all the healthy options that are offered here at the Chicago French Market.  So impressed, I even wrote about it (http://tinyurl.com/y88qt5k) in my column for the Examiner.

At RAW, you can enjoy salads and raw entrees; their mint bar was delicious.  How often do you see a raw food place at a french market?  Not in the burbs, anyway.

And Chundy's features some delicious Indian fusion food for carryout.  I tried several of his unadvertised dessert breads, which are made with all fresh ingredients, as well as his delish chicken salad.

You can get freshly squeezed vegetable/fruit juice for breakfast at Juicy Orange - your choice of unlimited ingredients.  

And Sweet Miss Giving's alone is worth the trip - they donate over 50% of their profits to the Chicago House, helping the formerly homeless and HIV positive.  Their baked goods are pretty darn good as well!

City Fresh Market features Tallgrass beef, Amish chickens, and seafood.  City Organics has a good selection of organic produce at good prices.

Perhaps if you live in the city, this is not that impressive.  But for the commuter crowd, Chicago French Market offers unparalleled convenience, a great selection of healthy and not-so-healthy foods, and wine and cheeses. Definitely worth my time!
review.author: Tina T.

review.description: This place is soooooo overrated!  They have lots of little shops to choose from  We chose the Saigon Sisters and the Mexican restaurant.  Our food was tasteless.  I've had better at chain restaurants.  Plus, the food is very over priced.  Don't waste your time.
review.author: Madison B.

review.description:
I went to this market after seeing so many 4/5-star ratings, yuk! Let me rephrase: this place sucks balls. Immediately after I walked in, I noticed this place was ridiculously small. Next thing I found out was their fruits were nowhere close to 'fresh' like some people described. Actually quite a few of them were overly ripe, and fruit flies actually swarmed around them! Well that's an instant turn-off. I continued walking down the aisle, through the pasta, sandwich, meat and fish section, and none of the products even remotely intrigued me. Almost everything was so overpriced and trust me, 80% of the stuff they have here can be found in common grocery stores at lower prices. Before I left I got an ice cream cone 'cuz they looked about right. But guess what, it's 100% artificially flavored and tasted like a mix of syrup and sweetener.

Gross! How dare this place call itself 'French market'? Virtually nothing here is French!! As I walked out, I thought I might just enter a forlorn parallel universe where the French market had been demolished by the devil.
review.author: Dex Y.

review.description:
If you've been to another city with a large indoor market, you'll be pretty disappointed. 

For instance, in Philadelphia, the Reading Street terminal market (another train station based one for apt comparison) is a large beautiful market filled with specialized grocers, bakers, pizza, butchers, fried chicken, baristas, and Amish farmers. 

The Chicago "French" Market, which is a terrible name because there isn't any plethora of French food or styling, is small and filled with franchisees with a handful of farmers.

The farmers were done a huge disservice by premiering in Winter, although it does make sense given that it is an indoor market, but the real strategy is that Metra riders who are often from the suburbs are making pitstops that coincide with their trip home.

There are a couple of shops there that are good, but their stocks are lighter than I'd want. The butcher has a limited supply of meat without any special cuts or game that I couldn't find at a local Jewel (albeit higher quality) or a local boutique grocer like Olivia's. You're a whole butcher counter - give me calf's liver, goose, or Delmonico cuts!

Pastoral and Saigon are the only places with lines most of the time. Pastoral because they're the most infamous local purveyor of cheeses and charcuterie and Saigon because it's delectable Vietnamese food.

The chocolatier is pretty good. The sausage shop by Pastoral got stiffed bad on location! I didn't even know they made sandwiches, but it's a good alternative if you don't feel like waiting in line for Pastoral. 

I feel like if the hype hadn't been there and this opened up as a surprise, I would be blown away more. I will say however, that I'm happier that this is here than it not existing.
review.author: Sharlene K.

review.description:
Yay! West Loopies and train commuters rejoice!  The first stage of the Metra Market is open.  Hopefully one day it will be as cool as Philly's Reading Market.

The brighly lit-up-for-the-holidays multi-colored trees in front were an indication it was finally open!  I had watched that darn Metra Market website and the Fulton River District Association's page for the last few years for news.  Finally.  

I have to second the cured meat recommendations for Fumare.  I tried the Gypsy bacon.  Great selection of Eastern european meats.  Was listening to stoppers by searching for Croatian items, etc.  The staff was helpful and was offering up a few slices for sampling purposes.  I also grabbed a few organic grapefruits which were beautifully colored.  

I will definitely be stopping by for the Tallgrass steaks from Kansas.  Grass fed is harder to cook but far superior in nutrition (higher Omega 3 versus Omega 6) and taste.  Nice to have a mini Lavazza coffee stand as well as the taqueria; there are some nice tables in the back with murals of the Eiffel Tower to hang out and munch.
review.author: Taylor O.

review.description:
I did a quick walkabout of this place just to check it out.  Like others have indicated, it's a lot of pastries, produce, bread and meat.  I may return on a weekend to grab a sandwich from Pastoral, as this place isn't far, but I didn't see much else that looked like it would blow my mind.  

The location of the market is a head scratcher.  It's in the north end of the Northwestern station on ground level.  I would imagine a lot of commuters race right by this place without stopping.  And on the weekends there can't be many people around.  Most commuters/weekenders seem to go out the Madison Street exit.  This area of downtown/West Loop is dead on the weekends.  I guess they are targeting the Monday through Friday office workers in the area.

What would make this place instantly cooler would be decorating it like the casino area in the Paris Hotel in Vegas with the blue sky.
review.author: Mike K.

review.description:
Yes, maybe the market was misnamed, but I did enjoy my experience here.  Obviously, I am outnumbered on this altogether.  Personally, I didn't let the name or the lighting influence the fact that I found numerous tasty treats, at reasonable prices, with friendly informative staff inside one venue.  That's a lot more than I can say for many of the grocery stores in this area.  

I appreciate the local vendors and I enjoy supporting them.  I especially enjoyed meeting one of the owners of raw.  She was outgoing and extremely knowledgeable.  Anytime we were contemplating a product she was eager to pass out sample.  Meaning she stands behind her product and knew we'd enjoy it.  

The fresh baked breads, delicious assortment of cheeses and nice display of seafood are just the beginning.  The market also offers beautiful flowers, gelato, soaps and much more.  It's definitely a spot worth checking out.
review.author: Lori Taylor R.

review.description:
Just came back from the Chicago French Market.  Not bad for the first crack.  Now mind you I've been spoiled by the Queen Vic market in Melbourne (http://www.qvm.com.au/) so any market has to stand up to that.  Selection is somewhat limited, but you can find your euro basics here:  cheese, bread, wine, fresh produce.  It makes for a nice Saturday morning jaunt.

The fish didn't look the freshest, but that's merely my opinion.  It's nice they have a mix of prepared foods and groceries.  They do need more seating though, and I'd love to see some more Italian and Greek vendors.

So get a crepe from Flip, have a Red Velvet cupcake at Sweet Miss Givings and get some Glogg from Pastoral.  You'll be happier than when you came.
review.author: Misi P.

review.description:
The French Market is fantastic if you are in the mood for yummy food and don't quite know what you want. There is a little of everything along with produce, meats, cheese and desserts. Be sure to check out Sweet Miss Givings.

At lunch it gets pretty busy and tables can be hard to find. Go with a friend so they can scoop up a table while you order food.

Bummer that there is no outdoor seating. The tables present in the summer are for the Lavazza cafe. :(
review.author: Lauren S.

review.description:
So there's nothing really "French" about this market (except that you can buy some pastries and cheese) and the decor leaves something to be desired but it's still a pretty good addition to this part of the city.  My favorite aspects in no particular order:

- Little mom/pop style grocery stands: For this single twenty-something year old, it sure beats going to Dominick's.  The produce selection is greater and the prices pretty comparable.  Plus, all the vendors are friendly and answer any questions.  Apparently you can get green cauliflower from crossing a broccoli and a cauliflower - who knew?!

- One of the stands sells Tallgrass beef - 100% grass fed, free grazing beef.  It's a can't miss if you're a steak fan.

- Saigon: As a former Californian transplanted to Chicago, I've been missing Viet food.  This saves me a trip to Argyle.
review.author: Jing C.

review.description: I go here almost every day for lunch. The best place is the meat and sandwich deli. You get a huge sandwich for 5 bucks and it's only 4 if it's the lunch special.
review.author: Patrick H.

review.description: I've been wanting to come here for the longest time and finally got to go this past Wednesday. I had heard Saigon Sisters was here and was looking forward to tasting their food and looking forward to purchasing some specialty items. I went into the "free" parking and was yelled at by the parking attendant who told me that the garage was full and I should've known it by the cars that were double parked. I promptly stopped him from continuing his yelling at me like I was his child. That exchange kind of dampened things for me and further when he told me that free parking was only available for an hour and after that it would be $20. I guess if you want to shop at the French Market you have to hurry up. Anyway, the choices seemed delicious for lunch but I quickly headed to Saigon Sisters despite sampling a delicious sandwich from a sandwich shop on my way to SS. I ordered the Beef Pho from the rude female clerk who could hardly crack a smile or speak a few extra words to tell me what they had. Her cold attitude and the parking attendant were enough to ruin my experience at the FM. I was seriously surprised at why she was so cold like I was bothering her for ordering my meal. When I asked her for my water she just waved her hand to the side of the beverage area without barely looking at me and she wasn't even busy. Anyway, the Pho was decent even thought the noodles lacked some flavor. I thought the food court was a bit dirty and we struggled to find a semi-decent clean table. The young man collecting the garbage also looked pretty unhappy and I wonder if it's perhaps not a very happy place to work? On my way out, I did stop at Beavers donuts and and they were delicious. When I asked about their gourmet donuts the sales clerk encouraged me to try their basic donuts which was a great suggestion although I don't understand why he discouraged the gourmet ones? All in all I don't think I'll be returning to the FM. I would rather try a more welcoming place. Like I said maybe the FM is not such a great workplace because the people I encountered seemed so grumpy and unhappy.
review.author: Alex G.

review.description: Love the French markets international flavor of eateries and produce...etc..Its a skip and hop from the office on Washington and Clinton. Saigon Sisters Vietnamese Sandwiches is the best along with the GELATO place on the other side. There is so much to look at. Come here for a quick bite and cool experience. Grab a table fast if you have a group. :) It gets busy here during lunch! So hussle and strategize people!
review.author: Bella D.

review.description:
I can't wait for this place to be completed! I tried the crepe place this morning and it is fantastic. I'm a regular at the fresh juice bar... the perfect pick up after a long day and it's filling too! I love the selections of shope overall, and the places to grab food (plus, fresh produce!).

Try the chocolatier here too... the candies are gorgeous!
review.author: Valerie R.

review.description:
I'm a fan on this place, yes! I just wish it was more mature and built up....its such a good idea for this area of the city. I mean, seriously, if I lived in the burbs and took the train I would be here all the time getting stuff for dinner. They have fresh veg and fruit as well as some really nice cheese. 
When we went we were just looking for a quick bite, so I got Saigon Sisters' chicken bahn-mi and it was yummers. My bf got a salad, which looked good, but I just never have gotten onto the salad bandwagon. 
So overall, great idea, I hope it sticks around and becomes more of a fixture in the area....
review.author: Phil F.

review.description:
Okay, as a daily metra rider I'm going to have to eat some of my earlier high and mighty words on accessibility. More and more I've come to appreciate the absolute convenience the French Market offers when I just can't be bothered to stop into Dominicks on the way home. I'd rather get right off the train, pop into the french market to pick up the one item that I need for complete my dinner for that evening. Butternut squash for beef stew? Check! Apples for tarte tatin? Check! A ready made salad? Check! Some artisanal cheeses? Check, check! 

So you pay a wee bit of a premium? All the time I've saved in the past month has been well worth the additional pennies I've spent.
review.author: Bora U.

review.description:
Maybe I was more disappointed because I made a separate trip here on the weekends to check it out.  I felt like I was in an elementary school's basement bake sale being pedaled similar quality goods.  Yes, some of the dessert displays were cute but it's really hard to sell $10 pieces of chocolate next to $10 sandwiches.  I also don't like seeing all the crappy soaps, purses, and needless junk being sold in the same space.  

2 stars for the concept and potential when better vendors come in this space.
review.author: Amanda S.

review.description:
I love this place. My bf and I started going every Saturday since our weekday schedules are so busy. Lots of interesting little vendors, which I love a lot more than the large supermarket chains. Our favorite spots are the cheese/sausage/bakery sections, but we've picked up some decent fruit here as well. We haven't splurged on fresh meats or seafood yet, but we'll probably try that eventually.

Excellent cheese selection, and the sausages we've gotten so far have been delicious! Fun spot, definitely check it out! We will have to try out the food vendors at some point...and the smoothie/crepe places...
review.author: Janet L.

review.description: Just a great place to stop at either before catching your train or getting off the train. With this type of variety a few steps from Ogilvie Transportation Center, it a place to grab a bite to go or to relax for a bit. I frequent Delightful Pastries, Saigon Sisters and Frietkoten Belgian Fries & Beer.
review.author: Mike M.

review.description: This place is great.  All the vendors are very nice and the food is excelent.  they have everything from fresh pies, cured meats, cheese, and an olive oil vendor.  It is a great place to buy great food in the city
review.author: Will W.

review.description:
A large group of friends and I went to the French Market when it first opened. It had a nice light and bright atmosphere that was extremely airy. We went on a Saturday and were surprised to find that the French market was not quit as busy as we thought it would be, which to be frank made it a little awkward walking down the aisles at times when the merchants would stare at us beseechingly to stop by their booths. At the same time, it was nice to have been able to stroll through leisurely without being bombarded by crowds.

We are excited to go back to visit and to see some of the changes and additions that have been made since our last visit, but at the time, a number of the restaurants and shops seemed out of place, inevitably detracting from the supposed "French" part of the French Market.

The prices are high, the merchants are friendly, and if you're looking for an all encompassing cafeteria slash// high end mall food court, then this is your place to be.

From soups to sandwiches, from flowers to gourmet chocolates, Indian food to Vietnamese, they were all very delightful (especially that of their bakeries!) but at a higher markup, of course. It is what it is, and that's a tourist attraction.
review.author: Samantha L.

review.description: This place is not a French Market. Actually, it's a grocery store combined with a halfway decent food court. I'm not saying stay away. If you're in the loop and you need a quick lunch, it's not the worst choice. Just don't expect a French Market. Voilà tout.
review.author: Andrew M.

review.description: I went here with my girlfriend for lunch to check out the place in terms of range of product varieties that they have, food wise, etc. it's not a big market which I expected to be, just a 3 row shop stalls ranging from fresh produce,cheese, chocolates, bread, cakes,etc. dining area is quite good as it ranges from Indian , Vietnamese, Korean, halal, sandwiches, n crepes. I will go back there if I happen to be in nearby area but I don't think Im going there just for it; as I can find most of the stuffs that they sell nearby my residential area. But nevertheless, it's a good concept.
review.author: Irah H.

review.description:
what a super cute place!   i felt like i was on vacation when i came here!

there are tons of different vendors here.  i made my rounds before i decided what i was going to purchase.  there's even a little seating area/food court in the back which wasn't crowded at all (i was there on a saturday around 2).  

i opted to get some sandwiches and then get my favorite new desert - macarons.  yum!!!  i heard they have great produce and i am dying to try more of a parisian-type sandwich the next time i swing by.
review.author: Kris R.

review.description:
I just wanted to write a little update to my review here.  As the place settles in and gets more comfortable with what it is, I'm finding myself enjoying it more and more.  It is still more my 'place to go for a 3PM snack' rather than my destination for lunch, but each time I go I'm noticing more and more enticing options.  I just noticed one of the places serves up Pho (but only on Monday and Tuesday) so I'll be checking that out next week.

I also have stopped by to pick up produce at my wifes request a couple of times now.  

So little by little I'm coming to appreciate this market more and more.  But I still feel like it could be so much more than what it currently is.
review.author: Chris C.

review.description: The Les Fleurs Florist in the French Market is Fabulous. Wonderful arrangements for our rehearsal dinner.
review.author: Joy S.

review.description:
Well, okay. 

It's got aways to go. I went to the French Market on Friday night after work and it was indeed crowded and slightly difficult to get to any specialty merchandise. When you first walk in from the station, you're greeted with some convenience foods in a cooler and a bunch of way-overpriced (but HUGE) fruit. But I didn't come here for fruit...and definitely not at that price. I did see a seafood counter that looked promising; the Wisconsin Cheese Mart was also cool, and Pastoral...the Pastoral counter is the undisputed star of the show, and it's also the most busy. They're staffed about right, the prices are about what I expected, and the people are friendly. 

I would come back for Pastoral alone.
