Nothing else there really caught my attention and I was disappointed that so many vendor spaces - about 1/3 - were either empty or closed down way ahead of closing time. No one was sampling but Pastoral. Of the two places that appeared to be open to serve food (but I wasn't really sure), one of them had just burnt something awful, and the other was fully-stocked with counter people, just standing around. No food was visible at all in either place. 

To be fair, the place just opened up last week and there are some definite kinks that still need to be worked out. One note: apparently they've figured out the credit card thing, at least at some merchants, as I used mine everywhere with no problem. I will likely venture back in another month or two, when hopefully there will be more merchants, better selection and fewer gawkers.
review.author: Erin J.

review.description:
not to rain on my fellow yelpers' enthusiastic parade about this place, it was actually a lot smaller than i had hoped. and most of the food stands are not french, as the name would otherwise suggest.

if chicago were any smaller of a city, i would probably let go of the fact that this market is barely a fraction of the size and exciting factor of new york's chelsea market or san francisco's pier market. but since it's not, i can't. 

side note --someone holler if there's another indoor market around that i'm missing out on please :)
review.author: Jenny T.

review.description: I am a lucky gal to work right across the street from this magical place.  So many fantastic things!  Produce, meat, seafood, desserts, made to order crepes, THE BEST Belgian fries in Chicago, Montreal pastrami sandwiches, bahn mi sandwiches... The French Market is truly a hidden gem.  I've only found one horrible place down there- Fasta Pasta. There are so many other wonderful options, skip Fasta Pasta.
review.author: Kristen T.

review.description:
I love the new French Market! I've already been several times and plan to stop by on my way home from work tonight to pick up veggies for tonight's dinner. I love that I can decide what I want for dinner on my way home and cook with fresh ingredients instead of planning out menus in advance and cooking with produce I bought days ago at the supermarket. The selection of produce and proteins is really good, especially considering the size of the stands. I was also impressed by the quality and the prices. Yes, things are slightly (only slightly) more expensive than at a supermarket, but I'm willing to pay more for the convenience and the quality. 

To all the people complaining that it's not big enough, there aren't enough vendors or that it's not a "real" French market, we have to start somewhere, and this is a huge step in the right direction.
review.author: Alexis A.

review.description: Every once in a while, I have to take the Metra up to Evanston from OTC.  If I'm there early I make it a point to stop at this great Market.  Lots of fresh fruit and veggies as well as different foods from all kinds of vendors, including my favorite, Pastoral.
review.author: Mike P.

review.description:
Great spot for a snack. 
Saigon Sisters has good banh mi, although it's a bit more expensive than other good banh mi shops in town. The Porky with pork belly is their best. 
Vanille has a good selection of macarons and cakes. Plus there are a couple more chocolate/truffle shops for dessert.
review.author: E M.

review.description: If you are grabbing the Metra stop by. This place is great. Maybe a bit pricey,but quality and convenience can't be beat. $1 oysters.
review.author: Gil T.

review.description: So I love this place for the interesting products and variety of foods they offer but the people that work here seem to have an attitude problem. There are some exceptions: spicy monkey and the mediterranean place I can't remember the name of right now, and of course the couple of places I haven't been to I can't speak for.. but yeah I seem to always get a "I'm too good for you vibe" from the people that work here, its like seriously? Do you want me to come back? I dont think my "can I get one coconut cupcake?" was offensive in any way.... It seems the employees here just can't handle customer service.
review.author: Sarah E.

review.description:
Four stars because I AM a fan.  I love the options. I love just meandering down the aisles.  It's all a bit expensive but if you want to grab a piece of fruit and something else...it's completely within your reach at this place...you make it what you want to make it...and spend what you want to spend.  

I hope this place survives and they open up a few more grab and go options...more like in Europe!
review.author: Anne S.

review.description:
UTTER & TOTAL DISAPPOINTMENT, BIG WASTE OF TIME

I heard about the opening of this marketplace while watching the news one night.  Since I work in The Loop and one of my co-workers sometimes takes Metra, we decided to make a trip to CFM after 5 one day.  

I ride the CTA, so I was initially impressed by the sleek building that is 131 North Clinton.  However, when we reached the actual market,  all my expectations of gourmet and fancy deflated faster than a pin poked balloon.  The place had the feel of a makeshift fair set up in a suburban, high school gymnasium.  I know it's a marketplace, but I felt like I was attending a job fair or some kind of trade show with multiple exhibitors.  

While there was variety (popcorn, gelato, banh mi sandwiches etc.), most of the displays did not seem that unique or appealing.  Everything was pretty expensive.  One small container of pasta salad was about six bucks.  The medium sized, cheddar and caramel popcorn I bought for a pretty penny paled in comparison to Garrett's.  We sampled some bread from one vendor.  It was solidly good, but didn't taste like anything worth buying there. 

Unless you really need that bread or fancy cheese for your dinner with the Grundersons tonight, don't bother.  There's probably a Whole Foods nearby.  Heck, even Jewel or Dominicks will do.
review.author: Vicki W.

review.description:
Today for lunch I went to the MetraMarket. There were some hits and some misses but over all ..... I am a fan. 

So, the good stuff....They have burek. I am familiar with burek through my significant other who orders it on the regular. It is specific to his culture. I talked my friend into trying one, of which I had one bite. I should get a medal for sticking to my diet and not eating the whole loaf because it was bombtastic. 

Next, I purchased some meats from the meats counter....all grass fed and mostly organic...I was able to purchase 4 meats ground grass fed beef, grass fed beef and lamb chevapi, Amish chicken (which was confirmed free of hormones and antibiotics), and beef stew chunks for TWENTY BUCKS!! That's a lot if grass fed goodness for $20. Definitely cheaper than Whole Pay Check.

The cheese curd is delicious. They have some other tasty treats that I was unable to try but look yum! I want to try the juice bar.

The misses....the Raw Shop. I don't want to completely hate on it, but they were more expensive than Karyn's and that is hard to do. They also didn't have the nut pate - which I thought was standard raw food fare. Maybe I was spoiled by Karyn's. I will try again, though.

Pastoral Artisan Cheese's looks delicious, maybe it's only a miss based on pricing. Although, they are supposed to be the best of the best which explains the price. $32/lb for cheese....I am no expert, so to be fair I won't comment on what my gut level response about that one is.

There are so many places there. I will likely update this review once I have had a chance to visit more of them!
review.author: Rebecca H.

review.description: I call this the 'Ogelvie' market :) because it has nothing French about it...ok Pastoral, Vanille and a few others, but the attitudes of that place are not market-friendly. Except for the Saigon Sisters stand :) Maybe the morning brings better customer service?
review.author: Mimi I.

review.description:
This (almost) makes me wish I still commuted in from Palatine daily.  This would have been the ultimate in convenience!

First off, you can also do a bit of grocery shopping here.  It's definitely not going to take care of all of your needs but you can definitely get some of the basics covered . . .   And from local farmers as well.  The prices appear to be better than Whole Foods but, as with everything, your mileage may vary.  

Second is the main reason I like this place . . .  Usually when coworkers and I were unable to figure out or agree on what we all wanted to eat the Ogilvie fast food court won out.  Unfortunately . . .  It's all fast food.  This is a great alternative!

I do expect to see it continue to improve as time goes on.  Right now it's the dead of winter. I'm really looking forward to seeing what the spring and summer brings for the vendors in there.  

So far I've tried three of the vendors for lunch.  

Raw - GREAT food VERY personable staff.  My only comment is they have too many free samples out!  I went with a coworker and we tried each of the four samples they had out.  They were VERY VERY good but she was full from the samples alone.  I walked away with the Chicago Raw Rolls which were like vegan sushi rolls.  Excellent!

Buen Apetito - Not thrilled.  I ordered a Chicken Taco and Tortilla soup.  The Chicken Taco was bland.  The Tortilla Soup was very tomatoey (for lack of better word).  Not bad food but I can go to La Cocina at Washington and Wells for better Mexican food.  

I also got a turkey sandwich from one of the vendors . . .  It was good!  Not sure what the vendor's name was however.
review.author: Derek W.

review.description: Great place to come for lunch--I've had Saigon Sisters, FLIP Crepes and tried a few of the dessert stands. Such a fun experience, so much to choose from...nice for a date with your friend.
review.author: Farrah D.

review.description:
I live next door to this place and happened to run into by chance .... I am really glad I did.  There are fresh organic fruits and vegetables, great cheeses and breads, fresh meats and fish.  It is the only place I know where you can buy quality artisan bacon without having to sign up for "monthly online plan" ..... 

Great place, great food.  It is fun place to shop or even walk around when you are bored.
review.author: Vispy M.

review.description:
I had read an article celebrating Chicago's 175 years with a list of 175 'must-do/see/experience' things in Chicago and this market was one of them.  We picked up 4 different kinds of cheeses from the same very knowledgeable vendor that is also on Broadway in Lakeview (Pastoral).  Strange thing about this market it is apparently actually like France, so I'm told.  What I mean by this is that you pay at each vendor vs. walking through the market with your basket and then paying at the end.  Who knew?

In addition to the wonderful cheeses, we grabbed delicious olive and sun dried tomato tapenades, buttery soft prosciutto, apples, and avocados to go with baguette.... and we picked up the ingredients for bruchetta too.  A feast indeed. 

It was delicious.  The cheeses were great minus the Brie, which kind of tasted like a dirty, camp foot, and the tomato tapenade was one of the star players of the meal.  

This place has an amazing fresh seafood counter so we are excited to try our hand at grilled calamari next time.  There is also a florist, a candy vendor, a raw bar, a sushi bar, homeade sausages, a pastry place (maybe 2?), and a couple of fruit and veggie stands.  Definitely a place go to over and over again.

Parking is validated if you spend $20+ dollars.  Just bring your receipt and ask the vendor to punch your card from the parking garage before you go back out to your car.
review.author: Jeanette S.

review.description: Don't be fooled by the name- nothing like a french market.  I repeat for those who have actually visited France- NOTHING like a french market!  Even Disney's Epcot is a better version than this disaster.  I really wanted to like this place, and have been so eager to visit.  Upon entry, I felt like I was in a bad food court in NJ.  Such a disappointment!  Honestly, Whole Foods feels more french market-like than this place.
review.author: Krystin I.

review.description:
It was really fun to walk around and see all the variety of food and drink stands and even some merchandise.  They have some vegan selections, asian, mexican, indian, salads, crepes, sandwiches, deli meats and cheeses, pastries... tons.  

We decided on a crepe with brie, fig jam, nuts and ham.  It was different and very tasty.  We added a cup of soup, Italian meatball, which also satisfied the belly.  Next time we'll go for lunch we'll have to try some of the indian or was it polish - meat stews?

Overall, I think it is a work in progress - as it still doesn't look done.  The sandwich line at the corner was ridiculously long when we were there and I heard a lot of people complain.  the next day my husband went back to get some cheese curds and they were out too.
review.author: Jessica M.

review.description:
Like the previous reviewers, I didn't find anything French about this market, but it was a nice collection of different food and grocery stands.  

I found that most places were slightly overpriced, but that didn't deter us from getting a sandwich from pastoral artisan cheese & wine (pretty good, the gruyere on the sandwich was the highlight), a smoked salmon crepe at flip (it was shaped like a large burrito and wrapped with aluminum foil...i thought crepes are supposed to be flat and eaten with a fork?), and some chocolate desserts from vanille (so delicious).  they had a wide range of healthy stands with raw food and juice that looked great too, but no time to try it on my visit.  i'll definitely try the gelato and banh-mi on my next visit.
review.author: Tiff W.

review.description: This review is strictly for the super market which is great.  They have all my fruits and vegetables that I need and both are very fresh!  The meat dept is fantastic.  The men that work there are fantastic.  When looking at the meat case they acknowledge you right away and ask if you need help and they can cut a whole chicken for you or cut up  fish into however many ozs you want.  I bought bass there as well as chicken thighs.  Its nice to stop in the supermarket before I get on the train to pick up ingredients for dinner.  The market didn't sell parchment paper so the butcher gave me some from the back.  He was soo nice!!!
review.author: Ccc C.

review.description: Very cool spot, food vendors are definitely the highlight.  The Vietnamese Sandwiches alone are worth the trip, but don't pass by the Montreal smoked meat.  Those are two things very hard to find Chicago, and there you can get them twenty feet from each other.  I wish we could get some out in the 'burbs!!!
review.author: Jenna G.

review.description: I am usually excited to make a visit to the French Market at Chicago's Ogilvie Transportation Center. The last time, I made a couple of stops on Wednesday afternoon to some of the different merchants and walked away with some delicious loot! First, I had to buy some macarons. Vanille Patisserie, located at the train terminal entrance, is the only place in Chicago that I've found that can make macarons the way they are supposed to taste. Light, crunchy, flavorful, and unique, these macarons could even rival the ones that I covet from La Durée! There is also a Vanille Patisserie on Clybourn. Now all I crave is an Ispahan from a Pierre Hermé or La Durée boutique in Paris. Looks like I might have to wait a bit longer for one of those, though! Next, I walked to the opposite corner of the market to the Pastoral Artisan Cheese, Bread, and Wine merchant. Their selection of cheeses is almost unrivaled. The best part is that many of them are so unique that I've never found them anywhere else! For example, I purchased a chunk of manchego cheese with a rosemary wrap around the outside. I also bought a goat cheese infused with anise and lavender. The flavors were light and fresh, perfect for summer. I'm in love. Although the prices are quite expensive, it's just a joy to treat yourself to some delicious summer fare once in awhile. Also in my grocery bag was a 1/2 lb. of Venetian Calamari linguini from Pappardelle's Pasta (I made sure to steer clear of the Habanero pasta so as not to repeat a dinnertime drama from last week). I'm planning on checking out Pappardelle's suggested recipes to see how to prepare the pasta. But if all else fails, I can always make a sauce with cream, butter, shallots, garlic, and perhaps some clams/clam juice? If anyone has any suggestions, I'm all ears! I'd definitely implore you all to check out this little slice of France in Chicago. It's pretty damn great!
review.author: Carolyn L.

review.description: I have been eating/living so much better since the French Market has opened! Every week I go and stock up on fresh produce, fish, poultry, breads, and the flowers- absolutely amazing! All of the vendors are so kind and the quality/pride people have of what they are selling is so refreshing. They are all so knowledgeable and willing to share--I absolutely LOVE this place!!!  The only bummer is like what other posters have said- sometimes a place you love just disappears without warning- like that sweet little french man who sold the BEST olives I've ever had. One day-poof- he was gone. That feels a bit cold but I'm sure thats a management thing- not the vendors. Anyway- check it out if you get a chance!
review.author: L S.

review.description:
A quick stop at the french market was a last minute detour before heading back to Milwaukee.....I was hoping for something better. 

When you and a few friends are the only ones walking though you get all the "please buy something!" stares from the stand owner/workers. All I could muster was a coffee purchase.

Great idea, great space for getting train foot traffic. I will return in spring with an empty stomach and more time to peruse (vegetables, breads, soups, wines, etc).
review.author: Erik P.

review.description: Disappointing, honestly i was just hoping for an indoor market, and if it had more "french" to it then a whole foods so much the better, but a market it ain't...more accurately its a food court where you can perhaps buy some groceries. There is not 1 traditional french thing to be had, its all americanized crap, or not even french themed at all, and its all overpriced. Tres touristique
review.author: james j.

review.description: I adore the French Market and love to come by here to pick up food for dinner or a quick snack or lunch during the week.  That being said, can the people marketing this place PLEASE do a better job so that places like the Papardelle's and the Indian Food shop don't close up within months of opening??  It depresses me when I stop in and see that yet another wonderful place has disappeared.  I'm only one person and can only buy so much, but you have enough traffic coming through this building that you should be able to sustain all of these places!
review.author: Yvonne O.

review.description: Just do yourself a favor and go.  There are so many options.  I'm sure you'll find something to love.
review.author: Steven G.

review.description: I love the Chicago French Market and would gladly tell you my favorites if I wasn't concerned about making the lines longer at my spots, but I can be of service to answer the question "What is Montreal Pastrami and how is it different than deli pastrami?" The guy behind the counter will answer the Deli uses Navel, we use brisket (as though that's something that would actually give you a semblance of an answer). So here it is, the Montreal 'brisket' cut is much much much fattier and less salty than the deli version you know love and can't find enough of in Chicago. Also, they serve it on dark rye, which you normally don't see at the deli, this is a sweeter rye. SO you end up with sweet bread, tons of slimy fat, and some good beef mixed in there somewhere. Also, they don't put the mustard on the sandwich for you, which is just something I prefer. I definitely won't buy this again, especially because there are so many other much much better options at the CFM.
review.author: dan s.

review.description:
I hate to bump this down a star, but I have to. For my purposes, the French Market just isn't cutting it.

Stalls may up and leave at any time - which happens, but it also happens generally without warning. There was a great organic Italian booth here... gone. And Necessity Baking is gone too.

I'm bummed that it's hard to get out of here with a lunch that's under $10, too. I realize that goes with the downtown territory, mostly, but it makes it a less appealing option for me. ($7.50 for a bowl of pasta from the new pasta place is really pushing it.)

Worse, the whole market is lacking that bustling activity - heck, any activity - that is the hallmark of other markets I've been to. The space remains soulless and character-free, quiet as a mouse most days, and not heavily trafficked. I think the location is doing it in, to be honest with you, and I wish that weren't the case.

I'm sorry to say it, but the French Market is a disappointment. I wanted so much more.
review.author: Paul M.

review.description: Pretty diffcult to give a rating on a place that is made up of other stores/restaurants, but I think the french market is a great place to go for a relaxing lunch or brunch.  There's so many choices and they are all different from eachother....theres a crepe stand, different bakeries, produce stands, sandwich stands, vietnamese food stand, florists, and other unique stores/stands. Last time we had a couple croquette sandwiches from LM and an orzo salad from a produce stand....mmmmm so good.  Levazza is also there and they have good coffee and pastries aswell.
review.author: aldrich b.

review.description:
I'm ashamed that I've only just discovered this place.  I work along Wacker Drive at the UBS Tower, which is about a 3 block walk from the French Market.  I somehow have missed out on years already of what could have been delicious and nutritious lunches in an atmosphere that is as close to a French Market as you're going to get in Chicago.  The selection is great - there is a vendor representing about every ethnic food group.  I bought a delicious baguette sandwich with cooked prosciutto, brie, arugala (sp?) and sliced eggs with a mild and savory honey citrus viniagrette, and a Vita Coco to wash it down.  I'm very excited about the possibility of spending another lunch break in the loop at the market.  There is so much I need to try, and when considering the fact that one could potentially pick up ingredients for dinner while on their lunch break at this place, the conveniency factor is 5-stars as well.

The only down side is the seating.  It is far from any door or windows, so you are not able to sit and gaze at passers-by, or even anything too aesthetically pleasing.  It is sort of hidden away from the rest of the market at the back of the lot.  The location is also hidden.  I mean, I did not locate this place for years, and I work downtown.  It is at Ogilvie Station, but it's at the Washington St. Entrance to the station (apparently there is one), in a corridor behind the platforms.  Unfortunate that they are not allowed to use this spacious corridor for seating, as it would make a better arrangement to enjoy one's fresh foods.  I hope this place is able to attract the attention it deserves.  It is a short walk from the offices of thousands of Chicago workers - ones who would like a fancy feast, or also with under $10 ideal lunch budgets.
review.author: Daniel F.

review.description: I am at the Ogilvie Station a few times during the week and it took me three months to finally decide to check out the place.  They have a great selection of vendors, with a wink to french style shops.  You can find a few eye-drooling pastry shops down there, if you look too long you'll end up buying something -- you've been warned.
review.author: Ernesto D.

review.description: A fabulous concept,without a doubt! Fresh meats,bakery items,cheese,produce,seafood and some premade items as well. I love the concept! However.....wow.....you need some deep pockets to shop here! Not a place I would frequent on my way home to grab and get something for dinner,even though I would be tempted. I would blow the budget assembling a full meal here.I could see grabbing some cheese or bakery items on the way home,but carrying the makings for a full meal would be awkward on the train as well. It will be intresting to see how this much awaited market will fare in our city.
review.author: Patty V.

review.description:
I like the french market in general, I work in the Ogilvie building so it is highly convenient (with a lot of variety) and leagues above the food court at Ogilvie.

A warning for readers about Fumare Meats, however: These people have a tendency to upsell with no warning about vast changes in price.  For instance, I went in today asking about their special (which was basically a club for about $6-$7) and the lady behind the counter suggested a pastrami that they roast themselves.  Now, the pastrami was pretty damned good, but the sandwich was a bit small.  The shocker was when they charged me $12 for it.  Just a bit of warning: if you're going to upsell to the tune of a 70% increase in the price, you should warn your customer.

So, play it smart.  If they make a suggestion, ask in advance about the price.

Other than that, their meats are pretty good (though the bread they use for their sandwiches is generally lame.  After today's shocking upsell, I'm unlikely to return however.

Now Pastoral (right next to Fumare) is incredible.  They have a great sandwich including great meats and cheeses.  They're likely to get my exclusive lunch sandwich business from now on.
review.author: Rob L.

review.description: Lots of variety. From the name, I assumed there would only be 'French' foods, but its Indian, Vietnamese, Vegan... anything really! The only reason this place isn't five stars is because there is never any seating available.
review.author: Denzell W.

review.description: Being new to the West loop lunch offering and typically avoiding the Metra like the plague has apparently veiled me from the pricey delight that is the French Market.  Combining a market reminiscent of my old fave Fox an Obel and the sandwich styling of a Pastoral variety (there is a location here) sandwich shop. the market just keeps adding on the variety.  So far I have had a sandwich from the pricey but amazing specialty market next to pastoral (BBQ pork belly on fresh baked french bread mmmmm) and what is probably the cheapest option in the market, the Chinese place, that was also pretty damn good.  I have to make time though to try the Belgian french fry bar, that's right, nothing but fresh cut french fries, assorted dipping sauces and a variety of Belgian brews.  Thank god they are open till 8, I don't think I would be very helpful at work if I made it a lunch.
review.author: Brett K.

review.description: What a gem!! Wonderful selection of "Farmer's Market" and specialty shop stands all in one place. I had a fabulously delicious vegetarian Indian meal for lunch. Rice with stewed spicy veggies and curried slaw. So delicious and a very generous portion!  I also split dessert with a friend at Flip crepes....nutella and banana! Can't go wrong with that! There is a Pastoral, bakeries, veggie stands, meat, seafood and cheese counters, worldly cuisines like Thai, German, Polish, etc. The whole thing felt very European.  If you enjoy the Farmer's markets in Chicago, don't miss this!!
review.author: Missy M.

review.description:
I love this place! I went for the first time the other day and all I have to say is that it was hard to choose between many tasty treats. I feel like this place isn't very well-known but it's one of those secret gems. 

So many yummy stores in one location. There is a Pastoral cheese stall (do they sell sandwiches there too? I'm not sure), Flip Crepes, Vanille Patisserie, Saigon Sisters, fresh produce and meats, Sweet Miss Givings bakery, etc, etc, etc.

I had a crepe from Flip Crepes, coffee from Lavazza and a mini-cupcake from Sweet Miss Givings. Both were YUMMY and I had a fun time walking around and looking at the other stalls. 

Minus one star because it seemed kind of empty (granted, we were there on a random week day at about 10am and empty is better than packed but there was something that made it seem forlorn.)
review.author: A H.

review.description: Very cool little place in the transit center. Such fresh foods and goods. Definitely a place to get some groceries and things you can find in the average store. I really had fun here and the setting was super nice.
review.author: Joshua N.

review.description: I love this place - it really is a great addition to downtown. In the winter I stop in to pick up juice or something to eat in the morning. In the summer I like to pop over for lunch. The stalls are full of fresh organic produce, which is helpful for me too when I need to pick up something to mix in with dinner before I head home for the night.
review.author: Jeff J.

review.description:
I never thought I would think along these lines - but I am actually jealous of the suburbanites that hop off those metra trains at Oligive. Why? They get off right in front of the best new breakfast/ lunch/grab a dinner on your way home venue in the Loop (at least according to me!). 
During a recent trip to Vancouver, I was absolutely enamored by the vast public market in Granville. The Chicago French market pales in comparison, scale, variety and crowds considered, but it is exciting to see the concept finally make it into the city. 
I've tried to make amends for not trying the place sooner by making a couple of lunch trips here. 2 trips, 4 vendors, sampling of apple-caramel crepes, Belgian fries served French style, fresh fruit juice and vegetarian Vietnamese subs - and I loved them all! 
A special shout out for Flips ( and this is not entirely to get a free crepe, their current offer) - great options, friendly staff, a bit slow - but hey, you can't rush those crepes. Saigon Sisters also deserves a stop - I was a bit reluctant to bite into a sub containing tofu,lemon grass and red pepper, but was really pleased with the end product. Next stop: the very enticing patisseries sprinkled throughout the market! 
Huge thumbs up for the French market - for anyone working anywhere in the Loop, this is a must try lunch destination.
review.author: D J.

review.description:
i think if you take into account what this is--a handful of diversely themed lunch and grocery stands next to a metra station--it is quite satisfactory. if you go here expecting a full-fledged market environment, you will be disappointed...but considering what it is and where it is, i'm not sure why anyone would expect that. 

ultimately, it's a good place for lunch if you work in the area, and a good place to go if you're trying to satisfy a group of picky and/or indecisive eaters. (i ended up here thanks to the later. we were also meeting at a nearby gallery, and there was a dearth of decent inexpensive dining options in the area.) i was particularly impressed with the variety of vegetarian, vegan, and raw vegan options; grabbing a (quality/nutritious) bite on the run isn't always easy for strict vegetarians. 

the place doesn't have much to offer in the way of restaurant dining atmosphere, but it isn't a restaurant. don't go here if you're looking for a quiet place to linger over lunch.
review.author: Meghan L.

review.description: I would love to see more of a variety of vendors here. While keeping in mind that the rent is probably pretty high, the items that you'll find here vary.  There are plenty of produce vendors, baked good vendors, t-shirts and homemade books, soaps and wine.  I bought a few meals for the week from Chicago Raw Food after having a few samples. The woman who helped me so warm and friendly and had the clearest skin and eyes I've ever seen. No lie. It must be the raw lifestyle. I bought the Raw Oatmeal, Veggie Rolls and the Signature Special Sandwich. All very good and to be honest, very filling. After checking this place out in the A.M., when it was slow, definitely check it out after 5. Lively!
review.author: Jojo F.

review.description: After spending some time in France, I have on a weekly basis dreamed about  pain au chocolate mmm.  The french market has them, despite the fact that they usually sell out right before I get there.  (maybe they should consider making more..)  I love the cheese stall and the fish stall has a much higher quality fish at a much lower price than Whole Foods and Jewel.  Sashimi grade tuna for $11.99 lb...Yes please!!
review.author: Jennifer S.

review.description: The main entrance into this food frenzy is on Clinton Street in the Loop, but, you can also seek the indoor opening through the Metra Station. From Vienna Beef Hot Dogs to Sushi to Gourmet Grilled Cheese and fresh flowers, the options are endless. You can grab salmon filet to throw on your grill or stand in line to wrap your hands around the perfect crepe. I venture into the French Market often, but, today, I was tempted by the new vendor, Beaver Donuts. Bite size and warm, what a way to treat myself to the perfect treat for Valentine's Day. Since I walked over, it seemed like a good idea to bring home enough to keep my comfy indoors while watching the snow fall. So, I waited at EJ Sushi for them to create my Chicken Udon Soup, then, stepped over to Wisma for a takeout container filled with Goat Cheese and Pasta. All set for the cold weekend! Can't wait to dine on my sofa.
review.author: Michelle S.

review.description: Where can you get a fresh, fantastic bahn mi, some cooked-to-order Belgian Frites and a great beer selection? The French Market, naturally. I stop by here sometimes to pick up something fresh to cook for dinner, but it's usually for the variety of lunch choices. Saigon Sisters really does go perfectly with frites and a beer.
review.author: Mally S.

review.description: Went during grand opening weekend.  Loved the variety of goods sold, especially enjoyed the crepes and Lavazza coffee.. other stuff included homemade soaps and body products and a nice cheese stand.. check it out!
review.author: Brenda V.

review.description:
All the years of waiting and all the buildup produced a big disappointment for Chicago. 
The produce looked like anywhere and not as good as Whole Foods... more like Jewel.
Fish market looked ok but no one could answer where the fish came from. 

Purveyors out of food at 1:30pm, so no chance to sample Saigon Bahn Mi or Belgian fries.  You'll find better flowers at Dominics or Jewel.
There were 4 good shops in the entire place--
The Wisconsin Cheese shop, Pastoral--tapanades and small gourmet items, and the Soap Lady who has lovely things. Also Fumare, the smoked meat purveyor.

Other than this, it was a big dud and cannot compare to any similar markets I've been to in any US or European city. You can find the same and better bakery and patisseries in their neighborhood locations in Chicago. Ex: Vanille.  For the most part, the items could be found at down scale quality grocery stores in the bakery isle.

If you are expecting a Chicago version of The Ferry Building, Pike Place Market or Les Halles or Jean Talon in Montreal, you can forget it.
I guess if you are out of an item and commuting in the train station, you can find some hormon free meats to grab and go but who knows what they're  like?  No Niman ranch here!
review.author: Deborah B.

review.description:
Wow, what a cool place!

Now, I'm not some worldly traveler, I've lived in Chicago my whole life, traveled out of the country once in high school to go to Austria and Venice, Italy, and I don't know about all the cool little markets and shops enough to try and snob it up about this place.  But this has been an experience I've thoroughly enjoyed.  Visted the market quickly yesterday and today and have loved what I've found so far.  Yesterday I took home an apple and a thick grass-fed ribeye.  The apple was honestly one of the sweetest, juiciest, and crispiest apples I've ever had, I literally had apple juice dripping down my arm and the steak was AMAZING.  Now I am a bit of a steak snob, I cook a lot of steak at home and there's only so much I can with a Jewel choice cut but this thick ribeye was as good as any I've gotten in an upscale resturant and of course I had looker's on begging me for bites and repeat bites.

This morning was a coffee and although the lady at the counter had some opening day jitters and I got served a little slow, my mocha was warm and tasty, perfect for my long cold walk to work.

I can't wait to bring my bf here and tell the rest of my friends and family about this place.
review.author: Kristen F.

review.description:
I am a huuuge of the idea of the French Market.  It brings a lot to the city. Most big cool cities have one (or more).  But the execution of Chicago's version leaves a lot to be desired.

Zillions of people go to the Loop every day for work.  You'd think there would be a of variety in food to eat.  But there isn't.  The Loops is dominated with chains and fancier restaurants.  "Let's get something ethnic - how's Chipotle?"   Seriously??  There are only a handful of smaller vendors left.  The French Market gives the Loop an infusion of smaller vendors and ethnic food.  That's the greatness in the idea.

When you enter the French Market, however, it's a bit of a downer.  The first thing you notice is that you're in the wrong part of the train station.  The main entrance is off Madison, where all the foot traffic goes.  The French Market is north of Washington St.   I bet most commuters don't even know about this side of the station.  The second thing you notice is the super bright fluorescent lights.  Yeah it's a small thing, but it makes you think this place is a food court, rather than an upscale market.  The dining area, floor tile, etc. add to the food court effect.  It just doesn't look like a place you'd want to hang out at.

The food itself is fine.  There is a great variety of vendors.  Pastoral is excellent.  I enjoy Saigon Sisters (though there is better banh mi around but far away from the Loop).  There's Korean food, crepes, Belgian fries, raw bar, coffee, desserts, chocolatiers... all sorts of interesting food to consume.  I would much prefer these places to the Subways in the Loop, not to mention the prepared food at Whole Foods.  The groceries are cool too.  Some people complain that these vendors don't have everything, but c'mon people - these are just small vendor stalls!  It's nice to be able to get fruits and veggies for less than Domnicks & Whole Foods prices, within walking distance.  It's nice to be able to get fresh fish and fresh meat.  Yeah I could drive up to Stanley's to get veggies even cheaper, or I could go to the full fish market on Fulton/Halsted.  But having all this stuff here is a great convenience.

All in all, I'm very happy the French Market is here.  They could really give it a facelift to make it cooler.  And maybe just rename it to "Metra Market" - like the signs outside the building for the last 5 years - would make it less confusing to some.  Lately I have noticed that it's not terribly full during the lunch rush.  Not a good sign!  I hope the market stays afloat.  Today, the Chicago French Market is nowhere near Faniuel Hall in Boston or the various markets in Toronto.  Heck, it's not even as good as Milwaukee's market.  I think our market has a lot of promise though.  It may unfortunately require some churn to get it to where it should be....
review.author: Nguyen L.

review.description:
came here for sweet miss giving's 2 for $1 red velvet cupcakes for good friday around 1pm and they were already all sold out!!!! BOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO

got a duck sandwich from pastoral too. too much dijon for me, but lots of cheese so it was still pretty good. not sure if i'd make the trek out there unless there was some sort of deal/event going on
review.author: christine c.

review.description: The pho sucks...but the "Porky sandwich" is perhaps the best sandwich I have ever chomped down on. I used to dream about the Cuban Sangwiches from Marianao's...This is something life changing.
review.author: PJ J.

review.description: This is just an OK farmer's market, I did the walk through on a saturday afternoon and there weren't very many people there, so it felt kinda quiet and diminishes the fun and bustle of going to a market when there's barely anyone there.  I tried a smores crepe, which was really good, and really big.  It's more like a smores burrito, definitely share with someone, don't attempt this one on your own.  Other than that, I know there is Pastoral and Vanilla Patisserie, but both are slightly expensive, and the portions are not very big.  As a market, I don't think it compares to other really good markets, but if you are already in the area, then I think it's fine to stop by.  I wouldn't make a big trip out to the French Market, though, not worth your time.
review.author: Mary X.

review.description:
After reading the reviews, it appears folks are approaching this place from two camps: those looking for a quick meal--i.e. lunch--and those looking to buy things for making a nice quality meal at home--i.e. en route home after work.  The market is definitely worth repeat trips for having a meal.  However, where this place shines and shows how it is special is in the areas of fresh produce, fresh meat/fish (organically, grain fed meat/poultry, great section of fish), and variety of cheeses, high end deli, wine (Pastoral), and deserts. 

With respect to the dining, I have only eaten at the deli on site (very good to great but not cheap). My wife loves the Vietnamese noodle dishes and crepes. 

I think folks should be happy to have this place; it's akin to similar stuff available to commuters in world class cities--Grand Central Station, NY and Paris subway.  If you use the Metra, you should definitely make a trip over here en route home. You can pick up a high quality item to add to an otherwise routine dinner--whether it be fish/meat/poultry, a side dish, a great bottle of wine, or dessert. 

This place is truly a benefit to Chicago, the train station system, West Loop and urban living in general. I would avoid the reviews trying to compare this place to a large chain supermarket; the two places are apples and oranges and the comparison is not helpful or meaningful.
review.author: james h.

review.description: Love their hours! Selection seems very dessert driven. Their fish counter seems plentiful, but I haven't had the chance to cook with any of their offerings to taste the quality but plan on doing so soon.
review.author: Dina I.

review.description: Some of the reviews are a bit harsh IMO.  They just opened and need some time to work out the kinks.  I've only tried a few of the products so far, and they're all excellent.:  Canady chocolates, Pastoral, and the sausage stand next to Pastoral.  Chicago really needed this, and I hope it works out.
review.author: maurice s.

review.description:
A bit of a disappointment. Having been to France many times, to call a place like this a "French Market" is a bit embarrassing...

The saddest part of this market, is the fact that the Daley administration pumped $8 million dollars in T.I.F. funds into this project.

Please take time to read the current  new articles relating to this market.  You would be wise to spend your money elsewhere.
review.author: Alex J.

review.description:
went there for brunch and grocery shopping this morning

had the pork belly and the beef sandwiches from saigon sisters along with the shrimp spring rolls, not the best i have had but all were pretty good
we also had a drink from the juice stand and that was fresh and excellent

the guys at the meat/ fish stall were friendly and helpful
I am glad to see the meat selection is pretty extensive but the seafood side is still a little wee bit empty
hopefully there will be more customers and they can stock more items

i tried the delightful pasteries right before the holidays, and Robert at the stand was so nice and helpful, will definitely be back to try some other goodies there

haven't gotten produce there yet and that's next on my list

we need to give this place a little time as well as some love, that's the only way the quality will improve 

its a good start, now they just need to make it better
review.author: Agnes F.

review.description: Visited Chicago again this past weekend...this place has changed!  So many amazing new vendors and options.  I should have been a little easier on this place when it first opened...realize it takes time to get built up!  Wish I still lived in Chicago so I could eat here all the time!!
review.author: Meesh C.

review.description: This place is great! It is such a nice addition to the West Loop area, but nobody seems to know that it exists. There is everything from raw food to banh mi, from belgian beer to fresh groceries. The only downside is that it is a bit expensive and there are some empty stalls around the market, giving it a kind of 'just moved-in' feel. I hope people will start coming to this place so there will be more competition between vendors and more variety.
review.author: Stuart E.

review.description: I was really excited about the CFM. It's not that close to my work, but since it's open until 7PM on week nights I can make it there after work, but some of the vendors seemed pretty picked over. It was the first week or two that it was open, so I understand it's going to take awhile to figure out how much inventory to have ready each day and whatnot. I got to try the Vietnamese place's tofu spring rolls. It was pretty tasty, but I only got that because they were out of the duck sandwich which my friend told me they had. I will definitely be back to try the RAW vegan place in the future, but I may wait until it settles down a little.
review.author: Leigh K.

review.description:
I live 2 blocks from the French Market and I'm in love with *Espression by Lavazza*.  The best quality cup of espresso with just the right amount of smooth crema on top and always served in a china cup.  
Star Bucks; please explain why-oh-why would you think somebody wants a shot of espresso served in a paper cup, a cup that looks like something used for a urine sample?  Why do you make me ask for a real cup? 
An espresso is only a shot, about 1 fluid oz; it should never be served in a paper cup.
review.author: Gary C.

review.description: nice venue right below the Ogilvie train station. Nice selection of meat,cheese, bread, veggies, seafood etc. Nice pastries too. There are a few eateries including Italian. mexican, Belgian style pomme frites and Vietnamese.  worth a look and free validated parking is available if you spend 20 dollars ( which aint hard)
review.author: Larry B.

review.description: Lots going on! Lots of yummy foods! Went there for lunch with a small group, ate outside in the beautiful weather, and even picked up a vegetable I needed for dinner that night.
review.author: Anne M.

review.description: A yuppie atttempt at a public market and a weak attempt. I saw two guys trying to make "frites", they should go back to their broker jobs. The great public markets in the U.S have mounds of spectacular, interesting products and cater to real neighborhood people, this place is a pompous cartoon..
review.author: evan c.

review.description: I was super disappointed in the market as I was recently there during evening rush hour.  Having been to a variety of markets all over the country and in Europe, this seemed nothing more than a small sampling of a Whole Foods or a plain Dominics.  The variety was minimal, the sitting area was like a school cafeteria and there was virtually zero atmosphere.  It is understandable that we are not in the midst of the Midwest produce season, but it was still rather sad.   Pete's Produce can pull it off very well this time of year, so why this place cannot is beyond me.  I know that Chicago is capable of supporting a far more impressive market and I hope it develops into something bigger and better, but the limitations of the space itself will probably prevent that anyways.
review.author: Zack M.

review.description: I was teetering between a three or four star review and decided on three in my hopes that this will cause them to improve on their negatives. On the plus side there's a great candy shop, a nice pastry place near the fish and a very cool Belgian food stand. Besides that though, nothing else was that impressive. Many of the stands were either bare or had no one working and the few that were open, most of the employees looked like they could care less about being there. I didn't get the feeling of a French market with people chatting with the booth owners and other shoppers. The selection of meats, cheeses, and breads wasn't that impressive either. They should take a visit to Fox and Obel and see what a true world market should look like.
review.author: Eric M.

review.description: Well, I wanted to like it. Tried to get tofu from the Saigon Sisters. "We're out." Really? WTF. Okay. Moving on. Pastoral has a completely unjustified line. Forgot about the 'frites' place until too late. Oh my. Chundy is at it again. Hope he makes it this time. Respectable chicken curry. Wish he would have located in a less desolate and inconvenient stretch of Logan. He may have made it there. Most items in the market as a whole seemed slightly overpriced. I'll probably go back but it was overpopulated with tourists utilizing the Metra and they are generally not very pleasant to spend a lunch hour with. Maybe for baked goods in the AM?
review.author: Erik G.

review.description: I LOVE this place! I am a big fan of open markets like this, where I can pick and choose what I want. This is a new staple for my Mom and I when she is in town. I work at the Opera house and it is just a hop skip and a jump away. We love going there and looking around and getting a bunch of little things to share, it is the perfect lunch for us.
review.author: Chelsa P.

review.description:
Love it!  Living in the Loop this place is great for grabbing high quality ingredients (at reasonable prices) for dinner or have a quick bite to eat if you don't want to cook.

My Belgian husband is a huge fan of the Belgian fries (note the owner is from the Netherlands).  We learned that the owner had to import some of the equipment and experimented to find the right type of potatoes.  They serve it just like in Belgium - in a cone and sauce on top.  I think they just got their liquor license.  

We've also tried the Vietnamese food and baked goods....Like it all.

Our go-to place during the week.
review.author: Yini G.

review.description: How do many Chicagoans not know about this place! The French Market is one of Chicago's best assets to the loop. You can grab breakfast, lunch or dinner and be completely satisfied. The market type layout is perfect and they even have great places like Pastoral, Chicago Organics and Wisma. If you haven't gone here yet, you are missing out.
review.author: Sara G.

review.description: Not what i expected. Everybody talks very highly of the french market and i just wasnt that impressed. The crepe station was good but everything else I bought was just so so. I prob will not go back but happy I experienced it anyway
review.author: Brittany M.

review.description:
The setup lends more to a temporary setup rather then a actual long term store front. 
I made one unfortunate purchase at Abbey Brown. I was buying two gifts. It was suggested that maybe I put my purchases in my purse. When I asked for a 2nd bag as they were 2 separate gifts, I was told I would have to pay a $1 for a 2nd bag. I paid for the bag, but that will be the last thing I buy from that place.It's not like they were custom bags or anything, simple brown bags that they clearly stamp.  

 If you are looking for great products and outstanding service, I would recommend Olive Owl in Oak Park.
review.author: F S.

review.description: I was also looking forward to the opening and was very disapointed. I walked around on opening morning in a less than excited small crowd thinking, I wonder how long before this closes.  If you have been to a real open market like the amazing St. Lawrence Market in Toronto or ones in Philly or NY  you will be very disapointed. This is really an overpriced food court.  Not worth going out of your way for. No atmosphere, stark white bright and boring.
review.author: Deb M.

review.description: Relatively small in comparison to other cities.  Decent produce about the price you would expect to pay.
review.author: Jen H.

review.description: Why I didn't listen to my friends and come check out the French Market sooner is beyond me.  I finally decided to wander through French Market's doors after I moved to the city this April, and I haven't been ablet to leave since.  I pass it on my way home from work everyday, and the ability to walk in, waddle up and down the wonderful aisles and look at all the fresh food and produce, and take home exactly what I need on a daily basis reminds me of growing up in India.  I don't know why this concept didn't catch on sooner, but I am SO happy it's finally here.  My favorites are Pastoral, Pappardelles, and the little soap/sea salt bath place.  It makes me want to be back in Europe or India so bad.  The staff at Pastoral is always helpful and willing to take the time to help me select a new wine or cheese.  Pappardelles exotic variety of freshly made pastas has inspired me to cook some really great dishes and the soap place around the corner is always so inviting with its clean aromas.  I think it's time for me to finish up this review and head over there now actually.
review.author: Sonali K.

review.description: This place is really lovely. I'm always stopping by after work for a macaron from Vanille (the best!) or, if I'm really hungry, a sandwich from pastoral. If I had one complaint it would be the music. Dear french market,  PLEASE TURN IT DOWN!! Just a bit. It's very overwhelming. Everything else is wonderful.
review.author: sonia s.

review.description: My adoration for the French Market has waned throughout the passage of time.  At first I was very excited to find such a market in existence in a big city in the US.  Yes, in some ways it does have a European feel.  However, after being there probably ten or more times, I'm not too excited about it.  First, its really out of the way if you spend your time on the lake side of the loop (though parking isn't hard, but who drives downtown?).  Then, once you get there, seriously the prices are on par with jewel and the selection not that much better!  Yes, its nice to have pastoral, but there's a pastoral in the loop.  Yes, I do like the belgian beer and fries place.  Yes, I do like Vanille Patisserie (although there's one of those closer to my house anyway), but really for what you get, it's not worth the trip.  Plus the ambiance is heinous.  Really, really bad.  Florescent lighting, metal chairs... it feels like a cafeteria.  A badly lit cafeteria.  I don't like spending time in there at all.  Also, there's been a ton of turn-over with several of the vendors.  And once when I went there, it was to celebrate some French holiday, maybe Bastille day, and there was a singer belting Celene Dion in the common area.  No thanks, not even on Bastille day!!
review.author: Ali H.

review.description:
Since the opening I have visited here so many times I really can't even begin to count.  I've been trying to get around to all of the vendors and try something new each trip, but I'm only about a 1/4 of the way thru.  

I started with City Fresh Market and couldn't help but continue to return for their tuna salad. It's an ample (take-out) portion size in the $5 range.  I've also had their turkey roll-ups, pasta salads, and fresh produce/meats.  This has been very convenient for me to pop in, grab lunch or dinner and go!  
Another favorite of mine is Saigon Sisters.  The Porky sandwich is nothing like I've ever had before.   I highly recommend this one and I look forward to trying more items from their menu.  
I still frequent Pastoral because I'm in love with their cheese selection.  They also carry pate which I purchase on occasion.  
The fresh squeezed Orange Juice from (I think it's called) Juicy.  I've been there three times so I should know by now.  the first time I purchased a small o.j. I drank it so fast I regretted I didn't buy the large one. I've also visited the Organics & Necessity Baking.  
Soon, I will make my way towards some places catching my eyes - The Belgium Fries place, the pickle guy, Raw, Zullo's and Papardelle's.  

This Market carries fresh, high end products and usually the owners are serving you.  (Most of the sandwiches are about $6.  the produce prices are comparable to any other store.  Cheeses are priced at exactly what I'd expect and the desserts I've seen are gorgeous and priced right)  Everyone is friendly and ready to answer any of your questions.  This market has made things so much more convenient  for me.  If you haven't visited it yet you should stop in a take a peek.
review.author: Lily r.

review.description: The French Market is a great idea...not just the very European feel of the market, but the fact that's in the train station.  I always miss the Bahnhofs in Germany with their crazy morning bustle and the food vendors left and right, kind of like the Central Train Station of years past in the US...the French Market feels like a throwback those days.  The market is a great eclectic selection of fresh foods (read: yuppie...and yes, I am one of the chosen few, so it's OK to use the word), especially some great pastries and sandwiches.  We went on a Sunday morning and I settled on a lunch of Vietnamese Spring Rolls and left feeling full (in a healthy sort of way), cultured (that's right...these ain't your momma's fried egg rolls), and ready to visit the Art Institute (that one's unrelated to the goodness of the spring rolls).  Spring rolls aside, definitely sample some of the cheeses from the various vendors - my favorite was the chocolate cheese (it's exactly what it sounds like...delicious).  Take if it from a food snob from San Fran, French Market is worth a visit!
review.author: Rosers M.

review.description: A step in the right direction, but a long way to go.  I am a fan of Pastoral, so it is worth stopping by just for that.  I have yet to try Fumare, but it looks promising.  It certainly is convenient to be able to pick up fresh produce on my way home. There's too many bakeries (and that's after one of the bakeries pulled out at the last minute). And some of the food stalls were either out of food by 6pm or have not yet opened at all.  Food stalls need better signage for their menus.  I have been so looking forward to the opening of this market, but unfortunately I am disappointed.  Clearly not all stores were ready to open by December 3rd.  And too many bakeries.  Oh I already said that :-).
review.author: Jay B.

review.description: Walked home today with a baguette tucked under my arm and two meals of fresh ingredients in a bag.  Surprisingly inexpensive mix of fresh and prepared choices.
review.author: G G.

review.description: My hubby and I went here to grab dinner on a weeknight. We found parking on the street and paid for it before we saw a sign that said free parking if you purchase $20...too late...oh well. So I've been wanting to try bahn mi and pho from Saigon Sisters and that's what we got. Bad choice! It was the worst bahn mi and pho we have ever had and we paid $25. Never again! As for the rest of the market, it was pretty dead except for Pastoral. So next time...if we are in the neighborhood, we'll just go to Pastoral and maybe try the meat place next door too.
review.author: Daisyville C.

review.description: Meh - you might as well go to whole foods, selections is probably better there. There isn't much market atmosphere to it, feels more like a large food court than anything.
review.author: morten k.

review.description:
When I choose my food, I like to patronize the knowledgeable purveyor.  I like to have my questions answered about where my food came from and how it was prepared.  I like the reassurance that the food is fresh and is not preserved by chemical treatment.  Whole Foods does a good job of having people who can answer questions and make this information available, but the cost is prohibitive.  You can get this information from the farmers at the Farmers' Market, but in the bleak midwinter I'm not so willing to make the trek.

The French Market has a number of really terrific purveyors.  Lots of other reviewers sing the praises of Vanille Patisserie and they are correct.  These are the best croissants I have had in Chicago and I am addicted.  The Fumare Meats counter is another great place to shop.  This guy really knows his product and offers samples and advice.  His Irish style bacon is great and I have never seen a product like this anywhere.  Necessity Baking is outstanding.  They have bread that has not been overworked by machines so it has a wonderful body and a great crust.  One day I buy a decadent cheese bread and when that is gone I alternate with one of their delicious whole grain loaves.  Everything I have bought has been spectacular.  Produce Express (which runs down the center aisle) is terrific and they either label or can explain to you the origin on all their products.  They also have a daily supply of fresh herbs most of which are $1.50 per bunch.

Let me say I have not been disappointed with any of the vendors I have tried.  I don't buy much prepared food so I have only tried the Flip Crepes (the dessert one that is the cheapest) and that was very good.  They wrap it so it was still warm when I got it home.  The Delightful Pastries carry pierogi that you can heat up when you get home.  

Many reviewers are using their reviews to brag that they've had the authentic Euro market experience and this isn't it.  It is not Paris - what it does share with the European market is the small purveyor who is in touch with his or her product and has a passion for what he or she is selling to you.  

I am thrilled that I can stop at this place on the way home from work and get fresh veggies without having to go to a supermarket.  I don't know if it would be a destination for me - I would make a trip to visit the Fumare Meats.  I think this is his only shop.

I hope this business thrives and grows - there is plenty of empty retail space in that part of the station.
review.author: T M.

review.description: I walk over to the market at least 3 timer a week. I always end up getting something for lunch, or I purchase some produce from City Fresh Market, depending what they have that looks good that day. I am however tired of orderimg sandwihes or soups only to get back to my office and find out that I paid for an $8.00 loaf of bread with nothing in it, or my soup is in a small coffee cup for $3.00. I am willing to pay the high price, just don't cheat me. On my latest trip there I ordered fried clam strips, I was wondering why they didn't taste of clams, only to find out after breaking several of the strips open, that there were no clams in them. I was eating fried breading.The people that work in the market are very friendly and helpful, but the people managing  those stalls are cheating the customers. My guess is that the rent there is astronomical, and you might as well save wherever you can. I'm done getting ripped off.
review.author: Margo C.

review.description: This is a great location for a place like this. I love that there is tons of street parking available around here on the weekend. They validate with a $20 purchase I prefer the street. Good meat selection and really reasonable prices. Fish selection was really nice too and veggies were cheap! I really want this place to succeed. I always have problems deciding what to eat at places like this. Vendors were really, really nice and helpful. Why isn't this place open on Sundays? If anyplace should be open on Sunday this would be the place. I suppose they are going for the work crowd but they should think about people like me who will only find themselves here on the weekend because the hours make it impossible to get to during the week. I found a hot sauce I've been looking for today and was pretty happy with myself. I am going to go eat the pasta salad with feta that I bought right now. Nice price for it too...only 3 bucks. Oh yeah, and free meat and cheese samples....that's always nice.
review.author: Lois A.

review.description: Not really all that impressed with this place after all the hype. Some good things at the pastry and candy places, but everything is SUPER expensive at them. I've eaten at both the crepe place and buon appetito (Mexican) and I thought both were pretty gross, with the exception of the Mushroom Brie soup at the crepe pan. I found the Mexican place to be awful, and they couldn't bother to add the two items that I requested AND paid for to my food??? Also find it quite strange that they have a cheesy carnival food stand with caramel corn and cotton candy, but okay. The grass fed beef filets my husband bought for $30 last week were just "okay", but  certainly not as good as local restaurants who charge much less for the prepared version. My mom requested that we bring her some white chocolate bark from the candy place. . .it was $36 per pound and not that good. Its really disappointing considering that there had been so much hype about this place for the past few years, especially since we live in the immediate area. Maybe I will have a better experience here in the future, but from what I've seen/had so far, its just not that great. . . also a HUGE disappointment that the market is closed on Sunday.
review.author: Tracey G.

review.description:
So much hype for so little.

The market is still only partially full, and the selection is seriously redundant. The prices are high. Some vendors do not take credit cards. The ATM machine in the market was off (or not yet hooked up) this morning. It opens at 7:30 (a bit late for those of us who are commuters, and passing through the train station much earlier than that), but NONE of the vendors were ready then, and I was sorry that I milled around, waiting half an hour for it to open this morning. The guy at the crepe place actually waved me away because he was on the phone - won't be going back there (Crepe Cafe on Clark is a good bet, though! Try them - they're great). A guard followed me, commenting on my meandering while I looked in the cases (two cheese places? four bakeries, two with nearly identical cookies? a closed coffee place, closed mexican restaurant, and two closed asian restaurants? a rude crepe guy? WTF?)

Seriously. This market needs to get it together. I understand that they just opened, and that at 7:30 in the AM they've just opened daily, but maybe they aren't ready. Period.  

If you open at 7:30, be ready then! Trains are bringing in morning commuters much earlier than that, so an earlier opening time is probably wise, but if you don't have it together by 7:30 - seriously, no one was ready to sell me anything when I got there this morning - then what's the point? 

This could be a great place, if they did it right. I hope they pull it together. And, I hope that they start opening earlier, and are ready upon opening. But, I won't gamble by waiting on them again. Not worth it.

Two places in the area that offer a unique, European experience, with great customer service and commuter-friendly hours?  Hannah's Bretzels on Washington and the Crepe Cafe on Clark. I hit both on the way to work this morning.
review.author: Kate C.

review.description: I love this place and I'm always looking for an excuse to get over there. We've found it to be a great place to shop and prepare for a special meal when guests are coming over. The meat vendor is one of the few places where I have found grass fed beef (which has just about ruined all other steak for me) and they have an excellent seafood selection as well. There are wine vendors, pastry shops, cheese stands, produce vendors and cured meats shops as well as lunch options including Vietnamese, French, Belgian, and raw food. Prices tend to be a little high but the quality makes up for it in addition to supporting local / sustainable / small businesses. I think it's a fun little area to wander around in - every time I go back, I find something new. The free garage parking with purchase also makes it convenient. The vendors are also super-friendly - more than once, we've been given more than we've ordered or an extra cookie "just to try."
review.author: Edward S.
